" At 17, We met when we were at medical school. He started pursuing me and within a few months we were seeing each other — it was like a fairytale. I was one of the toppers of my class, had big dreams for myself and I'd been dating the man I loved.  I realised later  that his parents wanted him to marry a Marwari girl while I was Punjabi. They also wanted me to give up my education, but that's something my parents didn't allow — so even though I completed my masters their condition for our marriage was that I would never work — I was so madly in love that I agreed to everything. 
It started on the first night of my wedding when I didn't bleed and he was convinced I wasn't a virgin — he tortured me the whole night accusing me of sleeping with someone else. After we returned from our honeymoon he beat me up because I bought a kohl pencil for my sister —this happened in front of his parents who agreed with him. I had to wash clothes, cook, clean but never work. They allowed me to go to my father in law's clinic but only to dust his desk— I was given strict instructions to never attend to any patient. 
After a few years I got pregnant and he sobbed because it was a girl — he accused me of not giving him a boy. He began to drink, woke up at noon everyday and went to work whenever he wanted, because his father handled everything. 
I never told my parent's any of this but I broke when I was pregnant for the 2nd time. I'd just returned from England and was trying to talk to him when he told me to get lost. I took my daughter with me to the hall to sleep when he came out drunk, accused me of brainwashing our daughter against him, sat on my stomach and beat me until my entire face was bleeding. I called my dad at 4 in the morning and his parents came too, but instead of stopping him, they said I must have done something to 'provoke' him. My parents said they would call the cops and that's when he said, 'I won't beat you again but I will fuck your mind.'
That's exactly what he did — after his father passed away he would drink from 8:30 pm until 7 am and gamble instead of paying our daughter's fees. At night, he would throw cold water on me and say 'be thankful it's water and not piss', he would touch me wherever he felt like and call me all sorts of names in front of family and friends. My daughters were terrified, but 3 of us would sleep together and let him keep banging at the door. My older daughter is an athlete so we would wake up at 5 in the morning to go run at Juhu beach, while he was still drinking. Sometimes he would follow us. He would go upto my daughter in front of all her friends and say, 'where the fuck is your mother…who is she fucking now?' My daughter would try to calm him down and say that I was just walking with the other mothers. 
The breaking point came when his verbal abuse passed onto my daughters. He started calling them sluts and whores and my older daughter had a nervous breakdown in school.  I decided to leave him and when he came back home after being in rehab for the 4th time we decided to not let him in. Even after all this, I helped him get back on his feet, start practicing and even lent him my own money…but then he got me removed from the hospital where I was filling in for him while he had been drinking. Until today, he hasn't paid for anything for my daughters... even though he has 3 clinics.
At first I didn't know what to do but after 20 years I decided to open my own clinic —I didn't want any form of dependence. I work round the clock - pay for the clinic and house expenses. That man has even taken a loan against my name and he refuses to give me a divorce until I leave the house that my father and him bought together. It's been a dreaded 20 years, but my daughters have kept me going. They stick little notes on my wall saying 'we are strong' 'we love you mom' — and that has given me the strength to give them the life they deserve and finally be…free."

"When my parents passed away, I was devastated. Nothing fills in the void of losing your parents at a young age, but I knew then that I wanted to do everything I can to make children happy -- so here I am selling balloons and trying my best to spread some happiness."

"People often surprise you. 2 years ago I was in Delhi on 31st December when in the middle of the night I got separated from my friends and to make things worse I had misplaced my cell phone. I was terrified at that point -- it was past midnight, there was not a single cab in sight. I tried asking five or six women for their cellphones but they looked through me and walked away. 
I was lost and just standing on the road when a man approached me and asked me what was wrong. All kinds of things were going through my mind -- you hear so much about Delhi being unsafe that I was terrified, but this man who came upto me said, 'don't worry, I only want to help you' -- and that's what he did. He cancelled his own plans and dropped me to safety. That's the thing with this world -- we read so much that we stop believing that someone wants to help and on the day I needed it the most, it came not from the 6 women who I thought would help me out, but the 1 man who approached me. Not all men are like the ones you read in the papers...so stop believing it."

"A few of my friends and I started a project called Rastaa Chaap. We basically paint dead trees to make them beautiful works of art, but more importantly to create awareness about how many trees are dying around us.  We're not expecting the authorities to do things, we are not complaining, we're just going out there and trying to make a difference. 
We help people plant, protect and preserve trees and it's a small step, but it's a step none the less. Ever since we started, the support has been pouring in, in terms of volunteers or finances but one particular incident touched my heart. 
A young teenage girl came to me and said that instead of taking her friends out, she wanted to pay for all of her friends to plant trees. So on her birthday about 20 teenagers spent the day planting trees between 7th and 8th road in Juhu. What's amazing is that they haven't forgotten about their trees after that— on their way to school they would stop by and water them…this was when it was summer and the heat was unbearable -- it was heartwarming to see that they cared.
I'm just glad that I'm doing my bit to make this city greener and I hope that this little step can go a long way."

"The most difficult phase of my life would be right now. I'm studying to become a CA and everyday I go to class, go to office for my article-ship, go home, study, sleep and wake up the next day with the same routine. I've barely had any time to sleep, catch up with friends or do anything really...it's a difficult journey."
"Is there anything you did to break away from that?"
"I decided to take a break and do something which made me feel alive -- I went sky diving. I can't tell you how liberating that was and how much I needed it...it felt amazing to just be able to breathe."

"I was working a monotonous job around 40 years ago. I was working at a firm in New Bombay where my job was to unload the cargos which came in. Although I didn't like my job, I was always on time and never missed a day. I'd been working for a few years when one day I fell really ill and called my boss and told him I couldn't make it-- this was the first time since I joined the job that I wasn't going to work. On the same day, around 3:30 pm I received a call that the man who filled in for my job that day passed away because the hook of the machine broke and the cargo boxes fell on him.
I felt numb. I was so upset that he lost his life but what terrified me more was that it could have been me. I don't know what hit me, but I realized that I had been taking life for granted for far too long. What started off as a temporary job to make ends meet, grew to become a routine which I hated. 
I feel like that was the day I was born again-- I quit my job and started my own company. I've had ups and downs with that too but atleast I'm doing something that I love...that makes me believe I have a purpose. Every single day since the past 40 years, I wake up and thank God for this life and that one practice has changed everything. Because I'm so grateful, I know that nothing can pull me down-- highs and lows are a part of the process but I only get one life, a finite amount of time here and there's no way I'm going to crib about it. Life is beautiful and my only purpose is to celebrate it every day.

"I was born deaf and mute. We were living a good life until my father passed away and my mother had to raise my siblings and me by herself. My sisters were sent to Bombay to an NGO, but because I was the youngest and couldn't communicate I stayed behind with my mother. She worked at a dance bar, got into the sex trade and every night trusted our neighbour to look after me. 
What I didn't tell anyone for years is that our neighbour is the man who sexually abused me for many years. 
I didn't have a voice, but never before had I felt so voiceless. I was terrified of men and people in general.  I continued to keep quiet until the NGO which my sister's were a part of insisted that I join them. I still remember my first day at Kranti, I hid behind my mother's sari and wondered how I would communicate with any of them— only my mother understood me. I had never been to school before, but I started attending the Bombay Institute for the Deaf and Mute and I began to understand the world around me more. The other girls at Kranti began to learn sign language to communicate with me better and I understood what it's like to have friends who care and understand. Little by little, I broke the walls around me to allow people in.
Today, when my mother visits me I take her around the neighbourhood, travel with her in local trains and even bargain with vendors the best I can! It was only after I came to this city that I realised being sexually abused was not my mistake…and I had no reason to be silent.  My fear of men left me in the most unexpected manner. One of the girls from my NGO was taking down the trash at night, when a drunken man hit her. When we heard her screaming, all of us ran down to her but I was so angry that I chased after that man with a stick. I began to scream at him— not with words but just my voice which I'd kept within me for far too long. 
But that was another day, and I've had beautiful days since — I draw, I swim, I dance. Many people ask me how I can dance without music, but I just tell them that it's all in me - the song, the music and the spirit to keep taking the next step."

"I operated on a lady free of cost this one time, because she was critical but had no means of paying me. I never expected anything from her but a few days after her surgery, she came back to my clinic and gave me a big jar of homemade tomato ketchup as a thank you. I enjoyed the ketchup for many weeks to follow and everytime I had it, I thought of her and how deeply thankful she was...there are a lot of things money can't buy and this experience always reminds me of that."

"On his 4th birthday we took him to the Blind School to distribute cake and snacks to the kids there. It was beautiful -- they all sang Happy Birthday to him and even though my son realized that they couldn't see, he didn't think of them as different from him. In fact, they played together for quite some time and after that day he insists on visiting them often-- they've grown to become really good friends."

"The other day a customer came upto me, gave me a big bag full of restaurant food and said 'uncle, yeh aap ke liye choti si party'. At 78, I was amused that this youngster wanted me to have a 'party' but it was only when I got home that I realized what he meant by a celebration. I was so touched because that small gesture of his was actually like a real party for the entire family -- everyone loved the food and ate until there wasn't even a bite left and my grandchildren were absolutely thrilled with the sweet mango dessert!"

"What advice would you give to a large group of people?"
"Get out of your house more, have a goal that you can chase everyday and do something...atleast one thing in your lifetime to better your country."

"Ive had this store since 35 years. A lot has changed since then but this stall has been a part of my life for everyone of those days and there have been so many memories attached to it. 
One which I'll never forget is of this couple who came to have juice at my stall the day I opened...they were on their first date. I still remember seeing them and thinking 'college kids in love', but after that first date, they began to come to my stall every single Sunday. Years passed by, they got married and had children. A few years ago, one of their children was getting married so they came to me and asked me to have my juice stall at their wedding...I was thrilled! Just recently, they came to give me sweets because they had become grandparents -- I felt like I had become a part of their family over the years and I was so touched that they wanted to share their happiness with me as well!
Love is a funny thing...there have been days when only of them have come to my stall to 'take away' some juice because the other one isn't feeling well. Other days when they're quarrelling or times when they're sharing one glass even though there's plenty for both! From watching them as college children in love to being parents...I feel lucky to have played a small part in their love story and witness something so special in front of my eyes."

"When it rains heavily, I always think of the 2005 floods. I was stuck under the Parel fly-over with a man who wanted to reach his home in Ghatkopar. The water levels were so high, we couldn't even open the cab door to get drinking water but people started passing vada pav and water from car door to car door until it reached all those who couldn't reach food stalls. In my 40 years of driving a cab, I've never seen Bombay come together the way it did during those days -- there was no rich or poor, just humans trying to help each other in any way possible.
My passenger and I were stuck in my cab for over 10 hours and during that time we spoke about a lot of things -- from our families to our dreams. There were no barriers as he candidly told me about his life and I told him about mine. As the conversation went on, one thing became clear -- we came from different social classes but all we both cared about was getting home to our families. 
As the water started clearing the next morning, I decided to go to drop him to his family in Ghatkopar even though my house was nearby...I don't know why but I felt responsible for him.  When I did, he thanked me over and over again, gave me extra money even though I tried to refuse and said he would always remember me. I don't know about him, but every time it rains, I think about that night and how a flood unknowingly brought us all closer together."

"We were engaged for two years before marriage, but because I was from Kanpur and he was from Bombay we couldn't meet as often. My maternal grandparents lived in Bombay, so every summer vacation I would come here, and everyday after his work he would come pick me up. Those were great days, but eventually I would have to go back to Kanpur where I would wait anxiously for his letters. In those days, there was no telephone...but thank God for that -- I have each and every one of the letters he's ever written to me...and we've been married 52 years!
His letters were very romantic -- he would quote the great poets of our time and use his own words to express his love for me."
"Do you remember a particular letter?"
"Yes, he once wrote -- 'I've loved you for a 1000 years already, but I still love you today and I'll love you tomorrow.' Let me tell you, it's been a memorable life with him...we've shared it together for 52 years and with time, he's become more romantic! There's only one secret to a relationship like ours -- Give, give and give! We both have given to each other, without expecting anything in return and that's why we're still madly in love -- it's a beautiful feeling."

"A few days ago I met an old man who told me he hadn't eaten in days and pleaded with me to buy him some food. I readily bought him a hot plate of food from a stall near by and watched him eat it. He looked at me and said, 'you've been like an angel to me today...I guarantee that in the future if ever you have a trying time...someone or the other will show up to help you out -- it's how the cycle of life works."

"I was passing DY Patil hospital one day when I saw a girl sleeping outside -- weak to the point that you could see her bones. I found out that she was HIV positive and had lost both her parents. I asked what she would like to eat and she said noodles, but I couldn't find them anywhere so I promised her I would return the next day. She passed away that night and that incident kept haunting me, so I went inside the hospital and asked them to contact me if there were any such children in the future. 
2 such children were sent to me for different reasons. In 2009, I took a space on rent in Navi Mumbai for my wife, my two children and the two HIV positive children. At first it was difficult to make ends meet -- we could afford one mattress on which my 4 children slept and my wife and I would make do without. Eventually, people started donating -- beds, grains and money. My family of 4 slowly expanded to 24 as more and more children with HIV were sent to me. 
My wife has been a rock solid support and we've never differentiated between our children -- we scold all of them, love all of them and give them the same gifts. My wife cooks for all 24 of our children, looks after their medication and takes them for their medical check ups. We've tried to give all of them a good education and make sure that they have a life worth living. 
An incident I'll never forget is of a boy who was abandoned by his parents and brought to us in the last stage of tuberculosis and HIV.  We took him in, gave him all the fresh juices and lentils he needed. We began to laugh around him, make him play with us and showered him with so much love that he had to recover! Within two weeks from not being able to get up, he was running around everywhere!
That's the most fulfilling part about what I do -- I can proudly say that my family of 24 is overflowing with love! Being HIV positive doesn't mean that they have to cut their life short...they can live as long as any normal person and that's what I'm here for...to save them and give them a long life. And with love and care, everything is possible. These children all call me 'Papa Reji' and it's the duty of a father to protect...so I'm not someone special -- I'm just a father looking after my children."

"We met in school and what started as a friendship eventually grew to love. We were from different communities and no matter how much we tried to convince our families to allow our marriage...they refused. After a lot of thinking, we decided to run away and get married...not being together wasn't an option. We tried for many years for our families to accept us, but they refused. I knew how hard it was for him, but he never once made me feel less loved...in fact he showered me with more happiness and relentlessly tried to make both our families agree. 
My parents wanted me to marry someone within the community who was making more money but that didn't matter at all when we were together. Every small thing was celebrated... all our meals, the movies we watched when we could afford it and the life we shared together from children to parents ourselves. He passed away a few years ago, and there's no amount of words to describe his loss. The only thing that made me go on about my life was wanting to make him proud of me. I worked harder, earned honest money and continued our journey in this life alone. He's still very much with me...just not physically and that gives me all the strength I need."

"I'm from Jodhpur, and only got to Bombay about 2 days ago. The people here are hilarious! Yesterday, I went shopping and asked the shopkeeper - 'uncle, how much for this?' He turned around and said - 'only 500 Rupees, Auntyji'...I couldn't stop laughing!"

"I have two daughters, both of whom are in college. My girls have been very responsible and aware that I'm a house cleaner with limitations. Many years ago, when they both were still very young they did something that I'll never forget. They must have gotten a part time job or something, but one night when I went home for dinner they said, 'let's go out, today... it's our treat.' As a father, it was a very special day for me."

"I'm always happy...I find happiness in everything, but everyday I go to sleep believing that my happiest time is yet to come."
"When was the last time you were extremely happy?"
"Just a few days ago, there was a man eating pav bhaji at a shop by the beach. I kept looking at his food and salivating but within a few minutes the shopkeeper shoo'ed me away. A few minutes later that man came upto me and bought all my windmills without bargaining even once! Infact, he gave me some extra money which I tried to return, but he gave it back to me and said 'it's for your dinner'. 
Before that I'd never gone to a shop and asked for a full meal...I was usually given left overs and never allowed to enter. But that day I went to that shop and walked in confidently. I ordered a pav bhaji for myself and even ordered an extra bread -- it was the best day!"

"I decided to block out the noise and focus on me. I started taking spanish classes and love every minute of learning. The summer after my accident I took a trip to Punjab with my friends — everyone was concerned about how I would travel by train for 30 hours and manage…but I did and it felt liberating.
I'm also part of a whatsapp group where we're 20 women who all have prosthetics and it's a great platform to share. I've always loved to swim so I was concerned about how I would be able to, but a woman on that group suggested to take off my foot and just go for it. I tried it and I could still swim with so much ease…it felt normal!
After I graduated, I took off on a solo trip in Europe for 3 weeks. I was staying in hostels, doing all the local stuff and not once did I feel out of place — nobody cared about my missing leg!
I returned to Bombay and joined a startup as a Director. It's called Laughguru and we educate children using humour as a teaching tool. I work 12-13 hours a day and it's the most fulfilling experience of my life. 
What's funny is that I lost all my confidence over what people were saying but got it back in the most hilarious way. One night, my girlfriends and I were drinking and they told me I should get on a dating app and just go with it! We began to swipe right and I started getting matches. I started chatting with boys and after the first few conversations if they asked me to meet, I would tell them about my leg — not one of them thought it was a problem. As stupid as it sounds, it was validation enough that people can look beyond a 'disability' so to say. Ofcourse, this was fun while it lasted but I met someone when I signed up for a Public Policy course. He's from Bangalore, I'm from Bombay but we've been dating for nearly a year and he's amazing! 
My life has undergone such drastic change these past few years, but in the end no one can hurt me unless I let them. From losing a foot to solo trips to foreign lands, from worrying about 'who will be with me?' to being with someone who accepts me and loves me for who I am and from being an 18 year who didn't know if a missing foot would allow me to work to being a director at a company… Life has been everything I chose to make it." (3/3)

"After my amputation I was discharged from the hospital after 2 weeks. Then started the process of learning how to walk with the prosthetic leg and getting up from the wheelchair. I was worried that I would have to miss a year but Xaviers supported me relentlessly through this time — they sent exam papers home and even let me attend Malhar on a wheelchair. 
Slowly, I began to walk again. It was painful at first but I was determined to 'able' myself again. I started going to college first by car and then by train — all in a span of months. 
The prosthetic wasn't the difficult part, dealing with people was.  Often, I would be sitting on the train and the person opposite me would keep staring or nudge their neighbour and ask them to look at my leg — like it was on display. 
What's worse is the bureaucracy — when I tried to get a driver's licence was entirely different for me because I was disabled — I thought it would be easy but they made it extremely strenuous. I had to get different medical certificates from all over the place, I had to give a different test and could only drive if the car was registered in my name. My family had to sell the car we owned just so that I could buy the same one in my name  and modify it— all for a licence. If they really wanted to enable the disable they would make it easier…this whole process took me a year!
Recently, I had a nasty experience at the airport when I was flying. They made me go to a 'private' room which was a store room, remove my jeans and take off my leg which they then thew it into the scanner along with mobile phones, shoes and belts. How could I explain to them, how bad that made me feel?— that leg is a part of my body. I was hopping around on one leg for 45 minutes and finally when I could board I just burst into tears. I was so frustrated because while I was trying to feel normal and not 'disabled' these things served as a constant reminder. I thought having mobility would be tough…but these kind of little incidents, made it a terrible, prolonged experience that only made me more determined to fight." (2/3)

"6 years ago, I was walking down my lane when all of a sudden a big bulky branch fell on my legs- breaking my left leg and completely crushing my right. I was completely unconscious until half an hour later, when I woke up in a hospital bed. At first I thought it was a dream, but then I looked down and saw a mangled mass of blood and bones and I knew that something major had happened.
"Did you find out how you got to the hospital?"
"Because this happened on the street I lived, I knew all of the vendors down the road. The chaiwallah and vegetable vendor who I passed every day, picked me up and took me to the hospital. Infact when I was discharged and at home, they both came to visit me and find out how I was doing. 
"What happened next?"
"I went into surgery almost immediately after which I'd lost all my toes and a part of my foot. It was after a few hours that my mom sat me down and explained to me that I would have to amputate my foot because there was a chance of my leg getting infected. All this while I was completely dazed but it was only after the surgery that everything began to sink in. What made it worse was how people all of a sudden began to look at me as disabled and gave me a world of pity. Others started talking in not so hushed voices, 'who will marry her?' 'Her family will have to look after her forever.' My confidence began to dip… I was all of 18 and had no idea how things would pan out for me." (1/3)

"Can I take your photograph?"
"Sure... as long as you don't make me move or ask me any more questions."

"I was raised in a very close-knit conservative family. When opting for what I should study in my undergrad, my father suggested B-comm and I agreed without giving it much thought. After graduating however, I realised that I felt really passionately about design and straight out of college I decided to start my own label. Within a few short years, I was running a successful company and had clients all over the world placing orders for my silk products. 
During this period, I began to take a path down spirituality and one particular ashram where I began to learn and grow. It was here that I became aware that silk is made by boiling silkworms — and it didn't sit right with me to make money off another living being's pain. I gave up my company overnight and focused on finding my purpose in life. I was married at the age of 25 and had two beautiful daughters. 
Decades later, the Ashram which I was connected to was planning to expand. I loved design and still felt really passionately about it, so I knew that I wanted to be the one to design this plan…but I had to be worthy of something so special. At the age of 48, I found my calling and enrolled myself in Design School as an undergrad student. 
On my first day there, the principal asked me if I had any financial difficulty or had any qualification in design…and both answers were a 'no'. He told me that I wouldn't last more than 3 months….and that fuelled me to prove him wrong. Funnily enough, my daughter was in the same college and we overlapped one year but that experience was the best of my life — my daughter and I would be completing our assignments until early morning and my husband would make us both coffee! Even though I was much older, I made a lot of friends…they would come to my house, I would make them some treats and we would all study together. 
I graduated with a distinction and that very principal handed me my degree — I felt truly blessed. By tremendous grace I was
given my Ashram project after I formally established my company. Today, I have 150 employees and a purpose that makes me jump out of bed every morning. Everyday, I'm trying to give back the money that I've earned myself— just recently I adopted a child who suffers from cancer and that bond is something special as well. So Believe in yourself before you expect people to believe in you. Know that an honest passion will take you places and that life is about balance but also about celebration. Faith will keep you grounded and the right priorities will give you flight. Know that there is a time for everything but nothing is defined by the time you have lost in your life — it's never too late to start over."

"It's been 50 years since my family has been fighting a case for a piece of land that was given to my grandfathers by our Raja. He gave us all the papers with all the right authority letters and signatures, but when the new government came into power my father didn't register the land because he was unaware and uneducated.  As a result, the government took our land away without even informing us. 50 years later and the case is still going on. 
This court case has changed my life -- if I had that piece of land I would be able to put it to such good use and give my family a comfortable life. Instead, I'm working as a security guard in Bombay, struggling to make ends meet. So many people tell me - 'this is life, you have to deal with it' -- but I think that, this is India and I have no option but to deal with it."
"I absolutely love my job -- all the running around has made me quite thin...as you can probably see."

"Love to me, is the only thing in this world that's free... but we don't spread enough of. It doesn't matter who you are or where you're from, you can generate love just as much as anyone else can and that's what it's meant for... to be shared and transferred to everyone you come across in your life."

"I grew up in a small village where my family couldn't afford to send me to school, because we couldn't make ends meet. When I was 6 years old, my neighbour who was like a brother to me said that he'll take me to Bombay and educate me. So desperate was my thirst to learn, that without telling my parents I went off with him. It was the biggest mistake of my life.
He sold me to a Nepali family for 50,000 Rupees and ran away.  Theirs was a proper family with 2 children who went to school everyday, while I was made to clean the house and if it wasn't properly done - I was beaten. At 8, I was forced to go to a dance bar and wear inappropriate clothes. I would scream to go back to my family, but it was pointless. They would beat me with belts and stub me with cigarette buds to drown my voice out but when I would keep screaming and they couldn't house me anymore — they sold me to Kamathipura. 
Here again, I was beaten and forced to attend to over 10 clients a day — at the age of 10. I was broken — I lost my childhood and wondered if I would ever see light again. But amidst the darkest of humanity, I found someone with a heart. When he was told that he was my client…he was taken aback. He realised how small I was, so the next day he went to the police station and brought them to check on me. On realising that there was a police raid, some girls hid in a trap below the floor, others in a ceiling flap and I was pushed into a cupboard. The police kept searching for me and even though I was scared of being beaten, I decided to raise my voice. I started banging from the inside of the cupboard, they opened it, rescued me and took me to Devnath Home in Chembur. I was given days of counselling and taught to read and write, but there are some scars which even decades can't heal.
After 7 years, I was shifted to Purnata, a hostel where my new life began. I took hair cutting courses and parlour treatment courses. With this, I got a job at a parlour where I've worked everyday and slowly collected money.
Today, I've bought my own house with the money I saved up and a small loan from Purnata. I have a honest job, good colleagues and many friends. Up until now, I haven't told my colleagues my story out of fear that I will be outcast…but I've had enough. I want to show my face and have pride in my journey. The highlight of it all? Every month, I go back to Kamathipura the very place that has haunted me for years to counsel those who are stuck and encourage them to leave with me — so many have.  I've even tried teaching those girls whatever skills I have, just so that they're motivated. A time will come, when I go to that place and have no one left to save…but until then I won't stop trying."

I lived in Ahmedabad with my parents and 4 sisters. I used to work in a beauty parlour there to earn some money for my family. At the age of 24 i was married to a man who claimed to be from the same community as myself. He promised a simple but secure future for us in Mumbai. On reaching here I realised it was all a lie.

We were living in a single room with no basic amenities, he was not a builder but used to iron clothes for a living. He worked till midnight and drank till he fell asleep. I was not allowed to speak to anyone, get out of my house or work. I wasn't even allowed to eat dinner unless he was hungry which was generally at 3am post work. I was also never allowed to cook anything accept rice and dal, if meals were left over then I was not allowed to eat anything else for breakfast or lunch the next day. Between all this and the continuous physical abuse my life began to crumble into scars, blood and tears. At one point the beating got too much and i went back to my parents home but due to their own limitations there was only this much help i could take from them. 

I decided to come back to Mumbai and soon i was expecting my first child,i thought it would make things better but i got beaten up and kicked a lot more thereafter. He would accuse me of sleeping with other men and refused to admit the child was his. In my ninth month he kicked me in the stomach and threw me out of my house which is when my mother came down from Ahmedabad and took me there with her so i could deliver my baby.

I gave birth to a beautiful boy who then became my pillar of strength. On the fourth day post delivery my husband came to the hospital, beat me up, took my son and ran out of there suddenly claiming that because its a male child it's his. Once again I was compelled to go back and live a life there for my son. 

That is when I kept telling myself, If he slaps you twice, you need to slap him back once but by making something real of your life.

This time around when I got back I decided to work. I began going door to door finding clients and provided services like waxing, facials and so on. Soon my clients began to grow in number and I began to make a living for my son. During this time my husband fell seriously ill and his kidneys began to fail. I supported him through his surgery using the money I got by selling jewellery, donations and personal savings but despite this there was no change in the way he treated me but I didn't care. My heart was beating for my son and it was only his future i needed to look forward to.

I earned enough over time to make a house for myself but during the heavy rains a large tree collapsed on my house but I didn't back down. I worked harder, slept lesser, ran around for a million permissions and re built my house around the same one room i used to live in before. Now I have 6 rooms where I work, live and still play host to my husbands younger brothers who continue to ill treat me & refuse to pay for anything in the house despite having a good salary.But the land i live on is still in my husbands name and the cost of a new space in mumbai is far from something i can afford and so i need to continue living with them in the house. 

i made enough money to send my son to college in Gujarat and today i am providing for a family of 4 which includes my son, my husbands two brothers and my dog named Tuffy.

Today I stand fearless, having seen struggle beyond my imagination. I believe that determination and faith in my own strength can take me places, I believe in living a honest and driven life, I believe in celebrating life no matter what and I do this by learning traditional dance forms in my free time to keep me happy. I recently performed on stage with my group for the first time and despite knowing no one in the audience I danced my heart out. 

Yesterday was my husbands 10th year death anniversary and my son and I both payed a tribute to him by doing a small prayer and giving the local cow Prasad as per our traditions. But when I'm asked repeatedly by my clients to re marry i only have one response…I am complete in me.

I grew up in Australia, until my family moved back to India when I was 8. Following that, my life has been pretty humorous. I was teased for having an Australian accent, but picked up the Indian accent pretty quickly. While I was at BIS, I remember being ostracised from the group of boys because I was very open about liking girls, what I liked about them…and the others were still going through the 'we don't like girls phase'. 
I then moved to The American School, where I was teased for having an Indian accent…I decided then 'fuck accents' and say the words the way I liked how they sounded. I guess I've always been acting... It's always been around. I never thought much about 'career,' but I've never loved anything more than movies. Even though I didn't major in acting at college, I took interesting classes which challenged me. I didn't do a lot of work, but I realised that I wanted to make the most of everything…I was directing my own plays, writing and making a complete fool of myself.
I remember this one time, as a dare I stormed into this Karate class and said 'I challenge you to a fight to death'. The professor then came upto me, lifted me up by the collar and said… 'I will make sure you are incapable of ever taking my class' — I was fucking terrified and humiliated. It was still the orientation period at college, and I thought I was in serious trouble. Apart from that, my college life involved late night discussions, drugs and nudity…but my PR team has given me a strict talking to about revealing those stories.
I got a play straight out of college and worked at the Alliance Theatre in Atlanta for a year after which I returned to India and went to an Ashram in Bihar for 5 months. This was the point where I had less interest in acting and more interest in discovering things about myself…so I took off. When I returned, I wouldn't say I struggled, but I did odd jobs here in Bombay, went for auditions, got rejected a bunch of times but the thing that kept me going was that I never doubted getting roles. I knew it was a matter of time so I took whatever was happening in the meanwhile as a road to eventually getting there. 
My life has been a series of passionate decisions - from acting one day to dropping everything and going to an ashram, from being a hard core meat eater, to becoming purely vegetarian, from working round the clock to dropping everything to just walk around… I like to do things that I didn't expect myself to do. Life for me has been about limitations and pushing myself to beat them. It's been about learning different things…and knowing that I can learn anything with time and patience and knowing that I will succeed. Advice? I don't really have any advice…I would say— just try to live your life. I mean I'm barely living my life…who will I give advice to?"

"As a child, I was never great at art but I just loved to draw no matter what my work looked like. Very early on I knew that I wanted to be an artist, but I still have no explanation why...it gives me a feeling I can't describe. 
Obviously, when the time came to apply to college I applied to an art college here in Bombay and realized that I would have to give an exam to get in. In a one hour time limit I had to paint an object that was placed in front of me and even though I could manage it...that wasn't my definition of art and I didn't get in. How would I? They only accept 10 students out of the thousands who apply. I was disheartened, but I didn't give up and attended a private art institution. A few weeks later, my teachers there said that I don't have a future in painting and that I should try something else out. I left this institution and applied to the same college which rejected me earlier, but I failed again. I felt terrible and in order to feel better I applied for a BA course and started attending college...but my heart was only in the art that I wanted to create. 
Two significant things happened in 2015 which changed my life. I lost both my grandparents in a span of 6 months. I spent a lot of time with them before and having seen me being so passionate about art and still failing, my grandmother said to me - 'don't worry about these minor hurdles...you're going to do great things.' Around the same time, my BA semester results came out and I had failed 4 subjects...I decided to drop out. So there I was at 19, rejected from art college twice and failed my BA already. The only thing that stayed in my mind, was what my grandmother said and the passion I felt. I started painting more than ever, fuelling my failure to push me harder. 
In December 2015, I started posting my art work on an Instagram handle I created. Day after day, I started receiving messages and comments about my work and before I knew it I got my first major feature in Huffington Post!  Someone even wanted me to make a painting for them -- so I even earned my first money through the art that I felt so passionately about. Today, my work has been featured on multiple platforms and I have over 57,000 people following my art...all because I failed my first semester, while I was trying to be somebody I wasn't. I'm applying again to the same art college and I still don't know if i'll make it or not. I don't understand the testing system in this country or the limited seats or the cut offs...but I understand Art and I'm not going to let any college make me believe otherwise."

"Age and maturity aren't necessarily related. I'm 20 years old, but the oldest of 6 siblings and I understand my responsibilities towards my family. I'm still studying, but I know that there will come a time when my younger sisters may not get a full education or the liberty to study as much as I have, so I've figured out a number of ways to help the situation. 
Everyday after college, I tutor children to save some money, after which I go home and help my sisters with their homework -- my middle sister and I stay up 'till late, studying because we're trying to get her a scholarship for college next year. Like I said, I don't think age has anything to do with it...I just feel responsible for them. You caught us on a good day actually...I've brought all them here to the beach because I did very well in my exams. They're in the water now, but as soon as they come out I'm buying them gola-- it's our all time favorite!"

"I started working when I was 13 years old at a mill, but because of a union strike I was fired. 25 years ago, I started this flower business and it's been my source of income ever since. I wake up every morning at 3 AM, take the first local to Dadar flower market, buy my supplies and reach Borivali to sell by 7 am, after which my day only ends at 9:30 PM.
When I was a 13 year old boy who had to give up his education, I remember wanting to desperately study, but had no means to. At that young age, I made a promise to myself to never allow the same thing to happen to my children. 
I have two children- my daughter who has finished her graduation and working at a finance company, and my son who's in his second year of college. Of all the dreams I've had, this is the one that I made sure came true. To you it may not sound like a lot but every minute of the 15 hour work day I've had for the past 25 years, has been worth it...just to see this day."

My father owned a tobacco shop 25 years ago. He realized that tobacco was helping him earn but harming people. So he set up this shop and I've been taking care of it ever since. We sell worship material and my whole family is a believer in God.
Being one of the oldest shops in the market, it's always busy with customers. People of different age groups come to my shop. Not shockingly, there's a surge in student visitors during the exam season. 
Why do you believe in God?
Because of my mother. When I was a kid, she talked about God like he was her closest friend. She was convinced he deeply loved her. Any concern she would talk to God, trusting him to work it out or care for her in some way. 
She would tell me, quite candidly, that she was praying and that God would act upon her concerns. For years, I regularly saw what seemed to be answers to her prayers. I watched her life through a myriad of circumstances, and her faith in God was unwavering.
Ever since then I've believed in God but not just the one we worship in temples, but those around us. For me, my mother is no less than a God -- she's taught me about faith, kindness and being a good human.
I don't know if God exists or not, but what I think is being true to yourself and others is a great service to God. Every person who you meet is Godlike, if you just open your eyes to it."

"We met at college and became friends instantly. This one time, he drove me to the market to buy groceries when this lady came upto me and asked me to help her pick mangoes. While I was talking to her, he came upto us and said hi. The lady who asked me for help asked , 'who's this boy?' and I said 'oh he's a friend'. She paused, smiled and then with a straight face said, 'you two are going to get married someday.' At that point we were just  friends, so I started blushing and looking for words, but by the time I turned around to ask her why she thought that…she was already gone! It's so funny how people can tell there's some connection between two people even before they realise it themselves.
As it turns out, we started hanging out so much, that a  year and a half later we did start dating. I'm very traditional, so I think he picked up on the fact that my parents would need to be asked for my hand or any major life decision. He planned a dinner with my mother and me and I still remember how it all happened. I was taking a sip of my cocktail when he was rambling to my mother about something and then out of the blue he finished his sentence with… 'and that's why I want to ask you for your daughter's hand in marriage.' I remember spitting my drink out and just looking at him because he hadn't even mentioned it to me yet. Meanwhile, across the table my mother's telling me in our local language — ' yes! I can't wait to tell all your aunties!'. It was a funny dinner but I'm so glad my mother agreed. We got married soon after and it's like we're still dating in college. Just the other day, he got me lilies for absolutely no reason and I couldn't stop blushing!
Sometimes two people are just destined to cross paths — he's from Russia, I'm from Gambia but we met at college all the way in the US…it's amazing how the Universe works it's magic."

"I was born in Gambia, Africa but lived pretty much all over the world because as career diplomats, my parents were constantly on the move. Having lived in so many different places, I realised that human behaviour is the same all over the world no matter which country, religion or race. 
It all originates from what we as children grow up believing or accepting as the truth. If as a child you talk back, throw tantrums or are withdrawn…there are reasons for all those things, but we just don't understand them.
While most schools focus on the Intelligence Quotient of young adults, very few focus on the Emotional Intelligence…something that helps children reflect, understand and correct their actions. I founded 'Global Village Children' to help schools include Emotional Development into the curriculum of children. 
What we want the world to understand is that, disgruntled children go on to become disgruntled adults. If we teach children that we can't control the actions of others and that we're responsible for the actions of only one 'being' in the entire world - ourselves…we will empower an entire generation. 
The only way to World Peace is to raise a generation thats at peace with themselves, and the road to that is to place as much importance on our emotional understanding as we do on Math, History or Physics. The grades will come and go, but understanding what it takes to be a good human being is a lifelong skill…something that can't be replaced."

"About 15 years ago, I visited an orphanage where my brother-in-law was distributing bread-butter to the children who were so grateful to try something different. I've always been a housewife who loves feeding my children everything they wish to eat and it pained me to know that these children weren't getting to experience the excitement of eating their favorite dish. 
Since then, every weekend I feed about 350 children from orphanages and the Blind School, whatever they wish to eat. I wake up at 4 am every Saturday and cook for them, as I would for my own children and this is the highlight of my life…I live for it. Just last weekend I made 50 kgs worth of mango ras for them and my God, you should have seen their faces! They were thrilled… and I can't put into words how that made me feeI-- I was just so happy."

"I was born in a family of limited means. We were all sent to school, but in the 7th standard my family decided that I should drop out — and I didn't fight it because I knew that money wasn't coming in easy. My brothers continued to go to school and I took classes in sewing and embroidery, until the age of 14 when I got married to my husband who was only 16 back then. In our community, this wasn't unheard off. Even though we were both children, the responsibility on us was immense — my father-in-law was no more and my husband's brother passed away in a train accident, leaving behind his wife and two children who were to be looked after as well.
At the age of 15, I began to go door to door in big buildings, asking if their trash needed to be collected. I started collecting trash this way and it led to me becoming a rag picker. I was always well received by people who would call me a 'sweet girl' or give me sweets to eat, all because I never complained about anything. Some of these people gave me bigger jobs like cleaning their home and I took on them gladly because I knew that my family desperately needed the money. 
I became a mother after a few years and I wondered how I would tell my children that this is how I earn my money. I decided I would wait until the right age — but all of my apprehensions disappeared when the time came to send them to school. I realised, that if it weren't for the 10,000 Rupees I was earning every month…they wouldn't have an education. I had tears in my eyes as I thanked God for everything — the foul smell of garbage, the hard days of going door to door and the different homes I cleaned. 
Both my sons accept my work and there is nothing more I could ask for. I was terrified that they would be embarrassed of me, but they have been so supportive. My younger son recently wrote an essay on me for his class. It was called, 'My Mother Keeps India Clean'— I didn't understand a lot of it but it was enough just to know that he wrote about me…I'm a happy mother."

"Why waste money on rent, when you can have a walking-talking store, like me?"
"It's a great way to sell...do you have a name for it?"
"Yes...it's called Jugaad."

"My father passed away when I was 6 years old. We were living in a village in Andhra back then and being the oldest son, I had to give up my education in the 5th standard and start working. I used to work two jobs - one as a farmer and another in a clothing shop, but despite that money was tight -- so my uncles got my  younger brothers and to Bombay, in the search of more money.
As soon as I came here, I landed a job of washing cars. Today my day starts something like this - I wake up at 4:30 and wash about 30 cars in one day to earn 13,000 Rupees a month. A few months ago, I took up an additional job at a Gas Agency where I work as an LPG Delivery boy -- I earn 400 Rupees a day to deliver 35 gas cylinders. 
Last year my uncles abandoned us, but we managed to get our own kholi in Dharavi -- it's small, but it's a home none the less. I cook a hot meal for my brothers at about 4 in the morning, and then they help me wash cars...I'm happy I at least have some family here. We miss our mother terribly -- she's still in our village, but at least she's happier now that we are fending for ourselves and putting food on the table. 
At 22, I feel like I'm doing as much as I can. Sometimes my body gives up -- that's how exhausted I get but even after all that labour the money isn't enough. Every month however, I save a little and put it away for my education. I was a bright student, and the child in me still wants to sit in a classroom and wear a uniform. I have my schedule in place -- I'll continue to wash cars before and after school to keep my income alive and  I'll sleep 2 hours less to complete my homework. I know I haven't saved enough, but in the 3rd standard, I once learned that 'slow and steady wins the race' -- I believe that, that will be true in my case as well."

A few days ago we shared the story of Nagendra Tomar, a man who fell into a pot hole at his labour site after which his skull started eroding and eye sight started fading. Thanks to you beautiful people, we've managed to raise over 12 lac Rupees and Nagendra finally has a chance to get operated and live a normal life!

Here's his reaction, when Ria of Make Love Not Scars broke the news to him :)

https://www.facebook.com/makeluvnotscars/videos/978454812237216/

"Every morning before and after school, I help my mother at the shop. She's raised me by herself, so I want to help her out as much as I can. I also come here because this way, I get to spend more time with her -- so in between, when there are no customers I tell her about what I learnt at school. I'm also teaching mama some Math -- she's very bad at calculations -- while I'm here I handle it, but when I'm not she makes a lot of mistakes. But I've found a solution to that as well...
I ask her to play 'teacher - teacher' with me and try to make her addition and subtraction better and she's learning well-- she's my best student!"

"I've always wanted to be a nurse and at 19 when I cleared my SSC, I thought that I could become whatever I wanted -- but I was wrong. My parents forced me into getting married to a man who lives in a nearby village. I accepted their decision, moved away and tried my best to become a home maker. A few months into our marriage I was pregnant and at that age I was scared, but little did I know that I would have a lot more to fear. My husband, brought home another young woman, casually and began living with her without even giving me an explaination. I can't describe those feelings into words. There's no worse pain than emotional pain and I knew that I couldn't live like that.
I left him and came back here to Bombay only to find that there was no comfort back home either. People were doubting my character, asking me humiliating questions about my child and treating me like an outcast. At 20, this was a huge burden for me to bear, but it was the fact that I had a child in my stomach that gave me strength. I ignored what people were saying and silently began working to support myself. My brother allowed me to stay with him as I worked at multiple houses to support myself and save for my child's needs. I kept myself so busy that there was no time to listen to anything that was being said and it got even better when my son was born -- my entire struggle melted away. With great pride I sent him to school...I still remember his first day. There were times when it was tough to juggle my jobs, cook for him, pick him up for school, but we managed and managed really well -- today he works at a machine factory and has a beautiful family of his own in a small town near Bombay. I could have lived with him, but I love my life here...
Yes, I am a divorced woman, but my life has had more meaning than that. Let me tell you that the initial challenges have made me a strong independent woman. Through this process, the one thing I've learnt is to keep growing and pushing forward. Since the past 10 years, I've joined a library and read two books a week...which has helped me grow and understand affairs of the world. I also stitch quilts and bags as a side business while continuing to work as domestic help at a few houses. 
At 60, I'm not only a single mother, but a single grandmother and I'm not ashamed to be called a 'divorcee'. In India we only have modern technology, but no modern thinking. Being divorced isn't bad, sometimes there's no other way out. Hopefully, someday we'll be more accepting...but until then I'm not going to be embarrassed --I'm proud of the life I've lived."

"I am 28 years old but when people look at me, they recoil in fear and disgust. They don't see me as a young man with hopes and dreams of making a living and having a family. I am just like everyone else but was dealt a terrible hand of fate. When I started working at the construction company as a labour manager in 2004, I thought my life was set. 
8 months into my job, I was overseeing the labour on the site when I felt dizzy and fell into an open pothole. The pothole had no water, nothing to soften the blow and the 14 foot fall has led to lifelong consequences. I was unconscious for 10 whole minutes and when I woke up, I was given some water and ointment and sent back to work. A few years later, I began to have nosebleeds. I was referred to a local hospital and they did a series of tests. For 10 months, they poked and prodded and I went on for surgery. After my first surgery, the doctor called me into his office. 
He had tears in his eyes as he said that they can not operate any further because I have intensive nerve damage in my brain as a result of my fall 7 years ago and I could lose my life. I can also lose my life without the surgeries. As I asked the doctor to help me the same way he would help his son, the doctor wiped away a tear, took my hands into his and told me all he can do is pray. I left, disappointed. 
Months later, I started noticing my skin rotting away. My eye would begin to blur at random moments and one day I woke up to find that I could no longer open it. I have lost my eyesight, my skull is eroding and I can no longer afford to visit a doctor, having spent all my savings on medical bills already. I have no family to help me financially or emotionally and I lost my job with my eyesight. The same employer under whose guidance this happened fired me and asked me to fend for myself. For four years, I have depended on the occasional odd jobs to earn a living. I now know that my one true pillar of strength is God. I don't know how I'm still alive, but I am. Every attempt I've made to gather funds has failed — I even wrote to our government asking for help but all my letters and requests went unanswered. 
At times, I have thought I should just die. But I want to live. I have hands and legs, I want to make the most of this life that has been given to me and I know that God is holding my hand every step of the way. He has brought me here for a reason and just as my luck would have it, people are now interested in at least understanding my story. I know that this is a sign for me to fight for survival and with all this support, I feel as though my life holds a sea of possibilities…I just need some help getting there."

-------------------------------------------------------
Nagendra Singh Tomar is a 28 year old young man struggling to stay alive.  He needs multiple surgeries which he cannot afford. We want to try and give this man another shot at a healthy life. Please consider donating :

https://www.ketto.org/makelovenotscars

"I earned my first salary when I was 10. At the age where I should have been eating chocolates, I was wrapping chocolates with my siblings to make a living. Even though I worked at the factory all day, I was determined to educate myself -- so after a 8 hour work shift, I would attend night school and do my homework until the early hours of the morning. As time went by and we had more expenses, I took on more odd jobs like handling a laundry, but I still went to night school and completed my SSC. The one thing that I carried with me through this time, was a smile. No matter how tired I got, I would remain positive about better things to come. 
After my SSC, I didn't have a job, but I had a passion for music. I would go on auditions hoping that someone liked my voice, but I never really got selected. After one audition, a man in the audience came upto me and said that my voice touched him -- he said he wanted to help me in whichever way he could. He recommended me for an airline job and after multiple interviews -- I was selected. I started off as a cleaner, and rose through the ranks to become a mechanic...and that career lasted 38 years! It was through this job that I was able to raise my family and educate my three daughters to the highest level. 
I believe that if you choose to be positive, the right opportunities will be presented to you at the perfect moment -- how else did a singing audition get me a job that lasted a lifetime? 
At 82, as I look back at my life I can tell you that those days of poverty taught me valuable lessons -- to place love and family over everything else, to accept but expect the best from life and most importantly to be content and co-operate with God's plans for you without worrying too much."

"I'm turning 80 soon and it's been a great life. Most of these 80 years have been spent with my fine wife by my side, and the only plan for the rest of our lives is to travel, see the world together and celebrate 'us' -- it's like being 18 again!"

We posted a photo today of a woman who faced domestic violence. A few hours after we put the post up, she received a call from his lawyer and in order to avoid any further hassle and not add to her troubles -- we've taken the post down.

"I first came to Bombay from Allahabad to visit my sister. I was in high school at the time, but the cost of my education was pinching my parents everyday to the point where we were compromising on food -- so I decided to get a job here. I also wanted to be close to my sister, who's the only real friend I've had growing up. I started driving this cab since 1990, and in all these years, I've grown to love the people of Bombay and all that they've given me over the years. 
To tell you a little bit more, my wife wasn't able to conceive for many years and just like you, I began to speak with a passenger about it. This girl tells me that her mama is a doctor and might be able to help me-- she took down my details, got in touch and long story short...after years of trying, my wife was able to conceive a baby boy thanks to that girl and her mama who cared to help. I don't think there has been a happier moment in my life and I made a promise to myself to be kinder in my own little way."
"Has there been an occasion where you have been kind?"
"I don't know if you will think this is big enough but a few months ago at around 1:30 in the morning, I stopped for two teenage boys who were very drunk. They got into my cab and in their drunken state began to talk in English about how they didn't have enough money to cover my cab fare. At that time, I thought of my own son, and how I would be worried sick if he was out on the street, drunk. I dropped these two boys right to their door step in Dharavi and when they got off and told me that they were 100 Rupees short, I told them it was ok and to not drink so much. I know 100 Rupees is not such a big amount, but I dropped them home only because I actually did care about their safety. Since then, I often drive around at night looking for people who may not have a way or money to get home and drop them to safety no matter how long it takes -- it's the least I can do, for a city that's given me so much."

"She's getting married soon, so the two of us are doing a little 'sister's trip' to Bombay and Goa -- just the both of us and everyday I've planned some kind of a surprise for her. I've known that she's getting married for a while but it didn't really sink in until a few weeks ago when we were at our cousin's wedding. One moment we were sitting there laughing, but the next moment it just kind of hit me that she's moving away and I broke down. I started crying and telling her, 'I don't know how I'll live without you' and she was confused about how I had a random outburst-- but that's how it is for a sister. We grow up together -- fighting, teasing each other and driving our parents crazy, but at the end of the day we can't live without one another.
And when it comes to her marriage, It's like a part of me is moving away...oh God, I'm getting emotional again-- let's just end it with I'm really going to miss her."

"I've been away from my village in Kolkata since over a decade. My sons are working here as drivers and I have a job as a security guard but my wife is back home in our village. I get to see her once every year, and I miss her terribly...but what can we do, expenses here are so high. Every night when I get home we talk for a few minutes, and those few minutes are the highlight of my day. 
When I go back to my village, I'm the happiest. She cooks everything I like, we visit the temple and spend all our time exchanging our stories from the year gone by."
"Which dish does she make the best?"
"All year round I eat food from here and there, but my heart is at peace only once I savour her hand cooked daal and rice. 
At 60, all I want is my wife by my side, her daal-rice to look forward to every night...and I will be known as the happiest man in all of Bombay."
"The baby's been kicking a bit extra today...I think my cutie already knows its Mother's Day!"

"What do you want to be when you grow up?"
"An Engineer, didi."
"Why an engineer?"
"Baba once told me that he wants bhaiya to become an engineer so that he can take care of us and make our dreams come true. The next day I asked my teacher if a girl can become an engineer and she said yes!...so I ran home that day and told baba that I will become an engineer, not just bhaiya and I will also make his dreams come true."
"What is the first thing you will buy for your baba?"
"Mangoes didi...baba and I share mango-malai whenever we can afford it and it's the sweetest taste in the world!"

"I remember an incident from my childhood which has always stayed with me. I was about 11 years old and my mother wanted me to go out and get some stamps for her. As usual, I was dilly-dallying and only went a couple of hours later. When I reached the post office, I realised that I'd lost the 5 Rupees that she'd given me. In those times 5 rupees was a large amount, and I was terrified of going back home — I began to cry outside the post office, when an elderly gentleman came and asked me what happened. As soon as I told him, he took out a 5 rupee note, and asked me to be more careful the next time around. It was then that I felt that guardian angels really do exist, and I decided to go out of my way to help someone in need."
"When was the last time you helped someone in that way?"
"A couple of weeks ago, I was dropping my mother-in-law to the gym, when I saw a woman stranded in the rain. She'd been waiting for a couple of minutes trying to hail a cab, but no one was ready to take her. I offered her a lift and told her it was no problem for me to drop her to her office, which was only a few minutes away from mine. Because of the rain and the traffic, we were together for about 45 minutes, at the end of which we knew all about each other's families and our interests. Before leaving, she gave me a card and I smiled, because I knew that I'd not only helped a stranger…but I'd made a new friend in the city."

This was such a cute moment...the Nanny was shy of being photographed but the grandparents insisted on her getting into the frame. When she finally agreed, Nana looks at me and says-
"Nanny has to be in the photo...Nana, Nani and Nanny all love baby very much!"

"I've been raised in a family of limited means since I was born. Education wasn't really possible because we had to make ends meet...so I started working from a really young age. My life had only struggle and poverty until I met my wife. She had the most selfless heart. Everything got better with her around and we had 3 beautiful children.
A few years ago, she was diagnosed with cancer. I didn't know what to do or where to go. I took loans, borrowed money from friends and family and tried to cure her....but nothing seemed to work. She kept telling me not to spend this money and keep it for our children, but I was desperate to save her life. 5 years ago, she passed away and everyday I feel her absence. I had to fill her shoes and become both a mother and a father for my children-- from cooking, to cleaning to earning. Eventually, it became harder for me to balance both, so with a heavy heart I had to send two of my children to live with my sister. I send them money every month and hope that they're studying hard with my sister. 
So that's my life today -- I'm a security guard who's earning 7000 Rupees a month, and trying to be both a mother and a father for his children. I really miss my wife and value how much she did around the house -- I now understand how difficult it is to run a home. All that said, I'm still happy everyday because I have three beautiful children and I want to see them get an education and succeed. That's my biggest dream."

We're happy to have told Team Nihal's story to the world last year. He stated three things which were on his bucket list...two of which he fulfilled - meeting Aamir Khan and seeing the Asimo Robot.    He passed away earlier this week, having just completed a successful campaign for Progeria Research and raised funds for the cause as well. 
We hope he Rests in Peace knowing that his life was valuable and his story is a source of inspiration to millions around the globe.
link_name: Photos from Humans of Bombay's post

status_message: "There have been times when people have gotten out of my cab, saying they'll be back with my money...but they just don't show up again. I don't understand it -- these people live in good buildings, can afford good phones and good clothes, but when they have to be stingy...they cheat people like me who can barely make ends meet. I don't understand it."

"I've been a Fakir for a good part of my life, and while traveling the country I've found God many times in my life. Not in a temple or a mosque, but almost everyday, in different roles. I've found God in the young girl who gave up her seat on the bus for an aging man. I've found him in a young boy who gave me a bottle of water when I'd been starving and dehydrated for two days, even though I never asked him for it. I've found him in the random acts of kindness all around me, no matter where I go. Isn't it funny, just today I was thinking about what kind of legacy I would leave behind in this world and I found you...a medium to tell people what I've learnt in all these years."
"What is that?"
"Just think about how different your world would be, if you saw God in every human that's ever been kind to another being...would you ever do anything to hurt that God? The answer to that question is the answer to peace, in all it's simplicity."

"I was a copywriter before I decided to quit and focus my energy on the one thing I felt passionately about -- creating expressive jewellery. I've always loved accessories and that's where my heart has always been, so I decided there was no better time than now to give my passion a go. All my emotions are channelized through my jewellery and the material I use is very rich in culture so each piece tells a story...just like the neck piece I'm wearing right now. 
A lot of people will say that leaving a stable, well paying job is crazy, but I don't think those people know what it means to create something and see it come to life. 
I've finally found my calling...and it's too precious for me to give it up for any amount of money."
When roles reverse in the sweetest way possible-- an image of one of our buyers reading the Humans of Bombay Book to her grandmother :)

"Life was really difficult for me until a few years ago because I had to pay off the loan my father took to make this shop. I was in so much stress, because I couldn't make ends meet, let alone being able to buy my wife a sari or afford a decent education for my children. 
My father and I have run this shop for years, so we've had loyal customers for decades. About 15 years ago, a few of them came together and told me that they were going to sponsor my children's education entirely. Not just that, they gave me school supplies so that I didn't have to worry about that either. I have no words to tell you how that felt-- God comes in many forms and for me, they represented God in all ways. Today, I've paid off my loan entirely, my children are in college and I'm able to afford a good life. In fact, I just bought my wife a new sari yesterday...honestly, I'm feeling like the happiest man in the world right now!"

"My family has been selling mangoes for generations now. We make some money, but it's not a lot. What can I also do...now a days the competition has become crazy...imagine I woke up one day and realised that my latest competitor is Katrina Kaif!"

"I've tried to quit smoking for over 30 years but I've failed a million times. If I count the amount I've spent on bidis and cigarettes, for a man like me, it's a fortune. There was a time, where I didn't buy my wife food but spent the little money I had on cigarettes because it's that big of an addiction in my life. I've tried everything, but I feel anxious, I feel incomplete without smoking. Believe me, this is the biggest reason my family and I aren't on good terms -- it has made me lose so many people in my life."
"What advice would you want to give people?"
"Forget people, I want to give some advice to these cigarette companies. These boxes come with a disclaimer that 'Cigarette smoking can kill you' -- they should alter that statement and add-  'Cigarette smoking can kill dreams, it can kill hope and it can destroy your family.'
To everyone else I would say it starts with one drag, goes onto two and eventually it controls your entire life...don't try it, don't give in."

In the summer of May 2004 I was a 16 year old girl with big dreams and hope for my future. I didn't even know then that the demon that would destroy my life would be my next door neighbour, a man nine years older than me. It began with casual catcalling every now and then, which I tried my best to ignore. That summer when the catcalling took a new turn in the form him of him hurling obscenities at me, I finally mustered up the courage to tell my parents. On finding out, they were enraged and decided to talk to the boy's parents. The boys parents were understanding and made it a point to give their son a piece of their mind. Things went back to normal from that day, he stayed out of my way and I thought he had learnt his lesson. Little did I realize that he had been harbouring such immense hate for me, that 4 years later in  2008, he caught m off guard and attacked me with acid. He didn't even wait for justice to prevail... right after attacking me, he ingested poison and killed himself. I never even got the closure of justice and he got the escape of a quick death. Its very easy to press the quit button on life and get rid of all of your problems, he was a coward when he attacked me with acid and he died a coward. The hard part is surviving, which is what I am doing. 
 I felt like my life had ended and it did for 6 years, but little did I know that this experience would lead me to understand what true love is. I met an amazing man who was willing to look past all my external appearances and made me feel something I hadn't felt in a long time…he made me feel beautiful. We got married a few years ago and I felt like I had been reborn. I even managed to get a job at the hospital and that has given me the chance to move forward in life and be a part of society. I've been happily married for almost two years now and I"m excited to grow my family. 
The way I look at it, I can either cry over what happened for the rest of my life, or be thankful for everything - a job, a family and a person who redefined a 'soulmate' for someone like me. Everyday, I choose the latter…everyday I choose to feel beautiful."

"After I gave birth to my daughter, my husband started having an extra marital affair. I loved him very much, so I tried to bring him back to me but he began to treat me really badly -- he wouldn't even look at me. When I confronted him about this other woman he said, 'it happens in every family-- at least I'm giving you a place to stay, so you shouldn't complain.' He didn't give me any money for anything, so I began to do odd jobs in my village to make sure that my daughter and I could at least survive.
One evening she fell really sick and I begged him to give me some money to treat her, but he refused. I was so ashamed to ask my parents for money, but I had no other choice. That day however, I made a choice that I would never feel that helpless again. I left my daughter with my parents, left my husband and came to Bombay to find some work. I've been working as domestic help for a few years now, and I've been able to educate my daughter as well as pay for the expenses of my parents. Every month, I save a little money so that I can build a better house for all of us in my village and little by little that dream is coming true as well. 
My happiest moments are when I go back to my village and my family looks at me with pride in their eyes.
