I stayed at CST the whole night with one other police officer.
I never did what I did for any award or recognition, but I did receive 28 awards since then and a promise that I would get a job in the railway…a promise which is still not fulfilled 7 years on. If it was the son of a minister or politician who had done the same thing, God knows how much they would have done for him, but at the end of it I'm a poor chaiwallah and I have no regrets...I would do it all over again. 
#superhumansofBombay #HOBheroes #wewillneverforget

"I was in my Taj hotel room that night, when I thought people were bursting crackers to celebrate India winning a cricket match. It was only an hour later that I realised that the Taj was under attack. When they lit a part of the hotel on fire, I could feel the heat and the discomfort after some time because I was staying on the 6th floor. We didn't have any cable connection, or any proper information so at around 4:00 in the morning I decided to make a run for it, because I thought the fire would engulf me anyway. I didn't encounter anyone on the way out of the fire escape route - I just saw a lot smoke and chaos as I kept running down. 
When I walked out of there alive, it put a lot of things in perspective for me. It made me believe that we're all a speck in the universe, and the things like position, power, fame and money that we strive for our entire lives - mean so little.  It humbled me because when you're in something like this you realize that it doesn't matter who you are, where you come from, what position you hold or how much money you have — no matter what you do, you cannot buy yourself a life. In there, it was only about all of humanity fighting against the inhuman."

"I was a chef in the Taj banquet kitchen when the gunshots started that night. Initially the news was that it was an internal gang war in a neighbourhood nearby and that it would die down soon. It was only at about 10:30 - 11PM that we understood the magnitude of what was going on. We were 7 chefs in total in the kitchen that night, not one of whom left the Taj despite knowing all exit points. By then the shootout had happened at the Wasabi restaurant and all those who had survived were pouring into the banquet hall and kitchen where we were working. As soon as we had heard about the shootout, we prepared sandwiches for our surviving guests which we then handed out. After this, we entered the corridor to escort our guests out of the hotel through the back entrance. We had successfully helped a few guests when I saw the left profile of a terrorist in a red cap, who began shooting.
I was standing next to a refrigerator, when my head chef and sous chef both got shot. There was chaos, panic and fear as our guests started running everywhere - but by then they had opened fire in all directions. I remember running towards the kitchen and looking around to see that no one else had made it. All of a sudden, everything went quiet and that silence was the worst. I tried looking around for survivors, but it was just me. I stayed there for a few hours, until I realised that no help was coming anytime soon. I walked out of the kitchen and saw all of my colleagues dead on the floor - the whole Taj was deserted. I looked at the refrigerator where I'd been only a while ago and it had 3 bullet holes in it - I'd narrowly escaped death, but it was horrifying to see that my guests and colleagues hadn't been as lucky. I won't look back on that day as just a terrorist attack, but a day when many brave individuals looked death in the eye to help others."
#superhumansofBombay #HOBheroes #wewillneverforget

"I've never gotten along with my father. At the age of 20 I moved out of my house and supported myself by working at a call centre and being a fitness consultant on the side. I went ahead with this despite knowing that I had a kidney ailment since the age of 17 - and because I was supporting myself, I couldn't always afford all my medication. Also, it's important to mention that I've never smoked a cigarette in my life, or drank a sip of alcohol, so really... it could happen to anyone. This went on for 10 years, until I got malaria and my body started giving up. The doctors told me to give up sport, but that's all I knew - I had played hockey at the state level and I wasn't going to let it stop me now.
But by then, my system got so weak that my doctor asked me to go in for a Dialysis and I just wasn't ready for that. Finally, they decided to contact my parents and despite not having spoken to my father for over a decade - he agreed to give me his kidney in a heartbeat. Love really is a powerful emotion, where he so willingly decided to give me a part of his body and save my life. So, it's been 4 years since that transplant and despite having to take 24 pills a day, everyday - I'm still doing what I love. I play sport, I'm a fitness consultant and have won the All India Transplant Games 3 years in a row since then."

"I had recently given my 12th grade exams, when I came home one day and felt tremendous pain in my thigh, followed by a high fever. When I visited my family doctor, they asked us to get a sonography done and that's when we realised I had a 4kg tumour inside my body that didn't show even a little bit from the outside. I went into surgery the next day and I remember my doctor pacing up and down the room trying to break it to me that I had 3rd stage cancer, but by then I had already figured it out. I made it easier for her by asking the question, 'will I lose my hair?' At that point, when my parents asked the doctor for my chances of survival, I was at 0%.
The thing is, from the very beginning I didn't allow cancer to get the better of me - if anything, cancer was always playing a losing game with me. Since the time I was diagnosed with a 0% survival chance, I had made up my mind that I would defeat it. I did lose my hair, so I called a barber home, shaved it all off and proceeded to mock myself in front of others as 'egghead' - I never allowed cancer to make me a victim. I've always called myself a 'shameless cancer patient' because I would just laugh things off and embrace them as an experience - but I think that's the only thing that got me out of it. 
Infact, cancer made me realise how lucky I am to have gotten a 2nd life and pushed me to pursue everything I'm passionate about. I studied clinical psychology because I wanted to help others, especially teens who had cancer to deal with it. But the biggest thing cancer has done for me is to get me into music - I began singing to emote better - and I'm the lead singer of my own band!
So what can I say - I went through 3 chemo sessions, 8 surgeries and a million complications at the age of 17 -- but I won the battle, only because I was shameless enough to laugh at it rather than giving it the power to be life threatening."

"We were in the same batch and class in medical college. Back then, we had these study groups, so 6-7 of us would be studying together but eventually the two of us branched off and began studying by ourselves, and meeting alone. I don't know when it happened exactly, but through the process we fell in love and got married. 
We were in America for a few years after, then London...but eventually we came back home to Bombay. We led very simple lives the two of us, but he was always doing things to make me happy. I remember I used to complain to him saying that 'we have a love story, but you've never taken me to the Taj Mahal." So on my 60th birthday, he planned a surprise, got me onto a plane and took me to the Taj. He made sure that we were staying in a room where as soon as I opened my eyes, I had the Taj Mahal in front of me and that was so special, because I always thought these romantic gestures were for youngsters...but love just grows.
He was diagnosed with cancer a few years ago, but he never wanted to make any bones about it. He would go in for chemo and go back to work. We tried to make the most of those last 2 years - we would grab lunches in the middle of work, come home early to spend time together, travel to America and other parts of the world - but the special one was this short 5 day trip to Goa. 
Even though he would tire very easily on that trip, we've gone for long walks on the beach, eaten amazing food, enjoyed the couple Spa and even gambled. We loved each other, really I wouldn't have ever lived my life differently.
He passed away a few months after. We led a really simple life together, but I loved it like that. We didn't have any fancy dinner dates or dine at 5 stars, but it was still beautiful. You know I read somewhere that you have 7 lives and Karma defines how your every life will be - so I must have done something amazing, because this was my perfect life with him."

"We grew up in a joint family of about 30 people. My father used to earn 35 rupees a month back then, so money was tightl. I knew since a young age that I would have to work very hard to make something off myself. I would study for hours on end to get myself a scholarship - which I did. I didn't choose to become an architect - I took the first college that offered me a scholarship. The field didn't matter, my next goal was to study as much as I could about architecture and build a career that couldn't be challenged and at 68, I can say that I'm established only because I had that hunger. 
And I found someone to share that passion with - my wife is a doctor and for the most of our lives we've worked 12-13 hours a day to give our children the life we'd once dreamt of. Every love story doesn't have to be a fairytale - for me the special part of our marriage is that we both worked so hard to build a life together, to give our children the things we couldn't afford in our childhood and to bring them up well. Today they're both at high posts at their respective jobs and it's only because they understand the value of being self made. Just this year we took a trip to Germany, and I remember looking out of the plane, thinking that the young boy in me who always dreamed of travelling, was finally happy."

"We're both good at Math and we love football - so we were trying to combine our theories about certain angles with what our football coach taught us."
"How did that work out?"
"It worked...we both scored!"

"I couldn't conceive for a very long time, even though I was going through extensive treatments. Finally years later, something in my treatment ticked and I was pregnant. You know how it is with Indian families - everyone begins to guess the gender of the child before it's even born, but I never took part in that - I was only concerned with the health of my baby.
When I delivered, everyone was excited to know the sex of the baby and my whole family was really happy to know that it was a baby girl. I remember hearing, 'oh my god, it's a girl!' and I just kept thinking, 'oh my god, it's a healthy child.' I thanked God with all my heart for blessing me with Motherhood that day and everyday of my life. She's 22 years today, and still the best thing that ever happened to me."

"At 64, I have only one piece of advice to give - the most amount of happiness is found in the simple things, not in the luxurious ones."
"When was the last time you were that happy?"
"Right now...work's done and my wife is waiting at home for me with some hot tea, our front porch and a beautiful sunset - what more can I ask for?"

"My cart has been taken away by the BMC on several occasions - but they've been very sympathetic most of the time. These workers have a certain guideline to follow, but that doesn't mean they're bad people. On one such occasion when my cart was taken away, I pleaded with the BMC official to let me go. I told him that if he took my cart away I would have to spend all day trying to get it back and as a result wouldn't be able to pick up my children from school, and without a second thought he let me go."

"It's time for my evening Namaz, so I won't be able to talk too much."
"Is there anything in particular you pray for?"
"Nothing in particular...just peace for everybody."

"I wasn't able to complete my education, so I had to resort to becoming an electrician. It's sad because I can build products, I understand machines and I want to make my own device someday - but I don't have that certificate that gives me the qualification to do so. So many people complain about engineering, but it's my dream to be called an engineer - I'm sick and tired of being called a technician. I live in the hope that success isn't only determined by marks and diplomas - but on a passion as strong as mine."

"I'm fighting the same case since the past 20 years and it still hasn't concluded. It's a case of remarriage and custody of a young girl. At the time the case came to me, the little girl in question was 7 years old, but today she's 27 and it still goes on. I'm not saying our Indian System is bad, I'm just saying it's slow. Think about it, if they took 4 years to hang Kasab, even though there was so much evidence...what will happen to the low profile cases? How many years will those take?"

"My husband and I had the best time after he retired. We would never be idle - we used to paint together, spend hours cleaning and redecorating the house, watch the 6 o' clock mass together on TV and cook our meals together. But his favourite thing to do was to go for long walks in the evening, where he would hold my hand during every crossing and only let go once we reached the other side! 
He passed away peacefully in his sleep 12 years ago, but I still want more time with him. I try and keep myself busy by going to my daughter's house for lunch and dinner and going to mass whenever I can, but it isn't quite the same without him. 
At 89, I can say I've lived a great life and nothing really scares me...except one thing which I would have never admitted to him then, but I'm terrified of crossing the road by myself and I still can't do it without him."

"I was a pilot in the Indian Air Force, during the 1965 War against Pakistan and 1971 Bangladesh Liberation. I knew I wanted to be a pilot and serve the country since the age of 5, so I worked towards it and found myself a place in the IAF without an army background. During the 1965 war, we were a group of 6 army men stuck in a near death situation, and one small manoeuvre saved our lives — but we weren't happy to be alive, we wanted to press on to win the war for our country. For us, the country has always come first, but these bureaucrats and government officials have made it all a money game. Just recently, I met a man who was the Army General during our time and because he wasn't given any pensions on time - he had been reduced to begging. India is the only country who treats its Armed Forces and War Veterans so shabbily - it's shameful, utterly shameful. When Prince Charles came to India, before first visiting the Raj Bhavan, he went to the cemetery to pay respects to those who had lost their lives during war — and that's the kind of respect they deserve. The air you're breathing today, doesn't belong to you; it belongs to those who have given up their limbs, their families and their lives for your freedom.
And still, we fight with our brothers because of religion, but to tell you the truth, all these divides are created between us by the bureaucracy. I started the Institute of Aviation and fought with the chancellor who insisted on having the 'religion' column on application forms. I fought against it and made sure that there was only one question asked - Indian or Non-Indian, and that's how it should be. I've fought wars with my Muslim brothers side by side, and never once questioned differences in our religion, because we're Indian first. It's your country before religion, it's your Nation before the bribes and it's your duty to raise your voice when they're wronging our people."
"My husband said I should lose weight, so I've come to the park to prove a point. Basically instead of sitting at home, I'm sitting here and getting some fresh air -- it's nice."

"I'm on school break for a week, so I decided to make these and get them to the bazaar to try and sell. My father sells vegetables here, so it was easy for me to set up this small space...I've sold more than 100 today already!"
"What do you plan on doing with the money?"
"I want to become a scientist, but Baba tells me it's very expensive for our family to afford, so every break I try and sell different things that I make to add to my Education Fund. We call it 'Science Master."

"Hey, how's it going?"
"Hi! It honestly could have been better."
"What's wrong?"
"We're really scared. Imagine if someone put you inside a drum and kept beating at it...that's how loud we hear the crackers on Diwali, and it really frightens us."
"That's terrible. What advice would you give people during this time?"
"We love you Humans the most in the world, and as much as we take care of you, we need you to take care of us too...please try and have a noise free Diwali."

"I've been making and selling diyas for 40 years now, but even at 73 I love working during this time, because it gives me happiness to know that my diyas are lighting the home of someone's family. I wrap up quickly though, because my grand children wait for me at home to make rangoli with them and feed them sheera. Work comes later...family always comes first!"
"When boys try to make fun of us by pulling our hair or teasing us - we challenge them to a game of football…and beat them!"

"Everyone struggles for things in life - for me it might be to pay for my child's education, for you it may be buying a new car...but the struggle is always there. At the end of it, did that car give you as much happiness as the anxiety caused by struggle? At 60, the only advice I can give is to not place too much importance on 'things', but happiness. Now that I look back, I wish I had spent more time at home with my children, rather than working round the clock to buy them materialistic things... and that's a regret you just don't want to have."

"People have the wrong notion about arranged marriages. Many years ago, I had an arranged marriage too, but I feel like it's been full of love, romance and butterflies. Infact, I just came back to Bombay a few days ago, and my husband surprised me with tickets to Australia — and that feeling was amazing - I felt like a teenager all over again! So you can say that I'm going on a mini honeymoon with my lovely 'arranged' partner."

"When I found him, he was begging for money to support his family, but instead of giving him money which would last him a few days, I decided to offer him a job as my assistant. Ofcourse he was and still is underage, but he has a lot more dignity doing this than just asking around for money. In the end, it worked out well for both of us - I needed the help and he needed to support his family, both of which have now been accomplished."

"We studied together in school in Assam and even though I'm her junior we were always very close. We both moved to Delhi for graduation and she would always look out for me even then. Finally after 4 years she left me and decided to move to Bombay because of the guy she was dating back then!"
"And then?"
"And then he broke up with her and she realised that she should have never left me in the first place! Funnily enough, I'm meeting her today after 4 years -- we've done long distance better than her relationship with her boyfriend in the same city. That's the best part about our friendship - through all the boyfriends, heartbreaks and other drama - she's been my constant, my one phone call away - my number one."

"I knew his friends because they were my seniors while I studied in Xaviers. He was heavily involved in cricket at the time, so I hadn't really seen him around - but coincidentally the day his match was washed out, was the day he decided to come for Malhar to meet his friends. I saw him the first day and wondered who the 'new guy' was and when I looked around for him on the 2nd day of Malhar…I couldn't locate him. As luck would have it, his best friend who was my group leader asked me to go out to the gate and hand an entrance pass to his friend…I remember seeing him standing in line, smiled and introduced myself…and that's how we first met. At the time I was only 17, but we ended up dating for seven and a half years after, most of which was long distance. Somehow though, I feel the long distance helped us…because we weren't constantly breathing down each other's neck and the space helped us understand that we wanted to be together."
"What's your fondest memory with him?"
"It wasn't exactly with him, but it's of this one time when he was in Rajkot for a cricket tournament and I couldn't get through to him because of network issues. At that point there were no cellphones, so when I finally got through the landline, someone else picked up and said that he wasn't around. I asked him to look for him because I urgently needed to give him a message, so he said that he would take the message for me. In my frantic state, I said 'who are you?', 'I don't even know you' and he said - 'I'm the umpire for the game he's going to play today' and I decided to give him my message. When he walked onto the field for his game the umpire called him out. He obviously thought there was something wrong - but he just told him…'your girlfriend is really missing you and she wishes you luck.' He thought I was crazy…but he won that match and I think it had a little bit to do with me!"

"A year ago, I met someone who was deaf and realised that it's so difficult for them to convey messages and communicate. I decided to start conducting surveys to locate deaf children and work with them -- I really had no plan, just the desire to help. I learnt sign language and got a group of volunteers to visit these people on weekends and help them communicate better. 
We're not an NGO but we just try to make them feel like they have friends, are a part of society and are valuable. So now, I speak to them in broken sign language and some of them who we've taught to lip read, speak in broken words...but broken as it is, it's beautiful beyond understanding."

"As I've become older, I've taken a fond liking to simplicity. The kind of things I do, or need have evolved over time so I don't think I necessarily even have a dream - I just love everything that's happening around me and I get inspired from little things that make me think. Scientifically, everything is symbolic of everything else whether it's an atom, the universe, love or a relationship. When you understand the principal of balance - where things happen around you or to you to balance the energy in the world - your life will become a lot simpler and clearer."
"When was the last time you achieved that balance?"
"When I started to run and gave up smoking. I think I smoked my first cigarette when I was 29 waiting on the sets of a television show for no reason in particular. After that, while I was waiting around on set - I would be smoking 5 cigarettes at a time and 30 in a day. That's what went on for the next few years of my life. I think when something is so acceptable, accessible and addictive - it's the toughest to escape it. 
Know that no one starts smoking for comfort…that's what it does to you only once you're addicted. I tried and failed to give up my addiction for a few years, until I really put my mind to it and that only happened when I decided to start running, I could feel it in my lungs and body that I was unfit and unhealthy. Having been naturally inclined to sports since a young age, I felt terrible about myself and that's how I was able to release the habit for good over 6 months and now I can't even passive smoke. So I guess from being a chain smoker to winning the title of Iron Man…balance was restored."

"I probably didn't realize the impact Sana had on my life while she was alive, I knew I always had a thing for her but I didn't see her leaving a mark on me the way she has today. Sana passed away earlier this month. My friends called me over under the pretext of hanging out, they sat me down, gave me a glass of wine and broke the news to me. I remember thinking to myself that this had to be some sort of sick joke. For the first half an hour, I didn't even believe them. I kept waiting for someone to tell me it was a joke. 
I don't think I'll ever get over this but I'm coming to terms with the fact that its alright to not. I just desperately want to find some closure though. I think that's why I got her face tattooed on me because I thought it would bring me some closure but in reality it did more for me.
When I look down at her smiling face, I know that's how I'm always going to remember her and that she'll always be there for me. The impact that this girl has on me will always be something I can't put into words what I do know is that, even in death she has inspired me to be a more honest person. When she was still here and I refused to hold her hand or kiss her in public fearing stigma, she always called me fake. She said I wasn't being true to myself and if that's taught me anything, it's to always be true to yourself. I realized I wasn't hiding something minor; I was hiding who I actually was. If she was still here and I know I would have paraded her around with pride. Its sad that it took losing her to realize that I was going through life being someone I wasn't.  
Sana was one of the strongest people I have had the privilege of knowing, I know that people call other people strong all the time but as unconventional as she was, so was her strength. When people have the ability to feel everything so deeply, they often to choose to run away from it but not Sana, She was unapologetic, true and honest. 
So, here's to Sana and living each day as my last with absolute honesty and not apologizing for who I am."
"These young boys tried to fool me with a prank so I just chased them down the road with a sugarcane. Sometimes I really wonder how such small boys with such small legs can run so fast!"

"I had to start working for the first time in my life at the age of 42 after my husband passed away. I learnt everything there is to learn about about the stock market so that I could fend for my mother in law and 3 children. Even though I was devastated, I had to hold it together for my family and take control of my life. That's the thing about being placed in difficult situations - you find the strength you never knew you had and more courage than you've ever had before. You unknowingly end up becoming the superhero of your own life story...and this is true for anyone who's ever been thrown into a difficult life experience."

"If you could give one piece of advice to people, what would it be?"
"Don't listen to the advice of random people."

"His family and my family have lived in the same building for years but since his business was in Bombay and Dubai, I barely saw him. This one day, he asked my driver which college I was studying in, he came there, waited for me to finish class and asked me to coffee. We ended up chatting for an hour that day and I was completely enamoured by him — he was such a charmer! His parents wanted us to marry quickly because he was 7 years older - so at 19 I got married to someone who I thought was the man of my dreams…but he was an asshole. 
It started at the honeymoon, where I wasn't allowed to look anywhere but towards him, wasn't allowed to enter shops which he didn't like and was supposed to wear only what he wanted me to. We were to visit our relatives in London, so he asked me to wear a salwaar but no jacket…and I remember freezing. When we went back to Dubai, he didn't allow me to turn on the AC and if I did in the middle of the night because it was so hot - he would smash my perfumes, candles and upturn my entire wardrobe. He would drive his convertible car at the maximum speed and threaten to throw me out if I ever disobeyed him. Once, in between abusing and screaming at me, he pinned me down, forced himself upon me and 6 months into my wedding I was pregnant. He hid my medicines saying I don't need them — I was throwing up 30 times a day and all the minerals in my body had drained to the point that I couldn't stand and that's when he agreed to take me to the hospital. The nurse there saw me once and said 'I've to take you to the emergency room - and had you come a day later you would return to Bombay in a coffin'. When I went home after those 3 days, he pushed me, I started bleeding and he waited 24 hours to take me back to the hospital. On the hospital slip it said 'bled yesterday and brought to the hospital today.'
He only let me return home because my parents were at Hajj. When I came home, I asked him if I could stay for a night in my own home instead of his - which he flatly refused. I was talking to my mother on the phone for 15 minutes when he called me 40 times, sent his sister upstairs to snatch my phone and sent me a text saying,'If you return to Dubai, I will rip your ass apart' in Hindi. That's when I decided I had enough.
The next 6 years were hell for me. He sent me a legal notice saying he wanted custody of my unborn child, but I would never let that happen. So 30 days after I had delivered and my stitches hadn't healed - I went to the family court to fight for my son. My son has been to more courtrooms in the first 5 years of his life than most people ever would. He bribed people from the court and the judges to prolong this case and if not for this one police man who understood me and helped me - God knows how much longer I would have to continue my fight. In 2012, my hell was finally over. I won all cases because of that one hospital slip and received nothing in compensation from him or his family. He seemed so normal, but he snatched my innocence away. Please, don't rush into marriage because so often what people appear to be and who they are, is entirely different. 10 years later, I've put it behind me because I have my son and my life is for him. He's all that matters."

"Whenever underage looking children come to buy cigarettes, I ask them for their ID. I don't understand English, but if they give it they must be of age...otherwise these other young ones either run away or ask for chewing gum instead. Even though I don't make a sale, that's what makes me happy."

"My wife left me a few years ago, accusing me of beating her. She was part of this 'Mahila Mandal' which would make sure that whenever she went to file a complaint, the police would lock me in for the night, without any proof and beat me. 
Truth is, I've never raised a hand on her - she was educated, but I'm an uneducated man making paintings and earning enough to live happily…but not luxuriously. Finally, we separated 10 years ago. I raised 2 of our sons, while she didn't even come for any of their weddings. I just want to say that while some men do rape, beat and abuse women - not all men are the same and if an accusation is made - atleast wait to hear the truth before beating him and throwing him out of society."

"We met at church about 23 years ago when my daughter and I spotted her with her son. She was dressed very stylishly with one single long earring and I remember thinking, 'I'll be caught dead wearing such a hideous earring'. Somehow my daughter realised she knew her son and that's how the two of us started talking and since then we're like 2 little school girls! Till date whenever she's angry with me she won't talk to me and otherwise…she calls me 10 times a day!' But mostly, we're still doing fun things - I love riding my bike so you might often find us zooming around Tardeo, in the middle of the night eating bun maska."
"What's been that special memory of your friendship?"
"A few years ago, I was having surgery on my leg when she came to the hospital with me…she even tried entering the operation theatre but the doctor obviously shooed her away. She was there through the night and after I was discharged, she took me straight to her home saying, 'I know if you go to your own house, you won't rest'. She'd made the best food for me and treated me with so much care. I hadn't showered in a few days so I casually just mentioned that I wish I could just have a nice clean scrub - and she went about looking for a giant plastic bag, covered my leg and helped me bathe. I think it's very very rare to find someone who will do these things for you. It's made me realise that the best relationships in life don't have labels and that friendship sometimes goes a far way into becoming your family."

"I was fresh out of college in Bombay, when I was trying to write a play for the celebration of 2500 years of Cyrus the Great. My script wasn't good enough - but that's how I met the actor of the play. Although the sparks flew since the time I met him, he was Catholic and I was Parsi so I knew it could never happen. My parents were very open minded but our extended family was completely against it. It was such a tough space to be in because on one end was the man I knew I couldn't live without and on the other end was my family who I couldn't hurt. If there was hell on earth — I've been through it because of that period. 
Finally, one day when I was staying at my friend's house my husband and I decided to get married in court. My family didn't attend the wedding, but I didn't know what else to do…I could not live without him. For a few years after that I couldn't go home and see my family. When I had a miscarriage, the matron at the hospital called my mother when I was unconscious and said that I was constantly asking for her — and when I woke up she was by my side. I can't tell you what that felt like - to have both my husband and mother together by my side.
So what can I tell you about love? It's this extremely complex thing where sometimes you're on top of the world but at other times you're down and out. I've known only one truth and that's what I've stood by all my life - that my life would be utterly meaningless without him and everything - the pain, the suffering has been worth it for that."

"During our third year in college, as a part of a project we began to research visual impairment and devices to help the impaired. What we realised is that there are 40 million impaired people in the world...of which 15 million live in India.
Technology to bring the digital world to them is so expensive that Indian's can't afford it. We've been working on this keyboard, which can be connected to any device like a computer, phone or iPad where visually impaired people can type, read emails...the way we do - for 1/10th the cost. 
So we hope that what started off as a college project can change the lives of 15 million Indians...with new employment opportunities and giving them the chance to prove themselves as 'specially abled' not disabled."

"I dedicated my whole life to the game of Hockey. Although I never played for India, since the age of 18 I've played hockey or coached boys to play the game. It's a shame that it's the National Sport of India but it's slowly dying. I blame a number of things for this - the education system which makes it impossible for young boys to dedicate any time to the sport, the lack of government support, the lack of Industrialists' interest and no celebrity face. I mean there are a hundred different leagues for cricket and now even football (which by the way, we've never qualified for), but who cares about Hockey? 
Some of my boys have played for India, but their victories are made to look minuscule by the media, because if it isn't cricket in this country…it's nothing. If the media even gave half as much importance to my boys as they do to the boys of cricket - thousands of others will be inspired to play the sport. I'm 65, I remained a bachelor all my life dedicated to the sport and I'm not going to let it die…my boys are living my dream of playing in the Indian Team and I just want them to get their due."

"They're very naughty so whenever they get into trouble (which is often), my mother starts shouting at them and I always have to intervene. I tell her, 'I'll speak to them', but if I try to get strict with them they start laughing! It's tough being the oldest one — I always end up being the mediator!"

"15 years ago, I used to come here for a walk when I saw an elderly gentleman teaching a group of 5 children. I was working with Reserve Bank at that point, and my mind raced to my own childhood, when because of my dad losing a lot of money in the share market we had very difficult times. When I was 6 years old, my aunt had come to visit us and she'd gotten a box of crackers for me to light…at that point we didn't have proper food or money for my books and I remember my mother saying, 'I wish she had given us a book or a meal instead.' Because of those difficulties, I wasn't able to finish my education and I wanted to help children who couldn't afford similar things. 
After a while, I realised that the gentleman had stopped coming to conduct these classes - so I decided to carry it on for him. I started with 5 children, on this street and today we have 230 with multiple volunteers. They come here to study English and Math and believe it or not, every single day they have something to eat - not because I give it to them but because people from all over the city come here with bananas, chocolates, sweets, dal and rice to ensure that these children have something to eat while they learn. Humanity isn't dead - it's alive right here…not making too much of a fuss but silently working its magic."

"I realised I'm gay when it hit me that love and attraction for me was only towards men. I thought I was the only kind, so I lived a fractional life in disguise, filled with tears and fear of rejection. Over time, I grew to realise that there were millions like me and I wasn't in it alone. At the age of 21, I told my parents. I said, 'I have a truth to tell you about myself and I have faith that this won't change anything about us. I'm still going to be your son and my love will still be the same, I hope you understand'…and they did.
I know that everyone has different opinions and some are intolerant towards it, but I feel like we just need to be more accepting of people's personal choices…we're all human afterall. Thankfully for me, I've come across people who have made me feel more comfortable in my own skin. When I just moved to Bombay, my neighbours figured it out and told, 'you're like our son and you're defined by your name and how you are to people. Who you choose to love is totally your decision' and that kindness has stayed with me for a long time. The world needs more of that."

"He doesn't have parents so he stays with us now. He's going to start school next year and his grandfather and I are very excited - we've collected money over the years for him and even though we don't make much - from what we've saved we can afford his school fees. I'll miss him accompanying me here in the morning when he goes to school...but I've always wanted to see him in a uniform and shiny new shoes, ready to make his dreams come true."

"I gave up my job to kick start a project that I feel passionately about. Infact, I invested all my money, sold my car and took a loan to make it happen...but I still feel so happy."
"What's the project about?"
"I make little waste bins for cars and other vehicles to try and support the Clean India drive. Because spitting and throwing shit out of cars is second nature to Indians, these bins even have little disposable pouches where you can spit. The idea is simple really - over 40% of pollution can be reduced using the product but when I approached civic authorities and these popular cab companies they thought it was a 'great concept' but obviously wouldn't bring the big bucks to the table...so they didn't want to pursue it. It's fine...I'm doing it on my own and even though we've only sold 80 such bins, I feel it's a start to clean my country. 
Patriotism in our country is limited to national holidays, watching a game of cricket from start to finish or occasionally tweeting about politics...but it's really the small active steps that make a difference. Remember that the next time you roll down your window, thinking 'what difference does this small wrapper make?"

"We met decades ago at the Law College Library in Bombay. He asked me which section a particular book was, as an excuse to talk and we never looked back. We went around for around 7 years before marriage, which was quite a scandal back then...but oh my, what a thrill it was.
I think the fondest memory I have of us together is that of our 43rd wedding anniversary which we celebrated in France...he took me to the Moulin Rouge and a walk under the starry sky after - I felt like I was in a fairytale at my old age. Unfortunately he passed away a few years later, and I don't think I've still fully coped with it. 
Couples are age pride themselves on completing the 'Golden Jubilee' of 50 married years together. We never completed 50 years of marriage, but a few days ago I thought about it and realised that since I met him, I knew I would be with him...so if you count our dating period, we comfortably crossed 50! So now I proudly say...we've had a beautiful Golden period together!"

"During the final leg of my MBA my father was detected with lung cancer and succumbed to it a few months after. It was a trying time, because I was at the brink of my career but felt a deep sense of loss at the same time. Instead of crying, I decided to channel all my energy towards my career and bringing happiness to his soul, by fulfilling his last wish -he always wanted to see my brother, in a suit working at a big hotel, abroad. It was my only goal - to put my younger brother through grad school and make both their dreams come true."
"Where's he now?
"Working in Dubai, at one of the biggest hotels there...and I've never been prouder of him."

"I returned to Bombay from New York in the year 2000, thinking that I'd stay for a year at most…but I ended up staying all these years and I have no idea why. I guess it was a combination of things, the biggest being the opportunity to reinvent myself many times over - from consulting, running a not for profit initiative for an Integrated Transport Policy in public transportation to initiating an acting career in both film and the stage…it's been beautifully chaotic - the kind of chaotic I love. Little things  like the smile of the flower girl at a traffic signal or appreciation for something like my performance in the Vagina Monologues, make me believe that I did the right thing by returning."
 "Is there an experience in particular that touched you?"
"Just a few days ago an Italian friend of mine and I went to be a part of the Ganpati Visarjan at Chowpatty and a gentleman there, assuming we were foreigners, took it upon himself to protect us. Wherever we walked he kind of formed a barricade around us like our own personal body guard. That's the beauty about this city  - chaotic, energetic but still so large hearted."

"I just finished my morning classes and I'm going home now to help my mother at home before the evening class. Actually, my parents and I stay with our Nani because we don't have our own home yet, but I like that because I love my Nani very much. There are a lot of days when Nani doesn't keep well...so I want to become a doctor as quickly as possible to help her. What makes me sad is that there are so many like her in my neigbourhood who need a doctor but can't afford one. I will always charge less or no money to my people when I become a doctor."

"I was working on Wall Street in New York, when I took 2 weeks of for a humanitarian trip to India. Our host, was this big Indian guy, who showed us around the city. When I went back to New York, a couple of my friends were making a trip to Bombay so I provided them with the contact of my host, and in that process we ended up talking - - our first phone conversation lasted 8 hours! Everything solidified 6 months down the line and I ended up moving to Bombay. It's funny because I'm sure he would have liked a petite South Indian girl, but instead ended up with a loud mouth American! We started our own NGO called Tender Hands, which helps underprivileged children and started TH bakes, a bakery to supplement that income. Even though I'm not from here, I feel connected enough to the people to try and make a change."
"What's the best part about India?"
"I think its the diversity. Everyone's so accepting of other religions and cultures - the goats are going for Eid, the Ganpatis are going for Visarjan all at once and the energy of it all is riveting. Also, one of the things I'll never forget is what his grandmother said to him on his wedding day. She said - 'she's left her country, she's left her people…she can never know a sad day in India' and I think that's a reflection of the people here - they're so kind and accepting."

"I was born in a very affluent family, and we lived in a massive bungalow with servers looking to our every need. Somehow, this sickened me - the servants bowing their heads and being treated badly if they made even a small mistake. Around me, I could see Indians fighting for Independence, but if we ourselves indulged in slavery how would we truly be free?I started living with the sisters in Convent and did all by chores by myself...I gave up a life of luxury very early on. 
I was married in 1946 and moved into this house behind me — and I couldn't have been happier. I worked, earned an honest 600 Rupees a month and shared so many happy, innocent memories with my husband. I was just 18 when I was married, so even a kiss on my forehead made me blush to no end! One day, when he was leaving for work, he caught me, hugged me tight and kissed me on the mouth for the first time — and this was a while after we were married…he was so sweet that he waited all that time for me to grow and take my time. We had 10 beautiful babies together…and they're all brought up with the right values of self sufficiency. 
So here I am today, at the brink of 90 - washing my own clothes, sweeping my own floors and cooking my own food. Not because I can't afford the help, but because I cannot afford the guilt that comes with it. Always remember that 'richness' is almost never defined by how much money you have — it is defined by the way you choose to live your life. So small home, no luxury, no help - but I still feel like a queen."
"Your questions are too stressful...I haven't thought so much in a long time. If I had thought so much before writing my papers, I would have stood first...guaranteed."

"We're very different - I'm the fighter and she's the docile one. Whenever she would be upset about something, she would come home and cry and I would stand up for her. We were also in different houses in school - so there were many times when we were competing against each other and people would love to see us fight...whether it was athletics or a dance competition.
So we're like any other siblings really - except we tend to confuse people. We also fight a lot -- I have this thing where I get really scared of the dark, so whenever we fight she threatens to not sleep in our room...and she's done it a hundred times while I end up uncomfortably sleeping with all the lights on!"
"Is there any incident or experience which has stayed with you?"
"It was during the 10th standard that I fell seriously ill - I couldn't eat anything, so I was basically on the drip for a few months. I wasn't even supposed to appear for my boards, but I would end up wasting a year. I've basically studied for my 10th board exams through her -- whatever she was studying, she would read aloud relentlessly through the day. She would work out each math problem on a board for me to see and tirelessly teach me, while I was lying down in bed. Without opening a book for a few months before my exams, I ended up getting 89% -- all because she selflessly studied for both of us. That's when the whole two bodies, one soul theory made sense to me."

"Ever since I was a little boy, the only thing I knew was music. I grew up in Uttarkhand and every morning my mother would wake me up with folk songs which resonated with the mountains. When I came to Bombay in 1987, I began working but would sing at home whenever I could. Call it fate, but in 1991 my neighbour heard my voice and immediately gave me the opportunity to sing on stage -- it was my first performance. That's when my love affair with music and Bombay began.
But life really changed for me when I did my first 'live' show with NSPA at Churchgate station. I was so nervous, my feet were shaking, I didn't know if security would throw me out or if people would listen. But they listened...they all listened because for those few minutes the busiest station in Bombay stood still with the music. I've sang at so many stations after and people remember me, my music, my personally composed songs. My soul is connected to music, and Bombay is the only place where they appreciated my work, despite me having no Bollywood background, or no pull in the industry. I want to say 'thank you' to the people of Bombay, who keep the art alive and who made yet another nameless face on the street...feel special."

"In those days we needed a visa to visit Goa, so I'd gone to the city of Karwar with my friends to get it. We stayed there for 2 days until our visa came and that's where I met his twin brother at the Club House. He wanted to 'time pass' with me and told all his friends about the 'Bombay girl he met'. So after work, my husband here - his twin brother came to see me too. We only briefly spoke after which I left for Goa. A few weeks later when I was back in Bombay at my teaching job, the Principal called me and said that there was a phone call for me and 'personal phone calls weren't encouraged'. I picked up and realised it was him…he called and said he was in the Navy and was visiting Bombay— so he would like to meet. Now, my friend's husband worked in the navy, so we did some research and realised that he wasn't in the navy at all. Basically, he was coming to Bombay to see me and cooking up all kinds of excuses to do that."
"What made you want to see her?"
"I don't know how to explain this to you, but I'll give it a try - since the time I saw her, I knew she was the woman I would marry and I just had to be with her. I could have done anything to be with her. And look where we are today...53 years we've been together and I still love her just as much."

"Since a young age I knew I would have to fund my college education by myself - so I applied for a scholarship from the United States Air Force, which essentially meant they would cover my education for 4 years and I would have to give them 4 years of active duty. It was when I traveled the world and went to college, that I realised I was lesbian. Under the 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell' policy you were allowed  to be in the military if you were queer, but you didn't 'engage in homesexual activity'. That didn't sit right with me, because why should I live a parallel life? I told the general I was lesbian and even married another woman — which made me the first woman of Indian origin to be expelled because of my sexual orientation. Thankfully all that's changed now.
I came to India after and I'm still very vocal about being a lesbian. It's not gone down well with a few people and it has with others — so it hasn't been half as bad. This one time I was going to cut my hair really short, when a gentleman there said, 'You might not get any good boy to marry you with this kind of hair!' To which I promptly replied,'but uncle, I like women." He thought about it for a few minutes and replied - 'but beta, women are even fussier - with this kind of hair no girl will also marry." We had a good laugh, but I guess that incident made me believe that there's hope for a change in perception about sexual orientation and someday we all can have a laugh about it, instead of making it a such a big deal."
"Mein Pradhan Mantri thodi na hoon, jo aap aise, beech raste interview ke liye pooch rahe hein."

"Over a year ago this woman took a huge order of bananas from me and hasn't paid me as yet. She's a director in some big company - I don't understand why the rich take away from the struggling? What's peanuts to her, is an entire month's salary to me. So many people bargain with us, when we're barely making enough to feed ourselves. Please share the message - if you have to bargain, bargain at the shops where you buy expensive clothes, or the big restaurants you eat at -- they can afford to give discounts; we can't."

"I've been working since I was 6 years old and selling samosas from village to village. I was the oldest sibling and I had the responsibility of looking after them since a very young age. They used to say, get married and you'll be happy...but my life was the opposite - my husband left me after I delivered our daughter, because he'd wanted a son. I was determined to not let this affect my child and I would do odd jobs to feed us. So many times she would come to me and ask me for 2 paise -- and then she would run out, buy us Kurmura and water which we would share and sleep.
Then, I had the opportunity to come to Bombay and my life changed. I've been working at this house since the past 22 years...and I'm finally at peace. I've educated my daughter till the 10th, sent money every month for my siblings, made a house for us back in my village in Kolkata and I've even managed to buy some jewellery. Every year during Diwali, I won't buy a new sari for myself but I'll buy new clothes and mithai for my brothers and sisters. 
My job has always been to look after my employer's baby and today she's 24 years old! She's grown up with me, heard my problems, given me advice and treated me like her mother. Really, the respect I've gotten here, I've never gotten in Kolkata. My village people spread rumours about me saying that I work at a Kotha in Bombay...and I just reply saying that, 'believe what you have to but if push came to shove I would even do that as long as it would feed my family."

"When the Bandra Fair is on, I sit here from about 9 in the morning until late evening offering free drinking water. People always need water, and so many of them cannot afford it. People come, take a glass, say thank you and leave with a smile. I don't think you need to do 'big things' to change the world -- you just need to care enough about the small things that can actually make a difference... and that's what I'm trying to do."

"Everyone keeps talking about Bombay being the city of dreams...but it can be very unkind. Bombay hasn't been kind to me, but I've learnt how to deal with the struggle. This message is to those who are in Bombay, struggling and feeling what I do -- don't give up."

"I was married extremely early but thankfully my husband was my friend before anything else. We grew up together and helped each other grow. We survived the riots during Partition together, and made a home for ourselves, together...brick by brick. We had many trying days...where we were struggling to make ends meet, but my husband would never give up. On days, we would share 2 Rotis, but we were still really happy. It was enough for us -- a roof over our heads, 2 rotis to share and a blanket to keep us warm."

"When all of Bombay was under water close to a decade ago, I was stuck on a highway in my taxi for 15 hours with another man and his baby daughter. During those 15 hours, I ran out and got Vada pav and tea for us at regular intervals. We had long conversations about his life, my life, where we came from and where we were going. At the end of it, that man in a suit and I, an ordinary cab driver had no differences between us - we were both stuck under one roof, eating the same food and discussing our lives. I guess in a way, it's mother nature's way of telling us that our differences are man made...and in the end we're all human and we're all at her mercy."

"I'm 90 and still walking, talking, laughing. All my years have taught me only one lesson - break monotony as much as you can. Don't live the same monotonous life and expect to have life changing experiences...it's only once you step out of that shell, that you'll truly know what life is about."

"This is her first time visiting Bombay and that's also because she was right here for the Kumbh Mela. We were married when we were really young and have lived decades of our life together...but I had to move here 4 years ago to work and this is the first time I'm seeing her since."
"What's the best part about her?"
"There is no good or bad...Her good is my good, but her bad is also good to me."

"We took the same dance class a couple of years ago, and realized over time that we were both passionate about the same things in life. During one of the rehearsals, our dance instructor charged towards me to hit me because I was laughing and before anything could happen, she was standing in front of me, yelling at him to stop. He threatened us and our careers and humiliated us in front of the entire class. Finally, the cultural head had to intervene. He had been a senior instructor at that Institution for years...so he thought that he was irreplaceable, but as soon as our cultural head heard about what he did - she asked him to leave. I think that incident was great for many reasons - for raising our voice and having it taken seriously."

"I'm 76 and still going strong like Johnnie Walker. To tell you the truth - I smoke and need my whiskey at night, but I'm still healthy. I'm not advocating any of these but my point is this -- people will always tell you, 'don't smoke, you'll die early', or 'stop drinking, it's bad for you' but I've only followed one thing in my life that's worked. It's this - 'Give as much happiness each day that you possibly can' - to those you know and those you don't know and watch the happiness you receive in return change your life. Happiness my friend, is the only key to health."

"My sister's daughter has been working as a part time maid at this house for a few years now. The owner, a very old woman once saw me dropping her off and asked about me. When she realised that we're both widows she asked me to come over and said, 'why don't you stay here at night? We're both alone...might as well give each other company.' I smiled and gladly agreed. Over the years, we found that we could chat about everything under the sun. I know that technically she's supposed to be my 'Madam', but over time that difference in status disappeared and we became friends. The last two days I couldn't go to stay, that's why I was there right now. She worries too much about me -- I got so many phone calls yesterday from her son to inquire about my health...but old lady that I am, I couldn't understand much on the phone - so I came here myself to tell her that I was okay and to not take so much tension!"

"I was born deaf and dumb, but because of learning how to lip read since a young age — I can now manage to speak…although it may sound a bit different to you. I've always wanted to be a Chef and many opportunities were denied to me because of my disability. That was the worst phase of my life, where I had no money and no job. Finally, a year ago I got the opportunity to work in a kitchen, and I haven't looked back since — my work speaks for itself. I've been given increments and appreciated for my efforts. It feels great to be treated normally and even better to be called, 'Chef.'"
"When were you the happiest?"
"A few years ago I saw this girl at Dadar market and liked her, but I never spoke to her at that time. In April, my friend came upto me and said, 'I found a girl for you' — and as fate would have it…it was the same girl. As it turns out, she was deaf as well. He met her in the handicapped compartment of the train, told her about me and took down her number.  I messaged her on the same day and asked her to meet me for a date. When we met, we did't need a lot of words…we both were given the same disability but that somehow that made us feel even more connected to each other. I knew when I first saw her that I wanted to marry and when she said yes…that moment I'll never forget! 
So apart from there being not as much talking, ours is a relationship like any other - we both work and love to spend all our free time together. Oh and just one more difference — I do all the cooking!"

"When I was at my previous school I would be terrified of attending classes, because I couldn't always answer questions and the teachers there would shout at me. This was because when I was 1 year old, I had fallen down a flight of stairs and have had recurring headaches ever since. I met Neha Didi through The Green Batti project and she gave me so much confidence to face my problems. She told me to not take tension, think about the answers...and if I still don't know the answer - it's okay. Earlier, I couldn't say anything in English...but because of her support, now I can have a conversation with you."
She has helped me with my family problems as well. I live with 4 other siblings, 2 of which are from my father's previous marriage. My mother has to undergo a lot of abuse from them...but Neha Didi explained to me that I would have to support my mother and make her happy-- so everyday I try to make her happy in some way...and her health has improved since then! She's not like other teachers my Neha didi...she has never shouted at me, she's given me confidence and taken away my fear. I want to be a doctor so that I can help those families who cannot afford medicines, and that is the biggest thing Neha didi has taught me -- my dreams are just as important as everyone's else's...and I too can become something."

" My whole family prayed for a son, but I secretly wished for a little girl. When she was born, I was ecstatic and my family was a little disheartened. I remember picking her up for the first time, so small and fragile. I knew that I would do anything to protect her…my little angel."

"We work in the same firm, but she's at a higher position than me."
"And how is that working out?"
"It's great...my boss gets me coffee in bed!"

"I came to Bombay as a tourist, but when I saw that there were so many opportunities for work - I decided to make the move. All my life I've made leather goods, but when I came to Bombay I had to make it a profitable business...so I came to Dharavi. Here I found space, all the materials I require and a place to stay. People look at Dharavi as dirty - but it's home to thousands of people like me, who had no other way. Today, I possess an art of making leather bags ; even if I see someone carrying a particular bag, I can replicate it by looking at it for a few seconds. I'm a poor man but I've enrolled my son in Computer classes so he can digitalise our business...I'm trying to keep up with the way of the World.
It's a simple concept - for India to grow, business has to grow. Whether we're big players or small players...if we have business we have money. Today my products are sold Internationally from this 10 by 10 room in a slum...but when it's worn abroad do people discriminate based on where it was made? Call it dirty, call it a slum -- but our products are A1. My only message to the PM would be -
 'Chote business ko bhi badhao, Sarkar...India ussi tarah badega!"

"Having children changed my life. I write poetry and direct commercials…so I never really thought that having children could influence that - but it has. They inspire me everyday. Their way of looking at things is so different - before the world teaches them what's right and wrong they have such a fresh and genuine perspective. Everyday, they manage to make me think and that inspires my work on a different level....having kids has been the most beautiful part of my life, in every way."
"We've been friends for over 30 years now, but our best memory was just a few years ago. We went for an an all girls trip to Rajasthan, without the boys and had an absolute blast!"

"I came to the Ghat a small boy and returned to my village a grown man ; I've worked here all my life and I have no regrets. They say, washing machines and new age technology will drive our business out -- but we're not worried. Even though we work to fill our stomachs, we also do it for those thousands of Indians who cannot afford a washing machine. Besides that, there are those loyal families who can afford it all but still choose our services. I have not studied Business but from experience I can tell you -- products will come and go but nothing in this world will buy you loyalty. That will only come from years of handwork and trust and us Dhobi wallahs have put in decades of our life to earn it."
"I come from a small town, but my biggest dream is to make it in the city of dreams. I don't know what it is about this place...but now that I'm here I feel close to achieving it already.

"She's from Islamabad and I'm from Bombay but we met each other in New York in 2003 through a common friend and we've been friends ever since. Infact when I was studying in London, she came there to see a prospective boy for marriage and I remember going with her, hiding behind a pillar to see if he looked shady and waiting till her date was done. They ended up getting married, but I couldn't attend the wedding in Islamabad because of visa issues. 
So here's the funny thing - we've been friends for over 12 years but never visited each others home. So this time I applied for a visa, went through a procedure of 4 months and finally came to visit her here in Bombay. I remember sitting on the flight here wondering what it would be like and I just want to say that it's been amazing -- all these divisions are in our mind. Another funny fact - it took me 1 hour to get from Karachi to Bombay but it would take me 2 hours to get from Islamabad to Karachi-- we're so close geographically but history has made us so bitter."
"What's been the highlight of your friendship?"
"Like everyone from India and Pakistan, the highlight would definitely be watching Cricket together. During the 2011 World Cup when Pakistan lost to India in the Semi Finals, I remember being upset and she was ecstatic but she still tried to make me feel better. We left for this remote island in Greece the next day, and because India was playing the finals -- she made me roam all over this island trying to find a screen to watch the game. We finally managed to watch the game together...and if you're wondering -- yes, I supported India with all my heart."

"These are the 3 most pampered babies of my family- Snowy, Twix and Ralph. Infact, every year we celebrate their birthdays and cut a cake just like we celebrate ours. I love starting my day with them-- every morning all three of them come to drop me off to work and I can't wait to get home to see them again. They're more than pets; I've grown up with them -- they're my family."

"We don't have limitations...we have perceived limitations. I'm a visually impaired photographer with a dream to have my photographs exhibited worldwide. I could have thought of it as a limitation, but I choose to look at it as having a different lens than the rest of the world"

"My father opened the first women's school in 1920. He believed in gender equality right from those times, and his efforts were often praised by Bapuji.  During the Quit India movement, Gandhiji sent a letter to my father asking us to close our Ashram temporarily and leave for Karachi, because of communal riots. He didn't have to warn us, but he was that kind of a man -- so kind towards everyone. The most important thing I learnt from him was to satisfy our needs, not our greed. 
Years after Independence when I was working as a chief accountant, I realised that the only thing that was running India was black money. Everything under the table, bribes, non profits minting money...I felt ashamed. I tried for years to stand up to it, to refrain from bribes -- but what was honesty to me came across as a lack of ambition to my superiors. I would be demoted a lot, pushed around a lot. For 19 years I worked this way in Bombay...but I reached my breaking point eventually. I quit and left the country."

We're elated to say that we've raised the entire amount of 5,00,000 Rupees in less than 15 hours! Thank you for generously donating and making a difference. Robin, the Co-founder of Kranti is deeply thankful to everyone who has taken out the time to help her organisation out. She says, 'I've never before come across a community as giving as this one. Thank you, from Kranti and all our girls - we're all looking forward to our new home.' :)

"When my father passed away, life became hell for my mother and 3 sisters. My mothers' as well as fathers' family began looking down upon as a burden-- and in order to make ends meet, my mother became a sex worker. My mama would often pay a part of our rent and as result began thinking that he had a control over us - we would be beaten, if we were seen outside the house without a burkha. My father was Muslim too, but he was never against our education, or not wearing the burkha.
Finally, my mother took the step of sending us sisters to a hostel, but that was a terrible experience where we would be starved for making small mistakes. After 8 long years, we came to Kranti where we're happy...here, we're given therapy and confidence. My mother's family questions where we are-- they think she sold us to the flesh trade, but really she's protecting us and our future.
Today, I'm a Teacher at Teach for India. I know and understand these children better than anyone, because I know what it's like. So many of them come from troubled backgrounds, and I'm trying to give them the confidence to continue studying. So many times when I see them smiling at me, I feel relieved -- but there's so much more to do, not only for children like me but for those sex workers who more often than not don't have a choice."

"On the day of my Mehendi, I was very upset because the colour of my Mehendi was very light. We've grown up hearing the story, that the darker the colour, the more your husband will love you.. so I was terribly upset and crying to my mother. The only reason I made it through was because she kept telling me 'don't worry, it's going to be okay.'"
"Actually when she came to me and showed me the colour of her Mehendi, I just put up a brave front, but I was very upset myself. I wanted my daughter to have the best of everything--especially during her wedding. As it turns out, the next day when we woke up the colour on her hands was the darkest I'd ever seen and that's when I started to cry in front of her -- it was time to give my daughter away."
In the midst of getting yelled at, this cabbie realises that we're taking his photo- so he looks directly at us...and smiles. Only in Bombay!

"Can I say cheese for the photo please?"
And just as I was about to take her photo, she stuck her tongue out, laughed and ran away :)

"While celebrating Independence, we often forget the devastation of Partition. Those days were the worst -- riots everywhere, trucks filled with people who would throw glass and sharp objects randomly on others walking on the street and mass migrations.
During those days, we would all only speak about Independence at work. We were 5 of us friends who would have tea together - Hindus and Muslims. When rumours of Partition began, we would joke about it -- my closest Muslim friend said, 'If I move, will you miss me?'
He ended up moving a few years later and it was a difficult and sad time. He was my friend, my brother and I don't think anybody wanted Partition...it just happened. I'm 99 years old, but I still feel sad remembering those times."
"What do you think of India today?"
"I'm 99 years old and I've seen India through Independence-- only one thing stands in our way - Corruption. But, I'm no longer as worried, I believe in Modi -- he will do something, he's the man India's been waiting for."

"Pre Independence, a few of us girls would dedicate our time to picketing stores that sold imported silk. We would stand outside for hours with boards, urging our fellow Indians to buy or make their own Khaadi instead. Sometimes, we would even burn this silk on the streets and say it's the Holi bonfire. We used to take pride in everything Indian --my husband even went to jail for 3 months because he used to sing everyday in our Prabhat Pheris.
Infact, when my husband's family sent the wedding proposal to my house, they had only one pre requisite -- that the girl should wear Khaadi!
Before marriage, I was from Madras and he was from Bombay so we mostly communicated through letters. Once, when I was going to my Mama's house in Ahmedabad, he said he would come to meet me. He came to pick me up and we sat by the river for hours   -- I think I was one of the only few girls back then who went on a date before marriage! 
But the best part about him was undoubtedly how patriotic he was -- until the day he passed away he only wore Khaadi. He really believed that as Indians, we're self sufficient. During Independence, we were all bound by only one goal -- to liberate our country...today, everyone's only concerned with how much money we individually make. If we could do it back then, we can do it today - before we liberated Indians from the British...and today, together we can liberate India from corruption."
#IndependenceDay #68yearsstrong

"I had to drop out of school when I was in the 6th grade, because my parents felt it was unsafe for me to travel to school alone and because they're both disabled they couldn't accompany me either. Somehow, after a year I got back into education but during my 10th I had to face another obstacle, because this time I didn't have 3000 Rupees to pay my fees. With the help of the Shakti Circle in my slum, I approached IAPA to help me pay my fees -- and to my surprise they granted it! Can you imagine, what that 3000 Rupees meant to me?
We live in a slum and with 5 people in such a tiny space it was impossible to study-- so for all my exams, late into the night I would study on a small bike outside my house. There were flies everywhere, but I had to pass anyhow... and I'm so happy that I did.
I'm studying arts at a college now, and even though I have some difficulty writing in English, my teacher has motivated me to not be disheartened. I have big dreams; I want to be a journalist one day, and spread awareness about the lives we as slum children live...what's basic to you, is luxury to us. I want to make a mark in the world. I want to buy my mother a house so that for once, we can wake up in a space that we can call 'home.'"

"My parents took me away from Bombay to our village to get me married. This was at the age of 15 and even though I saw the boy, I made it clear that I couldn't get married. After we returned to Bombay, the boy's parents called us and said that the boy had said no. My mother thought it was my fault and that I did something, but the truth is that I didn't. To protect myself, I'd just said that I'll run away and tell the police--and if need be I would have followed through with it.
A few months ago, my Mama called my mother and said that he wanted me to marry a divorced man with 2 children. I got so angry when my mother even mentioned this. I said, 'How can I mother two children, when I'm a child myself. Why don't you understand that If I study and earn for myself, I won't need to rely on anyone to survive?' She said that this is all new age thinking, but ever since then she hasn't brought up marriage. I won't stop -- I have a dream and I will become an IPS officer and prove to her that a girl doesn't need a man to lift her up...infact she's so strong that she alone, can uplift others."

"I'm a designer and during the 26th July floods, my studio was completely destroyed and all my samples ; everything I had worked so hard for was ruined. Around the same time, my daughter who was in the 6th grade lied to me about her homework and I felt really disconnected from her and decided to give it all up. No one asked me to not work, but a sentiment that a mother shares with her child is unexplainable -- I wanted to be a part of everything they did.
As time passed and my children grew up, I realised that my passion was still alive, so 4 years ago I resumed working...this time with a bigger dream. I guess that fire doesn't die out, it just blows over for a while and that's exactly how I'm feeling right now. Infact, I just saw a bigger studio that hopefully I can move into soon."

"I study at a Municipal school where boys my age indulge in drugs, perform dangerous stunts and inappropriately trouble girls. A few years ago I joined Aangan, where several slum children like me have enrolled to have a safer childhood, and that's when I learnt the importance of respect for women. Earlier I used to be like those boys in my class -- but now I'm trying to make a difference myself. The other day, my friend from class was touching a girl and harassing her when I stopped him and tried to reason with him.
"What did you tell him?"
"I told him to think of his sister who studies in the 8th Grade and how he would feel if someone behaved that way with her. My biggest victory so far is that since that day, he's never done it again."

"We've always lived two lanes away from each other and started hanging out through common friends. We'd been best friends for 11 years, through the distance of him going away to boarding school and me studying abroad. While I was in London, he tried to set me up with his best friend, but realised through that process that he actually had feelings for me. On Valentines Day of that year, he sent me a parcel containing a tissue, that I had written both our numbers on, almost 7 years ago! He said, ' I don't know why I saved it all these years, but you've always been special'...and I guess that's how we started dating.
The best part about him is that he's always pushing me to grow. People always talk about the big things, but it's the small victories-- like him pushing me to learn how to drive that really count. Also, he makes the most creative gifts for any occasion- I've been trying to compete with him since years, but always failed! I'm so happy because today, of all days happens to be his birthday...so hopefully this year, this post makes his day as special as he always makes mine."
"What do you want to say to him today?"
"Just thank you for being you in my life."

"I was walking in the market, trying to buy Gasoline when a group of boys, listening to loud music on their phones walked towards me. Before I knew what happened, one of them grabbed me from the front -- I was so shocked for a second I couldn't even move. However, I was determined to not let this go and I went to the police station just opposite the road and told them what had happened. The police and people from the market beat that boy in front of my eyes, but I was terrified because of what people would say. 
When the police came to my house and told my parents what had happened, my kaka's initial reaction was, 'why did you wear a sleeve less dress and walk out?'. I realised then, that I was relieved that I had raised my voice -- earlier I would have kept it to myself but this time I had made the right choice. Even though I'm just 15 and my parents decided against pursuing the case in court-- I'm happy that that boy who went to jail for two nights will think twice before mindlessly attacking a girl on the street."

"I'm a divorcee - at least that's what my identity was until a few years ago.
