When I came back home, my mother and father were constantly worried about me, but I asked them to have faith in my ability and allow me to work -- which they did. Slowly, my identity went from being just a 'divorcee' to being a 'working woman', which some people looked down upon, but I was proud of. If left upto me, I wouldn't ever get married, but for the happiness of my parents, I met another man who was a lot more open minded.
I got married to him and the best part was that he looked at me as an equal.  We'd taken a loan for our house and we're both working towards paying that off. Right now, I'm on my way to BKC to try and get a 2nd part time job -- we're looking to have a baby soon and I don't want the future and education of my child to be uncertain. I work hard and so does my husband...equally and we're both so happy to have found one another's support. I don't understand, why should the entire burden fall on the man?"

"My son was an alcoholic and passed away a few years ago. His wife and 2 children now stay with us -- but I worry for their future. My husband and I are trying to make ends meet, while his wife manages the house and children but I've been worried about their education - they barely learn anything in these municipal schools. 
One day, my grandson came upto me and asked me why I looked worried...I told him that it was nothing, but he hugged me and said - don't worry, I'm going to study hard, become a big man and buy a house for us. I know he's young, but I realised then that where you study isn't the end of the world -- our dreams go a far way beyond that."

"We were on our way to Shimla by bus when my wife and I met a couple our age and started chatting with them. It was a long journey and we got to know each other pretty well. They were from Shimla, so they insisted that we stayed with them for our time there instead of spending money on a hotel. We were skeptical, but eventually agreed and how wrong we were -- they were the most hospitable hosts and took care of us like we had known each other for years. When we were leaving for Bombay, they came to drop us at the bus stop and gave us a box of home made ladoos for the journey. I was so touched with the gesture, I told my wife that the world has made us so negative that we doubt the intention of the purest of people.
I don't know a lot about Facebook and these new age communications but I sent him a letter inviting him to our home and we received a reply that said, 'My dearest brother, we will come to you in one month, but first my wife is asking you which ladoos you would like to eat this time' -- and that was the start of a very special friendship."

"I was never going to let myself beg. After I came very close to starving the last time, I borrowed some money and bought this weighing scale. It's 2 Rupees to check your weight -- but it gets me through the day and most importantly doesn't make me someone who begs for survival."

"What do you do?"
"I'm a writer from Delhi – I like all kinds of writing, but I prefer comedy"
"So which do you prefer, Bombay or Delhi?"
"To be honest it would be really unfair to pick one...because they're both so shitty."

"We used to live in the same lane when we were younger and that's how we first met. I knew I liked her when I first saw her but it was always going to be difficult because she's Catholic and I'm Parsi. This one day, our families went to Juhu beach and long after every else had come out of the water, we both were still swimming and that's when everyone realised something's fishy and her sister confronted us. 
I asked her father for her hand in marriage and even though so many of our relatives taunted us and spread rumours about us -- I convinced him of my love for her and he agreed. When we first got married we were really young, with no stable income but this woman here has been through it all with me. The happiest memory I have is the look on her face when we entered the first house we bought. She kept smiling and said, 'I can't wait to make it our home' and that's something I'll never forget."

"After my parents divorce, I started looking at life a little differently...I guess it broke how I believed in man and commitment.  So I've been traveling, finding my passion and meeting all sorts of people. I found it in a way -- I want to become a pastry chef and make edible art. The thing is, I let go of one of the biggest factors that influences how we live."
"What's that?"
"Anything that makes people love money more than life itself is the worst thing to hold onto -- give that up and you're free."
"My biggest dream is to sit on an aeroplane. I've never sat on one before, but I've always wondered what it's like from up there. It's a small dream...but nothing would make me happier."

"We've come here together as one to protest peacefully for our salaries. We've been working for years at a consumer goods' factory plant and since the beginning have received little to no payment for our labours. It's not fair for us women – we live in a small village and the amount of money they give us is not even enough for us to sustain just us alone. 
More than half these women have children that they have to support as well. I have a son and a daughter – my son is in 10th std and my daughter in the 7th std. In our village after the 7th std, they don't teach English, they only teach  in Marathi, which is why I have sent my kids to a school and hostel about 10 km away from our village – because  they learn in English there and I want them to make something of themselves.
I'm happy that they have the option to move ahead in life, and that is what will make me continue my struggle. All of us here are making ends meet for our children...so that they never have to go through what we have and we're sticking together so that we don't get swallowed by corporates trying to cheat us simple Indian village women"

"I remember a very different Bombay during Partition and Pre-Independence. One day, when we were driving by Marine Drive  all of a sudden there were riots, tear gas shells and violence everywhere. I saw a man die in front of my eyes and when I asked my mother about him, she put her hand over my eyes and asked me to forget about it. I decided then that I wanted to be a lawyer, I followed up on it and I was a topper in my year as well.
However, once I was married my In-laws asked me to give my practice up and focus on making a home. I gave it up and enjoyed my time with my husband who I loved immensely, but he passed away very early on in our marriage. It was then that my in-laws encouraged me to work again--this time running a business. I guess that's what we women do- we take on a role, or multiple roles to protect our families...and I have loved my time working, without any complaints. 
When we were well settled, I made a great investment in a plot of land in Karjat and got myself 2 dogs to keep me company on the weekends. Unfortunately, when the female dog passed away, the male slipped into a frenzy and even though I moved there to make him feel better, within 6 months he passed away too. Sometimes I feel like him, without my husband -- but I guess we as Humans have to hold it together a lot longer. So that's my story, and as for some advice, on a lighter note I'd say - Girls, study hard and remember to keep your accounts separate -- you never know how life turns out!"

"I was really upset when my last relationship ended. I'd lost hope on the idea of real love and began to think that it's something you build in your head, but really it's a piece of shit that doesn't exist -- basically I gave up. 
This had been going on for a few, when I met someone through a friend and I don't know if you've ever felt this, but I felt like I've already known him for years. That's the thing, when you're in a bad phase you think it's the end -- but it's not. This relationship is so much better than anything else I've been in and I had no idea what love was before. I've always been a hopeless romantic and to think that I almost lost myself to something as trivial as a 'bad phase' is scary. So, I got this tattoo - a crescent moon, to always remind myself of a 'new phase' that's just around the corner."

"I've been very close to an autistic child for many years now. He really changed how I looked at life -- he's so innocent and helpless, but still so full of love that it made me question the things I complained about. He made me feel more grateful for my life...for having a healthy son and family. 
When I first met him he was 22 and very expressive, but I found that when we were out in a social environment his family would tell him not to behave a certain way, or speak loudly or really express anything at all. Being as expressive as I am, I put myself in his shoes and understood how difficult it would be to curb his expression, for no fault of his own. I asked them to let him be and find his expression -- and he did! He loves dancing and he's with Shiamak now - leading a normal life where he goes out with his friends, family and does what he loves for a living. It's funny that we think Autism needs to be hidden, because it doesn't-- trust me sometimes they're more normal than the rest of us."
"Oh my God, I've always wanted to get featured and I can't believe you've found me today of all days...it's my birthday!"

"I was away from home at boarding school since a very young age. I was exposed to things like drugs and suicide since that age. I was sheltered all my life so, initially I felt like it was difficult to connect with people there, but I guess I grew out of it. I came back to Bombay and realised that id seen a different version of Bombay before I left. What I thought was Bombay, really wasn't. Its about feeling the sticky wind of Marine Drive, eating that vada Pav and having chai at your favourite chai wallah. It's about walking through the bustling and crowded street of Colaba Causeway rather than the Palladium mall. So even though I thought I had been sent away...I get it now - Sometimes you have to get out in the real world to change your perspective."

"I lost my son to a highway road accident a few years ago. To outlive your child, through such a painful experience hasn't been easy - especially because there isn't a day I don't think about it. However, I haven't shown any sign of weakness, because he's left his wife and son behind -- and I have to be strong for them. My daughter-in-law and I both work and I'm doing everything I can to make sure that we all still feel like a family. Sometimes it gets difficult to understand what God's plans are, but I know now that its best to have faith, try to move on from death and live for one's who are alive and still believe in you."

"I knew when I was 16 and I was sure of it when I was around 20. I told my sisters, cousins and important friends first, and I'm very open about it as well, but the final act only happens once you tell your parents -- which I haven't yet. Speaking with you now, I realise that this is just something I have to do...I don't want to go through my life buried with a secret. So now that I'm doing this, I know I have a timeline and I have to tell them before your post comes out...so I'm going to do it tonight."
"What are you going to tell them?"
"That I bumped into Humans of Bombay, they asked me about my life and I told them I'm gay, but I'm still your son and I love you just as much."
"My happiest memories are of my entire family coming together to break our fast during Ramadan. It's more than religion -- it binds us together in the most beautiful way."

"The four of us are best friends...family almost. We were here 2 years ago in Delhi to teach English to underprivileged children, but we love India so much that we had to come back--this time to Bombay. We're staying at a youth hostel but one of the weirdest things to happen to us here was when a couple of lads decided to follow us for an entire day, making hilarious comments like - 'come cook some fish in our restaurant'. Anyways, can you help us with this jewellery seller - he's asking us for Rs.100 for these earrings, is it a fair price?"

Hi guys,
There are multiple accounts floating around on Twitter and Instagram which aren't us. Just mentioning our official handles here-
Twitter - @humansofbombay
Instagram - @officialhumansofbombay
Thanks for the love :)

"Years before I retired, I began saving for a World Tour with my wife and now with the children all married and settled -- it's finally happening! It's taken long...but I can't believe I'm going to see the whole World with her soon."

"What's special about Leopold is that we have had people come in from all different walks of life, from Hippies, to Arabs and Afghans--we've had a little something for everyone and it's an amalgamation of culture, and love. The best compliment I've received, is from the author of Lonely Planet Guidebook. This was about when 20 years ago when he would come into Leopold from morning to night and write all day. He said to me, 'this place has some magic--it makes my pen fly.'"

"I was treating a patient of Schizophrenia at the Thane Mental hospital years ago. Her attacks were extreme and her actions were drastic, to say the least, but at other times she could be like you, me or anyone else -- well spoken with a great understanding of the world. I felt really close to her, so one day I asked her why she chose to stay in this hospital, when most tests had said she was stable enough to be allowed out. To that she, replied - 'because I find that it is safer here, than out there in that unreal world'...and those words really shook me up."

"I'm married so I have a lot of responsibilities at home, but every alternate Saturday when she has an off from work -- I make sure I finish all my work in the morning and spend my day with her. We're trying to do different things and get stuff off our bucket list...and this is actually one of them -- spending a rainy day lazing around at Marine Drive, not really doing anything else."

"I was in Kuwait working a night shift as a nurse when Iraq invaded. For the next 3 days, I was taking care of the patients and wounded soldiers all by myself, surviving purely on Glucose water, until an Iraqi doctor arrived. When you see war and death up so close, you realize the true meaning of 'Life is Now' and I wondered what I was doing today to help the world. When I came back to Bombay, I got heavily involved in Yoga and teaching Yoga – but it was on a trip to Thailand that I was first introduced to Foot Reflexology. I took a course to learn reflexology and when I came back to Bombay, I trained visually impaired students from the Blind School in the same field. 6 months later, they were all well trained but no spa wanted to employ them because they weren't as good looking, or wearing short skirts. I decided to go by 'Life is Now', sold my jewelry and opened a spa of my own with visually impaired staff. 
At the end of the first day, when we had given free massages, one of the girls came upto me and asked me to count her tips – she had earned only 70 rupees in tips for 6 massages. I felt terrible. But what she said to me next, changed my life. She said, 'Madam, why you worry? 60 rupees ka recharge, 10 ki Cadbury – meri toh ho gayi Chandi!"

"I went to the school at the end of this street and when I see a fresh set of young boys every year, running around care free -- I sometimes wonder where life has passed me by. I've had a peaceful life, working at my own store for close to 6 decades, but I think that maybe I would have liked to take a few more risks and been exposed to more change. A lot of people think that change is a bad thing -- but take it from someone who's lived his entire life on one street that change is a lot less frightening than living the same life every single day."

"When I was 14, I used to talk to boys; drive motor cycles, smoke cigarettes and people in Bandra would often call me a whore because of those things. I never understood the term back then, but sure if doing all those things made me a whore-- I'd take it gladly. After my father's death, I moved to Chicago where there were so many like me and it gave me the freedom to get inked, experiment with my hair and just be myself.  One Christmas Eve in Chicago, I walked out of a bar alone late at night in a short dress and red lipstick. I was 24 and had been drinking, when from a dumpster a group of guys walked upto me and put a gun to my head asking me to give them blow jobs, eventually leading to gang rape. I remember walking home, showering and pushing this incident to the back of my mind for years and never letting it break my spirit – I still wear short dresses and the brightest red on my lips.
 In years to come, I got married to my high school sweetheart, faced domestic violence and walked out of the marriage wondering how this could happen to ME, a feminist? It's because sometimes there are things that are beyond your control. We live in a world where everyone stresses the importance of voicing yourself or walking out of tough situations, but I just want to say this— no one wants to be beaten up, get raped or sell their bodies. It took me 20 years to voice my incident, but for me a woman keeping it all within her because she has no other choice isn't a sign of weakness – it's a mark of strength and something we need to start respecting."

"My mother used to stay very ill when we were little and she died when I was two. Because we were poor we couldn't treat her and at the same time my siblings and I had to drop out of school. I could only study till my third standard, but I always wanted to study more. I came to Mumbai about four years ago and got a job as a security guard. One of my lady co-workers would often bring one of her friends along. She (the friend) was my age, we started talking and became good friends. I've learnt so much from her-- everyday she would teach me how to read in English. She has an incredible way of talking and dealing with people and I picked that up from her as well. Today I can understand English well and can read full paragraphs in English, even though it takes me time. I've loved her since I was 16 and that's not only because we grew up together...but because she gave color to my biggest dream as if it were her own."

"I was a stroke victim, post which I couldn't move the right side of my body, but I never gave up. I got into a wheelchair in one week and went back to whatever work I could manage, working half day. Today I'm 98% recovered but that period of paralysis taught me a lot about life. It taught me the importance of controlling your mind and the huge influence of family. My children have taken care of me and my wife stood by me like a rock-- not only through this, but everything in my life. I used to work in shipping and was on call 24 hours a day, I quit multiple jobs and was away from home a lot, but she never complained. I'm the man I am today because of her.  We had a love marriage and the one golden reason why we stayed together for so many years is this -- we would never go to sleep angry with each other. She isn't here today, but I still love her like its the first day we met."

"Years ago I was travelling to Jammu by train with a friend and both of us didn't have confirmed seats. Being young and travelling to a new place in a crowded train without seats, we were a little frightened of the situation. There was an elderly couple in our compartment who must have sensed our discomfort and all through the journey offered us food, asked if we were okay and kept asking us to sit instead of them. I've travelled almost the whole country, and I found that it's given me so many such experiences -- the journey ends but the feeling of strangers going out of their way to help others, remains forever."

I've always wanted children, but God had different plans for me. I have money, land and property -- but I don't have motherhood. I used to get very upset over this, but then I decided to shift my focus and introspect. I noticed everyday that so many people would call me 'amma' and seek my blessings-- I was already a mother to so many! Motherhood has many different forms and maybe this one was meant to be mine...I just never noticed it before."

"I used to work in the verification department at a bank, but after I had the baby I took a break. Once he was a little grown up, I knew that I wanted to do something that would allow me to work and be with the baby at the same time-- so I chose to sell sweet corn. A lot of people think that it's a decline from my previous job, but believe it or not I make more money here than at that bank. Also it isn't always about the money and life isn't always about doing what looks good to society -- sometimes you have to block out what people say and do what's right for you and your family."

"My uncle suggested a boy for me to marry a few years ago, and my parents trusted his decision. A few years into the marriage, I realized that he was an alcoholic and very abusive under the influence. I tried to stay patient and change his habits but when I couldn't take it anymore I decided to leave him. I expected my parents to be supportive, but instead they were pressurizing me to go back to him and not shame the family. My husband and uncle brainwashed my parents into believing that I was lying about everything. I knew that if I continued to stay at my parent's house, I would eventually succumb to the pressure and go back to him -- so I left for Bombay. I work here at a salon, but I've never felt more alone. Even here, men look down upon me because of my failed marriage. I don't understand how I've shamed my family, or why it's so wrong to be divorced? What do they want -- for me to suffer but continue putting a smile on my face?"
"Me and granny play 'House-House'. I always be her mother and granny is always my daughter!"
"This is the saddest phase of my life, but I prefer smiling to moping around - you know why? Because 99% of the time it helps...I don't know how, but it makes it easier to cope."

"I was 18 and studying music at McGill University when I got an opportunity to work on a 'Chakra Album' in India. Something in my gut told me that I should take it, so I spoke with my parents and decided to 'take a semester off', but never ended up going back. I came to Bombay, fell in love with the city, it's people…basically everything. I also ended up meeting a very special person here…but eventually I had to go back to Canada. When I did, I recorded a song called 'Tu jaane na' for him and uploaded it on YouTube…and it got 1 million hits overnight!
I was working as a waitress at that point to buy a ticket to India and afford rent there…but after the video, opportunities started flowing in and as fate would have it – I came back to Bombay. So, I dropped out of college, worked as a waitress, came to an unknown city without knowing much, found love, worked with A.R.Rahman and created a life for myself all because I stepped out of my comfort zone. I decided to not just 'wait around for the right moment'….but instead made it the 'right' moment."
"My happiest memory was when we were all watching Chennai Express together...Shah Rukh Khan makes me smile."

"My daughter lives in Canada, so she told me one day - 'Mumma, follow Humans of New York you're going to love it!', so I told her, 'we have Humans of Bombay - you start following that'...and look Lisa, here I am today!"

We grew up in a red tiled cottage with a backyard in Colaba. Our doors were always open and all of us siblings would be running around playing all day. On the first day of summer vacations, my father would take us to a sports store and ask us to each buy 1 thing we liked — so all us brothers and sisters would get together and make sure that we didn't overlap anything and had as many sport gears to pick from. I realize now that he wanted to form that bond between siblings and how successful he was! He always said, 'Find your friends within the family first', and till today we're all best friends— our mother included.
As everything goes by quickly, so does time with your siblings and I got married at the age of 36…but it didn't work out. When I came back home, my youngest brother and I were sitting at home one evening when the doorbell rang — someone had come to inquire about the car he was trying to sell. However, he turned that person down. I asked him why, because I knew he was trying to sell that car since a long time. He looked at me and said, 'Because I want you to have it'. I don't want you to depend on anyone to drop or pick you up and feel sorry for yourself - I want you to be the happiest, most independent spinster in town!'. I knew he really needed that money, but what he did for me took me back to what my father said…'find your friends within the family first'. Ofcourse, it  took me time to get out of my shell at first but because I'm blessed to have beautiful people around me... I'm here today. I'm 57, single, happy and still not giving up on love."

"I was happiest when I first fell in love. It's something you can't explain to anyone, but just the fact that you can feel like you're on top of the world, day after day is special. When things end, it's sad and just like being in love, the beauty of sadness is that it's so personal. People will tell you that they understand how you feel and I'm grateful for the empathy -- but no one can completely understand what it actually feels like to be in love, or feel the sadness once it's gone."

"My husband was over protective and never allowed me to work. I was frustrated with my life, sitting at home without a purpose. After he passed away 15 years ago, I decided to stand on my feet and take over our family fish business instead of selling it. I began working, supporting my children and having a purpose. We're a community of ladies who all do this and support one another. We're fisherwomen yes, but that doesn't mean we have no value. Our hands may smell, but we have good hearts. So today, I can look back at my life and think that it was so hard because my husband died early, but I choose to look at it as something that gave me a new life - one that I lived being strong and independent."

"We tend to think of God as a super power, who we haven't ever seen or heard. I've come to realize that most of the time, he takes the form of other humans around us to give us a message. Just now, 5 seconds ago I was sitting here asking him to give me a sign; any sign to let me know that what I really want is on it's way and just that second you, a complete stranger came from across the street and said, 'hello'!"

"I was travelling by train one day when the lady next to me was bitterly crying. None of the other ladies asked her what happened or if she needed anything...they just passively let it pass. I was alone during that train ride and realised that she was alone too and just needed somebody. We spoke, she stopped crying and we parted ways but the incident stayed with me. It was after this that I got a tattoo that reads - 'If we are all alone then we are all together in that too.' It reminds me everyday, that I might just be the one to make someone else feel a little less alone, when they most need it."

"At 12, my mother pulled me out of school so that she could move to Kuwait for a job and I could take care of my younger siblings back here in Bombay. She's promised to send money but that never happened, so I learnt young that I would have to make money to survive - I did odd jobs, cleaned houses and took care of my sisters. 
At 21, I moved to Kuwait myself to work with an Arab family and with that money educated my sisters. I thought I was too young to be taken seriously, but I worked there for 8 years! I moved to Bahrain and Egypt after and before I realized I was 40 years old! I'd spent my life working without a man by my side, but Father told me that it was never too late--and he was right. I fell in love and got married at the age of 40. 
After he passed away a few years ago, I resumed cleaning houses for a living. While cleaning a house in Bombay I came across a teacher who couldn't pay me what I usually charge but promised to teach me in return-- I was besides myself with excitement! Can you imagine...at 55 I was sitting for hours completing my homework and trying to read and write? So if I really had to tell you what my experience of 60 years has taught me, and could you please put this in bold... THERE'S NO SUCH THING AS THE RIGHT TIME, AND IT'S NEVER TOO LATE TO DO ANYTHING."

"It was raining heavily that November night, when I just wasn't getting a rickshaw outside the railway station. There were many others, one of which was a man standing around 10 meters away, looking at me helplessly. When I finally got a rickshaw, on an impulse I turned to him and asked where he was going. He replied, 'Veera Road', to which I said - 'Well, in that case you drop me off first' and asked him to join me.
At this point in my life I was broke and was praying to God to send someone in my life who I could start a business with. The ensuing conversation in the rickshaw was basic - we exchanged names, phone numbers and he dropped me off. Eventually though, we became friends and I realized that he too was unhappy at his job. That's when one evening we put together a business plan and became partners...and we were immensely successful, even expanding internationally to London. It was also through this man that I was introduced to the love of my life a few months later -- all from a chance encounter...Serendipity as they call it. After that day, I've paid closer attention to the little incidents and realized that there are countless Serendipities all around us...if we were only open to their existence and gave them a chance."

"I started feeding them around 5 years ago. A lot of people thought it was unusual to feed crows, but I could relate with them the best. I've known all my life what it's like to be hungry and uncared for -- and I feel it's like that for them too, so I decided to do something about it."

"What's do you like most about each other?"
"Well, there's nothing that great...she's alright."
"I like that she's blunt- the 'no bullshit' kind."

"I'm here on business for three months and my newly wed wife is back home in Ranchi. The city's fine, business could have been better but right now that's the last thing on my mind. I thought that three months away from her wouldn't be so difficult...but it is. Beyond a point, no business or money matters; like right now...I just want to go home to my wife."

"I got my first period at the age of 12 and I was told to keep it a secret from everyone - my father and brothers included. From there on, during those 7 days I was considered impure - I couldn't enter the kitchen, or sit on the sofas and of course…no entry into a place of religion. My teachers in school would blow over this part of biology and ask us to go through it on our own. I used a cloth (which I washed and rewashed and hid in a damp corner when I wasn't menstruating), because it was considered 'shameful' to ask a chemist for sanitary napkins in a small town like mine. Ironically, most of the time- these restrictions are imposed by the older women in our families. I grew up being ashamed of my body, considering it impure and dirty during periods.
It was only after I went to boarding school and met my husband that I could discuss my period in the open. He was shocked to know about the restrictions imposed upon girls when they are on their periods. That's when we started Menstrupedia - a comic strip that teaches young girls about menstruation and any problems they might have, because there are so many girls today who are still kept in the dark about menstruation. My question is…why are made to hide what shouldn't be hidden and why isn't enough respect given to the fact that it is because of a woman's period that life itself exists?
"I come home from school before mom comes home from work, so I wait for her. As soon as she does, we sit with a bowl of milk and a pack of biscuits on the table and talk about our day...everyday."

"The heat is unbearable and the only respite we have is to park under shady trees, or any form of shade...but these days before you can reach and park, these young couples have already occupied the spot!"

"I used to be tied down before marriage. I was never allowed to work or voice my opinion on anything, because I was always considered inferior to my brothers. I got married at 20 and my life has changed since. My husband made me a partner in his work, he asked for my opinion from the smallest of matters to big family decisions. He encourages me to keep myself busy and makes me feel equal to him, because I too contribute to the family income. They got me married early to get rid of the burden, but didn't realize that the burden actually lifted from me -- I finally felt free."

"I was visiting my sister in Allahabad when it happened. She had recently separated from her husband and was getting a divorce, that summer. My sister, our two friends and I were walking near a railway station when her husband and two friends were waiting with acid. He held my sister's hand and tried to pour acid on her but she was fighting him off. She shouted, 'Reshma, you run!' but before I could do anything, his two friends pushed me to the ground, held my hands and poured acid all over my face. I was only 17 at the time and my offenders are walking free today, while I have to go through life without a face. 
After the attack, I didn't receive a single rupee in compensation from the government, but instead from an NGO- Make Love Not Scars and that's where I met Ria Ma'am. She changed my life…I used to cry all day after the attack and had no hope for my life, but she drew me out of my shell. I used to have no courage, but now I want to study and work for so many other women like me who have been subjected to this brutality. I want them to have hope, like I do now. I want them to have faith, like I do now. I want them to know that beauty isn't skin deep and it goes a far way beyond that. I am brave. I am beautiful."

"Brian here is our first pet, and he's just one and a half years old- so he's like our baby. Just like a new born, we learn things about him everyday. When we get him here for a walk, he sits facing the sea and doesn't even make a sound or move an inch. Whenever I come back home from work, he runs upto me, licks my face as if to ask me, 'where have you been'? I can't explain it but I feel like even without words, my communication with him is by far the best. That's love I guess...it doesn't always need words."

I'm a gymnast, but in recent times I've learned a lot about our government because of my passion. We have zero facilities, and our government sponsorship is minimal. When I went to Brazil to participate in the World School Games, I was shocked to see the kind of support the government of other countries were giving them. I actually performed for the first time on mats there -- because they weren't available to us in India. Governments of countries like Russia and China spend thousands of dollars on costumes and apparatus, and ours is made of the cheapest material and sometimes we have to pay for our own equipment. We're supposed to have budgets for all of this - but we don't get anything that we're supposed to! When will we respect passion for the sport (other than cricket) and when we a see a change from politics and corruption?"

"We were passing by this Street Art, when she shouted- 'Dadi, even I want to paint Bombay!' This was three weeks ago and everyday she says she wants to paint Bombay...so here we are - paints, newspapers and all!"

"Like any other group of boys in high school, my group was naughty, full of pranks, back benchers and constantly teasing one another. We graduated in the year 1968 and I thought we'll lose touch -- but that hasn't been the case; they've been with me through it all. 
A few years ago, I was having a bit of trouble putting together the money for my children's education, when voluntarily they came together to help me out - no questions asked. Today, my children have graduated from New Zealand and America and I can't be more thankful, because I never imagined that the 'boys' I went to school with would do for me, what sometimes even family would hesitate to do."

"I was working at a PR firm,when I randomly thought of what the visually impaired read when they wake up. I began researching and found that apart from a newsletter once in every 3 months, they didn't have access to what's happening around us. I quit my job and began working full time on publishing a monthly Lifestyle magazine in Braille for the visually impaired called 'White Print'. My idea was to make them feel as normal and a part of society as possible - so the magazine entails information on cool new apps, fashion trends, Bollywood updates, advertisements from Tata Group to Coca Cola and yes, even a subscription fee. More often than not, we treat them as charity cases - when all they really want is to pay for things and do things the way we normally do. Just the other day my visually impaired proof reader at the National Association for the Blind came across the word 'selfie' and asked if it was a typo. I went on to explain what it meant and believe it or not, the next day she called me and said, 'check out my photo on Facebook' - and it was captioned 'Selfie!"
So may times people have told me to stop this charity (even though its not) and get a big salary job, but no job can give me this kind of satisfaction. Satisfaction is when a visually impaired man tells you -'I've been blind since 1958 but very people and things have touched me--and White Print is one of them."

"He asked for my hand in marriage in 1947 when I was only 17 years old. In those days it used to be difficult to just 'date' before marriage and I'd known him for years before because he was my family friend. I agreed to get engaged so young because my mother said that with the partition and riots he would take at least 4 years to get a house -- but my fiancé was so excited to have his bride at home that he worked really hard and bought a house within just 6 months! We lived in that house for 66 years after and oh what a beautiful life it's been...he was a pilot so we've travelled the world and made amazing memories together. Even though I became a mother at a really young age -- it never stopped us from traveling and our love from growing. 
He passed away in January this year, and for the two months that he was unwell and in bed before- he would call out to me every 15 minutes with his arms wide open and say 'come here, give me a kiss -- I love you so much'. And gosh, I miss him and love him too. But you know, he lives on still -- we've had 4 children, 12 grandchildren and 4 great grand children and that's how our love will live on for a long, long time."

Met this young boy during our shoot at Dharavi -
"What do you want to be when you grow up?"
"A doctor."
"Why?"
"My mother falls sick often...I want to become a doctor so that she never falls sick again."

"The entire concept of development has become so myopic today. For us development is an elaborate skyline and sophisticated technology...but it's very different for people who are a part of lesser developed areas. It is not the objective of every city or village to become a metro; what's more important to them is to be self- sufficient and so many of our villages and cities are.
I was working with farmers in a village in Gujarat when I realized that they're actually content with their lives. We were basically connecting these farmers to processing units where they could have access to open markets as opposed to being cheated by middlemen who take their margins. When I was talking to one such farmer who had just purchased a cycle, he said with a smile on his face -'progress to me is purchasing a motor cycle next year and a car the year after that.' - they have simple needs and a very happy life and we should stop trying to make them work towards anything else but that."

"We've both come out for our evening walk actually. These past 3 years she's been playing with me all day and I've gone back to being a child myself! She's growing up so fast -I can't believe she's going to Jr. Kg. already...what will I do once she goes to school all day?"

"Can you think of an experience that has touched you the most in these 30 years as a Social Worker?"
"A couple of months ago a 3 and a half year old street child lost her mother and a limb in a Railway accident. Her father was suffering from some illness, so he wasn't around much either. We created awareness via various news channels, about how her treatment  (which costed 20 lakhs) would help her walk again, with the help of an artificial leg. What happened next, left me overwhelmed...the money poured in, in large numbers from thousands of people across the country. We raised the amount in a week, her treatment was successful and this little girl today is walking and jumping around. Ofcourse, I was surprised by such an overwhelming response...but that's India for you. I don't think I've ever felt prouder of the place I come from and the large hearts that we, as Indians have."

"When I was just 4 months old, my family and I moved into the house next to Mrs. Iyer. As I grew older, I would come back from school and rush to her house...you can say that I used to live there most of the time. My friends and I would call her 'biscuit mummy' because she would make us sing 2 or 3 songs before spoiling us with biscuits. I lost my mother early on, but Mrs. Iyer never let me feel that loss. Her daughter and I grew up like family, and when her grandson refused to study --I used to teach him; infact I was the one who collected his 10th board result. When he suddenly passed away in a car crash at 27, I felt like I had lost my little brother. 
A few years later, my brother and I wanted to start out own business and were falling short of 2 lakh Rupees. Our own family - my mother's brothers who are so well off refused to give us a loan of even 50,000. That's when Mrs. Iyer and her daughter called me and said that after the death of her grandson, the company he worked for paid them a huge amount as compensation -- and that I should take whatever I need from that money. I had tears in my eyes, because I knew then that family isn't always about blood relations. In every sense, Mrs. Iyer has been my mother; my family and I miss her every single day."

Found this man sleeping underneath the shade of a tree, in this sweltering weather - completely at peace. A subtle but solid message to stop complaining about the heat...because things could be a lot worse.

"We went to Nepal to provide relief to the villages, which were inaccessible by cars. What started off as a Facebook Page (Nepali Relief) to collect resources went on to become a life changing experience.
We were able to generate real impact in 5 villages where no help had reached before us. 4 hour treks with 30kg bag packs, an immediate downhill climb with 10 villagers to pick up supplies. We were able to assess needs and distribute 3000 kgs of medical, food and lifestyle supplies. We treated over 300 patients and vaccinated 2 villages.
Ofcourse the last 2 days have been the craziest. 2 of us returned to one village to give them the supplies we had promised. Just as we brought the villagers down the hill, the earthquake hit (7.2), and we were at the epicenter. The road below my feet cracked open, the mountains on both sides gave way leading to major landslides, small apartments and shops on the road were crumbling as well. We found the Red Cross guys who were camping not very far away, and got picked up by the Chinese and Nepali Military 24 hours after.
You know there is a lot of chatter about how aid workers shouldn't rush to Nepal, and while there is some merit in what the articles say, my experiences tell me otherwise. If you want to help, and are ready to stay calm in the moment to absolute devastation, you should pack your bags and go. We operated out of a tiny village called Sakhuwa; on the China-Nepal highway. In the face of such calamity, they not only offered to let us stay, but they cooked for us, became our local guides and our friends. Without them none of this would have been possible. They were our angels and our guardians as much as we were theirs.
At the same time, I am not stupid. I knew before I left that this might be my last trip ever. Every aftershock felt like it might be my last. The last quake, well...even right now this wind that is creating a slight imbalance is seeming like a shaking earth. But, I do not regret anything...I would do this all over again.
Why?
Because I've seen the smile on the faces and the sparkle in the eyes of those helpless villagers and that's something I will carry with me to my grave."

"When I was 14, I was arrested 2 or 3 times for being a part of the Prabhat Pheris during Pre - Independence. We've been Lathi charged and taken to jail, but that never broke our spirit and the rest as they say is history. A few years after at the age of 21, I got married and that's when I moved to Bombay with my husband. I remember falling in love with the city the first time I came here, and he took me out on our 'first date' to Chowpatty beach. The best part about him is that he's always respected my choices even if it was something as small as my love for watching cricket - he didn't like the sport, so we've always had two TVs in the house and we would only talk during the breaks. I'm also very passionate about my city so I'm glued to all the Mumbai Indians matches, and even though he complained - when we won the league in 2013 he took me out to celebrate! That's the kind of person he was - he always put me before him and our love kept growing. Sometimes when my granddaughters came home and were wearing something nice, he would look at them smile and say, 'you know my wife would look much better in that outfit!' Even with age, we were always the love birds of the family…I really miss him."

"Givers get. Listen and listen carefully - What you give is the most important. Everything has a boomerang effect - if you give hate that's all you're going to get in return. Take the time out to give what you most want and see the results. Take it from me -- you can have all the money and luxuries in the world, but if you haven't given love and happiness, you can never be happy yourself."

"My boss and I got several extortion calls from Dawood and his men in the year 2002. I was the General Manager for a chain of restaurants across Bombay and in order to obtain the money from my boss quicker -- they wanted to make an example out of me. They have 'bugs' everywhere - 4 or 5 people who you have no way of tracing, working right under your nose. They knew everything about my family - from the name of my son's class teacher to where he played, what he ate and all about my wife. I went through hell during that period. My boss and I would take a different route back home everyday and I was in constant fear that the next minute might be my last. This one time, I made the mistake of cutting his call and he called me back and said - 'If you ever cut my call again--I will cut your balls in front of your children.' There are no words to describe the feeling of receiving those terrifying Unknown Number phone calls and being in stuck in the middle of his network that's so vast and penetrated that your closest friend or employee could be working for them. 
Thankfully, the nightmare ended when my boss paid a negotiated price. All the while I was thinking that I've only seen all this in movies -- threatening phone calls, dropping the money off at a dingy location (and his men picking it up as we drove off) and feeling helpless. But like everything else you have to move on so I changed my cell phone number, my profession as a hotelier and tried hard to just forget."

"My husband was the income earner in the family, but he never gave us any money, and spent it all on himself. Even when my son was born, he went on living his life the way he wanted and let us live penniless. It's been 14 years since I left him and came to Bombay to bring my life together, so that I could take care of my son, mother and sister. My son has a liver disease, so he constantly falls ill. I'm the only one that can earn for the sake of my loved ones, making it tougher on our family.... But it's still been a good 14 years because I've been happier here in Bombay than ever before. I've been able to find happiness in the smallest of things. I still remember when I ate "rasgula" for the first time, it was my happiest moment in a very long time!"
"And what keeps you going everyday?"
"My son. He needs me, and I need him."

"I've lived in Switzerland all my life with all the abundance in the world, but I felt like there was still something missing and that's when I decided to follow the path to find myself. I've lived in the Himalayas for a few years, travelled and found myself partially-- because when you're in something as magnificent as the universe you're always discovering and always creating. 
"What did you realize about yourself?"
"I've felt a divine presence, had visions and visualizations and have been able to create the world around me to discover that I am what's in me and that is the entire universe. The energy within you is the greatest -- And it's that realisation that will change your life."

"I used to be a farmer, but I didn't even have enough money to buy my family water...let alone manage an entire farm. I wasn't receiving any government aid, so I sold off my piece of land and did what most people with no money and a big dream do - I came to Bombay. I still remember my first ride in a taxi...I'd never sat in one and that journey changed my life because that's when I decided to never look back. 
I became a house cook and invested my money in my son's education...whose a graduate today! I also saved up enough money to buy myself a room in this city and even though it's small...it's mine and it's served me way more than a piece of land. The important thing I learned through everything is that everyone has problems and it's best to keep your issues to yourself -- because no one cares and no one's listening. In the end it's your battle to fight and what will matter is how you fought to survive it."

"I knew her since we were children, but I really got to know her when she moved to Bombay from Bihar and lived in my lane. I always knew I wanted to marry her, but how I asked her to marry me was very impulsive. I was a sailor and this one time, whilst I was dating her, my journey got cancelled. I don't know what got into me then but I just landed up at her door step, got on one knee and asked her to marry me! When she said 'yes', I said 'okay I don't want to wait any longer - we're getting married tomorrow!' Obviously, most places were booked out, given the short notice but we finally found a quaint little restaurant/hall near the Taj Mahal hotel which was available and it was just perfect because we had only our closest family and friends.
Unfortunately, our honeymoon was a really short one in Mussoorie, but you see I'm a sailor and we're as romantic as they get...so I took my bride to sea with me - and even though I was working - it was a 4 month long honeymoon with the only person I wanted to see the world with."

"The members of the home I work at told me that there was an earthquake in Nepal and I should contact my family in Nepal and check if they were okay. For the first 12 hours I couldn't get through anybody and those were the worst hours of my life. I was constantly thinking that I'm nothing without them and I don't know if you'll be able to imagine the fear, anxiety and helplessness that one goes through when their family is put in such a situation and you can't do anything about it. 
But God has been kind because finally when I got through my parents in my village they told me that thankfully they were all okay, but the walls of my home were cracked and could collapse anytime and the village was in complete shambles. They had no idea what was happening because there was barely any network or cable connection - so whatever little information they had was coming from me watching news back here in India. The worst part is, there could be hundreds of people still stuck underneath the rubble and we have no idea - all I know is that my family's safe...but I worry for my friends and brothers in my village.
When I spoke to them at length yesterday,they said that they were being taken care of by people from all over the world. Volunteers from America, India, Sri Lanka and many others had reached our remote village with food supplies and medicines. My brother said that had been stranded without food and at one point they thought that even though they survived the earthquake, they might die of starvation, if it wasn't for the help. No amount of words are enough to thank these angels...who have helped my people and taken care of my family...I wanted to be in their place, because i'd rather it be me then them and I'm overwhelmed to know that so many others feel the same way."

"I'm an ordinary driver, but I'm very satisfied. All of my three children are educated and working, and that was one of my biggest goals in life."
"What is your happiest memory?"
"I'm very happy when I eat my wife's parathas."
"And what advice would you give a large group of people?"
"Family is everything. Everytime you feel sad, think of them and it is my guarantee that you'll become happy - happy."

"One of the most under rated aspects of life is self conversation. What you say to yourself when you first open your eyes in the morning determines what your day and in the larger picture what your life will be like."
"What do you say to yourself as soon as you wake up?"
"Thank you."

"I felt the Earthquake when I was at the Kathmandu airport, waiting to board my flight. The first thing I saw was a young man, running through the gate's glass door which had jammed. Next thing I knew, an air conditioner fell on my back, but luckily I was wearing a backpack that saved me. Everyone at the airport spent the next few hours on the runway, constantly feeling tremors. We left the airport to go back to our hotel, but it had been badly affected...so we returned to the airport, where the Indian Embassy officials were systematically planning our evacuation."
"To everyone who has doubted the Indian Government my message is this - I wouldn't be alive today without the Indian Air  Force. Can you actually believe that, the real hindrance in the evacuation process were us Indian citizens who created complete chaos and showed no faith. The IAF officials were sending pregnant women, senior citizens and families with children on the first flights...but there were so many who were pushing to get ahead, offering bribes, screaming and fighting to leave first. 
Our Indian Air Force and the Military Personnel are the real heroes. They have carried luggage, senior citizens and wheel chairs on their back to make sure the flights left on time and this is in addition to swiftly removing resources from the flights that were coming in. 
I landed in Delhi at 12:00 that night and at 12:15 sharp the same flight left to get back more people...and those 5 flights kept relentlessly making their way up and down this route. 
When will we appreciate them? When will we realize that money cannot buy our way out of everything? and most importantly when will we realize that there are people who chose the option of staying back to help purely out of humanity, and no amount of money in the world could have bought that?"

"You may have a lot of friends but you can actually enjoy real friendship with only one type -- your type. Look at this old man here for example...I met him 20 years ago right here in this park and he's been stuck to me ever since!"

"When I was 14, my mother brought me here to Bombay from Lahore...and we missed the gruesome riots by a whisker! I attended college here in Bombay and that's where I met my soulmate at 16...and married him at 21. I lost him a few years ago, but we've had amazing memories together...all of which I fondly remember.
So that's my story. I'm an 82 year old woman who has lived a privileged life...where I've loved and been loved."

I was born with a physical disability and had no control over my bladder functions. I ended up with 'Trophic ulcer' by the age 16 and was left out of school classes, as my medical condition was considered a distraction to other students. I felt angry and helpless. And in that everyday anger, I felt determined to live through every moment for what must be fair. I found myself alone and in that loneliness, I learnt to become better. I learnt to believe in education and how it can transform life. I learnt to know that life's toughest problems are not solved through intelligence, but through endurance. 20 years ago, my mom lifted me two floors to make me sit in the class of school and that has changed my life. Education made all the difference as I went onto graduate from an Engineering college, work with an MNC and then to ISB for my MBA." 
"What would you like your message to be?"
 "The very least we can do, is to not just call people 'differently abled'. Start calling them by name, and then begin thinking that the infrastructure is actually disabling us. That way, we can begin working towards changing that infrastructure, than romanticizing disability into a non-existent special ability. Because, infrastructure and poverty is the true disability and calling a disabled person as 'differently abled' is like saying Monday is a 'special Sunday'...It makes no difference to the person's life whatsoever."

Humans of Bombay, it's the time to show our solidarity with the people of Nepal during these trying times. As much as they need our prayers, we need to do more. Here's how - CARE India is making survival kits to provide essentials for those affected and in dire need of basics. You can find more information by clicking on the link below. Words, hashtags and status updates, won't make the cut anymore; it's time to contribute and make a real difference.

http://ketto.org/humansofbombay

Image : Care India

"We've been cleaning these streets since the past decade. We live really far away from each other, so once we're done cleaning we talk for sometime and then go home. We live really difficult lives, so it's nice to have someone who cares and listens. I remember around 5 years ago, I was very upset because my son wasn't studying and he wanted to leave college when she said, 'don't worry - let me handle it.' She came home that day and spoke to him for about an hour outside. From that day onwards, he attended class everyday and today...he's working at a marketing agency and supports my whole family. When I asked her what she said to him she told me that she showed him a photo of her own son who passed away because of being unemployed and drinking all day. What's worse is that she didn't even bring it up until that day...but spoke about it only to make my son's life better."

"To me she was an angel. I've never known anyone to be as kind and loving as her...she made my house a home and gave me the best family. You know there's nothing that special about our story - we used to work in the same place, where we fell in love and got married. We travelled the world together, ate most of our meals at the same table, fought at times and had the most beautiful babies. So if you ask me, the only special part about our story is in the word 'together'...because that's the only thing that's lasted through the years."

"I've finally decided to become a journalist."
"What influenced your decision?"
"I've been told I talk too much...so I might as well make some money out of it!"

"I share a room with 12 other men and we pay 5000 Rupees all together for rent. It may sound like a small amount, but sometimes even paying that becomes difficult."
"Can you think of an experience that has touched you?"
"One day I was sitting outside our room, extremely upset because I didn't have enough money to travel back to my village to visit my family when one of the guys I sharing a room with came out and sat next to me. He had two cups of chai and one cigarette with him.   We started generally talking about life and family when I told him about my problem. I didn't ask for anything but he immediately called the rest of my roommates and within a few minutes collected the fare required for my travel. He said, 'If you don't take it from your brothers - who will you take it from?' I had tears in my eyes, because I thought these were just people I was sharing a space with...but in my time of need they didn't even hesitate once to give me their hard earned money."

The sweetest childhood memories are made of this - a grandfather animatedly telling his grandson stories on their balcony. When we asked if we could take a photograph, he said yes, and then said- 'look...that's a camera!'"

"I never wanted to get married since the beginning and I realized over time that the only reason everyone wanted me to get married was for society and to have children - but I didn't give in."
"What did you tell do?"
"Got a job where I had to pick up and drop over 30 children to school or classes and said, 'are you happy?...now I have so many children!"

"The other day a drunken man sat in my cab and started hurling abuses at me. I bore it and safely dropped him home at 4am, but I was very upset because as it is my job is so under appreciated. I was so cynical, I actually considered leaving and going back to Chandigarh. 
Just then, another customer got in and asked me to take him to the airport. Even though it was early in the morning, he asked me my name, where I came from and where I stay in Bombay. Half way through the journey he opened a box of sandwiches and offered me one and when he got out, he smiled and gave me 50 Rupees extra because 2 or 3 cab drivers before me had refused to take him. This is Bombay ; it has so many worlds within it that even if you want to leave it- you can't."

"I came to Bombay to get myself treated because since the past few months, I've been having a difficulty in breathing."
"What's your biggest struggle right now?"
"Being away from my wife. 65 years we've been married and she's still so caring that she's constantly calling me to ask if I'm okay."

I came to Bombay when I was 13 years old, hoping to support my ailing parents and two brothers in Jharkhand. I quickly got a job as a chaiwalla where I was serving tea at the shop as well as delivering tea to offices nearby. At the age of 15, one of the offices I was serving tea to offered me a job as an office boy - which I accepted. I realized soon that I didn't want to just serve other people coffee but actually wanted to work and make a difference. I decided to educate myself again, and even though I was working full time to support myself, I studied hard to clear my 10th standard examinations. 
I failed my first time, but passed the second time around. Likewise, I went on to clear my 12th examinations as well, and today I'm a web developer in that very company that hired me as an office boy. But the hunger is still alive…I want to complete my graduation and better my skills to become the best in the business. Today, I have a family of my own and everyday I work to make sure my son doesn't have to go through any struggle and my wife get's everything in the world! I came here for family, and I've made it this far for family as well."
Caught this one closely examining several packets of milk at 7 in the morning and also heard him saying 'yummy' several times. Who said mornings have to be grumpy?!

"I was really stressed before my Economics paper, when my blood sugar dropped to a really low level. I collapsed and even my calcium levels dropped as a result - all my muscles stiffened and I couldn't breathe. I don't remember much else, except waking up in a hospital bed, glad to be alive. What was all the stress for? One paper that would define my life in what way? I decided then and there that I just wanted peace and I wouldn't let any exam, job or promotion get in the way of my happiness. Nothing in life should stress you out to the point that you can't breathe."

"I remember playing Gully-cricket since I was really young. Over time, I used to play only because everyone else was playing. It may sound trivial, but back then it was difficult to be one of the only few boys who preferred Football to Cricket...we were left out of almost all plans. It doesn't really matter now though..I'm here to play football with my company's team, but for the sake of young boys who want to explore different sports the stereotype of 'cricket is religion' needs to change."

"I think, art allows exploration into every part of the mind. We mentally create two realms of real and unreal. Real is everything which is universally agreed upon as 'reality'. Fantasy is a result of things like imagination, faith, hope, love...their existence is always brought into question because of their abstract nature. However art loses these realms and I find the freedom to delve into every part of myself and express it without fear of bumping into some ridiculous boundary.
And that's also why art is so therapeutic. The more you explore the 'self', the better you are able to understand and empathize with the world around you. Over the years, I've grown a tenfold because of art. It sounds cheesy and untrue but I think if you are a part of something which dictates free thought and free expression, you automatically become more observant. And that's what growth is, it's the constant realization of the world around you."

"What has been your biggest struggle?"
"Seeing my children only twice a year - their childhood passed me by without even realizing."

"I first met him when as a young girl my friends and I used to go to play in his building. Everyone found him really good looking, but as soon as they found out he was deaf and dumb they would lose interest. When we first communicated through signs, we expressed our love for one another and I assured him that I would marry no one but him. We would walk on the beach for hours, where he would try to hold my hand and I would shy away! However, my parents didn't approve of my decision to be with him and after 7 long years of trying to convince them, I gave up and decided that I couldn't wait any longer. My husband's mama gave me away, because my parents didn't attend my own wedding. Everyone asked me, how we would survive if he wasn't earning but he shut everyone up when he got a job at a radio factory. He used to work really hard to support us and he even expanded to sales of radio covers and spare parts. 
Over time, I got so used to conversing in signs that often I would go days without speaking and I liked it like that because I felt we understood each other better that way. We had 6 beautiful children, all of whom he loved and pampered. There were a few years in between when his factory shut down and we were facing some troubles – but my daughters began giving tuitions to young children to keep us secure and even those values they've learnt from him. He really had the best heart. Even after retirement he would go to the Gurudwara and distribute sweets, take care of other people's children while they took a dip in the water and he was just so full of love. I really miss him everyday. He was the best thing that happened to me and every year on his birthday I make sure I go to the school of the deaf and dumb to speak to the children about him and his 'normal' life. Given the chance, in every life I'd choose him – the best husband, the best father and the best person."

"What has been your biggest achievement till now?"
"My 18 year old son wanted to quit studying to get a job because I'm a single mother and I convinced him not to."

"My husband and I were in our living room, chatting and eating dinner when all of a sudden he started breathing really heavily and succumbed to a heart attack. In 2 minutes my entire life turned around - losing my partner was the worst thing that happened to me and I had to slip into his shoes as the man of the house. My in-laws said that if their son was no more, my sons and I were not their responsibility anymore and I realized early that I would have  to support them financially on my own.
I began cooking at various houses, conducting stitching classes for young girls and making ends meet. There was a time where I used to work close to 13 hours a day, but I don't regret any of it because I did it for my family. 18 years ago I began my job as a nurse, looking after new born babies. I feel like God took away my love from me very early but has returned it ten fold through all the families i've worked with. I'm 65 today and have no reason to work because my sons support me, but I do it because I love working and getting as much love as I can, to feel closer to my husband."

"Modi Ji has finally made our dream come true. 16 years I've been cleaning these streets, and nobody seemed to care about not littering but after Swachh Bharat, there's a small change atleast. Soon, it'll completely change...ab bade sahab ne kahaa hai, toh karna toh padega!"

"What was the happiest moment of your life?"
"It was 1971 and I was in my village in Rajasthan. We were facing a drought for close to 3 years and one evening it finally rained."

"We broke up 7 months ago because her parents wanted her to focus on her career. We're both CA students, which is why they wanted us to end it. I met her father to try and convince him but he said that they couldn't allow it until she finished her MBA.  She couldn't say much because she was already feeling guilty about switching fields from Engineering to CA and didn't want to upset her parents more. They made her block my calls, Facebook and Whatsapp. I've tried to get in touch with her through her friends but it hasn't worked. She's the love of my life and I don't know what to do. No matter how much I try to distract myself with work and studying – she's always on my subconscious mind. People have said I'll get over it with time, but I don't want to get over it. Hopefully she'll read this and somehow get in touch with me. 
"What do you want to say to her?"
"Honestly, I haven't spoken to her in 7 months…I just want to know how she's doing and if she's okay."

"I was married at the age of 18 and my son was born when I was 19. We were both so young that it felt like we were growing up together. He was adjusting to this new world, and I was adjusting to the new life he gave me, and somehow we made it through this journey together...as friends."

"My only advice would be to listen. There's constant noise around us, but if you really pay attention - all the answers are already there. Listen to what everyone has to say with a smile on your face, filter out the nonsense, and then listen to your gut based on what's left...it'll never let you down."

This was probably one of the most heart warming moments from our shoot at Dharavi. Amidst the heat and lack of resources, this little girl looked up at me, smiled and said - 'Didi, pani?'. I guess it's because she's from one of the most hospitable places I've been to in the city and it was so overwhelming to have this little girl offer me water from her own glass, purely out of kindness.

"I'm originally from Gujarat, but like every other man with dreams, I thought, 'Bombay is the place to make it big' and that's when I came to the city - with one suitcase and a big dream. I've had a number of jobs and I've succeeded at most of them, but in the end I realized that I didn't like the struggle. I finally used all of my savings to buy a plot of land in Gujarat and I'm moving back. It's a big space - I even have my own backyard! Overtime, I guess I figured that it's okay to not 'make' it the way you planned sometimes. For right now, I'm happy and I'd pick these happy days over the struggling days on every given occasion."

"I ran away from my home in Bihar when I was 10 years old because there was no 'spare' money for me to buy a pen for school. After working in Delhi at a Leather workshop for a few months, I reached Bombay and moved into Dharavi where I shared a room with a few village boys and worked at a leather factory. I was always entrepreneurial, so on weekends I would make mobile covers and sell them at VT station. I painfully saved Rs. 25,000, but like so many in Bombay I got conned of the money and chased the culprit to Bangalore – all in vain. I started doing odd jobs in Bangalore and over time made a friend, Jacob. He took me to Salsa class one day and that decision changed my life – I fell in love with dance. 
When I finally returned to Bombay, I continued working at the labor factory, but began attending Sandip sir's dance classes (after he agreed to let me pay the fees in installments.) One day, Sandip Sir asked me if I could make 'dancing shoes' for him – which back in 2000 were only available abroad. I said,  'yes, let me try' and that's when this dream turned into reality for me. Obviously the first few pairs were disastrous, but I saw a market for it and what's more...I realized that I had a great advantage. I had easy access to all the raw materials needed, because they were all available in Dharavi itself. I quit my job in 2005 and started making professional dancing shoes full time. By 2007, I bought this small space in Dharavi, which is my workshop and started supplying my shoes all over…infact my shoes have been worn by all of Bollywood including Priyanka Chopra and Hrithik Roshan. 
Today, I make enough money to support my brothers who are in school and it's my dream to see them fully educated. As for me, I can't help but smile. Who knew a 'run away' boy from Bihar could start making shoes for movie actors? And I owe it all to Dharavi…for those who aren't born with a golden spoon, it's the only place that allows people like us to have a dream."

"Who do you think will win, India or Australia?"
"India...because Maxwell cannot play our short ball or our bouncers."
"Just that?"
"No, also because either we will score 350 and above or we'll chase down anything below that...actually we can chase down 400 also!"

"I've worked as a nurse all my life. For the last few years, I had been working as a 'house nurse' to an 80 year old man. Over the years, we ended up becoming great friends. We used to talk to one another about our lives, experiences and everything else. He was also aware that I had a knee problem, so if he saw that I was resting in the afternoon and he needed something - he wouldn't wake me up...he would get it himself, even though he was in discomfort.
One day, on my way back from work I felt an unbearable pain in my knees and I had to be admitted to Hinduja hospital - I was on bed rest for a week after. Once I was discharged, I got home and called his house to find out how he was keeping and his daughter told me he had passed away. She told me that he repeatedly asked about me when I didn't go to work and kept saying that he was worried about my health...his body couldn't handle the anxiety and he succumbed to a heart attack. I decided to retire after because I didn't just lose a patient, I lost a friend and as much as I have nursed him...he's taken care of me too."

"What advice would you give to a large group of people?"
"Will they listen? I don't think so, but I'll give it a go. To everyone out there who's killing themselves to get that promotion, or trying to make it so big that they can afford anything materialistic my message is this - stop. Just stop feeling incomplete over 'things' or 'positions' you cannot have. Even the richest of people will tell you that it doesn't matter. Ask yourself bigger questions - 'have I changed someone's life for the better?', 'In my time here, have I been kind to those around me, strangers or anything alive?'...'have I been a good human'?"

"We live in the same building - she lives on the 3rd floor and I live on the 4th - that's how we first met 45 years ago and we've been friends ever since. When we were younger we would always get each other excited about trying new things - if any new restaurant opened or a new movie released, we would be the first two to go. It's hard to keep that up now, but still whenever we get the car we try to atleast go to different places for an evening walk!"
"What's the best memory you've had with each other?"
"I think it was a few days after my husband passed away and I was sitting at home alone, when she came in with a tray full of my favorite food. She sat with me for hours after eating, talking and just giving me company. I'll never forget that day, because at a time when I felt lost, she made me feel like I wasn't in it alone."

"My father was a class 4 servant in the high court. We both had a common dream of me becoming a lawyer and my happiest day was when I fought my first case in court, and he was there to watch."
"And when were you the saddest?"
"When my lover left me...I mean such things happen in college life but it's been 13 years since it happened and I'm still a bachelor. Maybe there's no such thing as a second love?"
"I don't know where my childhood went. I'm a mother of 2 at 23 - Sometime's I feel like I'm still a child myself, but at other times I feel like I'm already 50."

"Art has always been a passion for me and when I started these hobby classes I didn't see it so much as a business, as I did a way to carry my passion forward. Children come here to 'live art' as opposed to 'learning it'...they can paint the walls, splash colors on the floor and use any material they like to experiment. All our lives we've been taught to stay within the lines - but here there are no lines; they can paint the sky black and we will still encourage it. We live by the rule that art is not about copy- pasting someone else's work - it's about creation and we're trying everyday to keep the creativity and that 'true' sense of art alive."

"My family is back in my village, but every once in a while I like to travel and see different places. I sleep on the streets, eat the local food and make new friends wherever I go...all on foot. I visit Bombay often, because I find it's the easiest place to earn quick money. Whenever I come here, I work at a temple nearby mostly to keep the holy fire going (dhup). A lot of people ask me how I'm allowed to do this, because I'm Muslim...but no one's ever had a problem with it and neither have I - so why should anyone else worry?"

"I'm reading about a small show Bob Dylan was singing at, where people weren't really paying attention to him and barely anyone knew him - when Gorgeous George a famous wrestler went up to him and randomly said, 'you're making this thing come alive!' and that was the turning point in Dylan's life. He said - 'Sometimes that's all it takes, the kind of recognition when you're doing the thing for the thing's sake and you're onto something but nobody recognizes it yet.' 
I read these words at the perfect time because even though I'm just an Economics student I feel like there is an ulterior motive for me. I'm going to specialize at Research in the Indian Economy and even though not many people believe research can help, I feel like I'm onto the right thing to make a difference...even though nobody recognizes it yet."
