"The doctor gave her 48 hours at most to survive after her birth but here she is healthy at 4 years old. Ofcourse, she has her shortcomings - she frequently gets epileptic attacks and is lagging behind a little at school but that's okay...she's still normal - not 'mentally retarded' as some refer to her. I sometimes wonder how she deals with all of this herself - we just found out a few weeks ago that she's blind in her right eye but she's taken that in her stride as well."
"How have you dealt with all this?"
"I'm a mother - she's the best thing that's ever happened to me. She's always so happy that I have nothing to be afraid of...she is my biggest strength and pride and I'm so happy to just have her."

"Even though I never went to school, from a very young age, my grandfather taught me how to make pots. For every pot I made, he would reward me with a marble ball and say - 'it's good to have a skill, no matter what the skill is.' After I got married and moved to Bombay, I discovered quickly that my husband was a drunk and whatever money he spent from tailoring he spent on alcohol. That's when I started this business 20 years ago...I never thought that a simple, uneducated village girl could make a life for herself - but yet here I am running my own business, supporting my children and most importantly...being my own boss!"

"One day I was bored and I decided to make up this whole story about 'Girlfriends day'. I basically told my boyfriend it was Girlfriends day and how I was so upset that he had forgotten it...and a few hours later he showed up at my doorstep with 8 red roses!"

"When I lost my mother I didn't just lose a parent - I lost my conscience keeper, my sense of balance and my best friend. When you ask me how I've dealt with it…I can only say that I'm still dealing with it everyday. There's no dealing with something like that once and for all. She was such a strong personality that everyday I try to channelize my energy in the way she would have liked me to. I know she's watching over me, so I try my best to make sure she's proud of who I'm becoming. Even in the midst of her cancer treatment she insisted that I go back to college to complete my senior year, and my brother begins shooting for his first film - because that's the kind of woman she was. We always came before everything else for her and she didn't want us to put anything on hold because of her illness. 
The hardest part I guess was coming to a home without her - because for me home was where my mother was…and now home is wherever my brother is. Even without being here she's made me so strong. I'm 5'11, strong, independent and nowhere close to being a damsel in distress. It's because of her, that I don't need anyone to save me...I already have myself for that."

"I can't believe I'm done with 5 years of college. I still remember the first day I came here, I looked around at this big beautiful campus and thought to myself- 'I have to make the most of every minute at  this place'...and I did!"

"My husband's back in my village and he can't work a lot because of an accident he had a few years ago. I came to Bombay with my grand daughter who also works as a housemaid here...if she can do it, why can't I? I love my husband very much - for the first half of our 55 years together he supported me, and now its my turn to take care of him. I'm 76 and working hard...and it's paying off! I'm finally going back to my village to see my husband in a months time, after 2 full years!"

"She understands that she comes from a family of limited means.She knows the value of everything we give her and she knows the importance of education. She never complaints about going to school, and at such a young age she's so responsible. She loves learning new words and whenever we ask her what she wants to become she smiles and says, 'English'!"
"I didn't know it was possible to love someone who isn't even born yet this much...can you believe there are two hearts beating inside me right now?"

"I've come to Bombay for an exchange programme from Malaga. My school took us to Dhobi Ghat one morning, and it left me feeling so sad looking at the conditions they have to work in...Ive never seen anything like it. I guess it's because they didn't receive a proper education, but I feel like things are changing because I've seen so many public schools, filled with children eager to learn. The funny part is, I was warned about the traffic on the streets before coming to India, but never the difficulty people have to face with basic education and living conditions. They also never warned me about how nice the people are, despite all of that. Bombay is what it is because of its people."

"I work with the United Nations in the Department of Peacekeeping Operations. Over time, I feel like people expect country negotiations and large organizations to restore peace in the world...but it takes everybody to put in their small bit to see a change. How can we fight 'wars' for 'peace'? When will we realize that weapons cannot drive out hatred...only love and compassion for human life can do that."

"I came to India four months ago to volunteer with Save the Children. The whole experience of being in a place like India has been surreal. It's a difficult place to adjust to in the beginning - trying to make my way around with language barriers and wondering if I'm getting ripped off...but I've loved every second of it. I never thought I'd say this but I'm going to miss the noise and the madness of this city when I go back to Spain."
"What will you miss the most?"
"Definitely the people - everyone here is so kind and full of emotions...it's like nothing I've experienced before. Just a few weeks ago at the center, I girl I was working with said to me, 'I wish you were my mother' and I was so touched - it's hard to put these kind of emotions into words."
"So how are you feeling about leaving India?"
"I'm leaving for now, but I'll be back! There's no way I can say Goodbye to this place forever...it's touched me enough for me to keep coming back."

"My brother has Down's syndrome, but in his head he's as normal as
everyone else- It's society's reaction towards him or some of the
things he does which makes him believe otherwise. If he meets you,
he'll become your friend and hug you…express his love for you; but so many people have frowned upon that. I don't know when people will understand that he's 'special' not 'retarded'. Just the other day we were at our gym and he was working out like any of us, but because he dropped something this woman turned around and said 'who let this mad man into the gym?' He had absolutely no reaction until my sister and I fought with that woman. That's when he started crying because he thought he had gotten us into trouble. That's the kind of person he is - he loves selflessly without expecting anything in return. His happiness doesn't depend on anything materialistic but only on the love he gets and returns 10 folds...and that's something us 'normal' people can definitely learn from him."

"I work in Bombay as a driver, but my family's back in my village in Bihar."
"How often do you speak with your wife?"
"Every other day and whenever I speak to her, she only asks me one question..."
"What's that?"
"Have you met ShahRukh Khan yet?"

"I have an older son and my daughter here's 5 months old."
"What's the best part about having a daughter?"
"Honestly...the clothes! I'm just loving that I can finally play dress up!"

"What did you want to be when you were a child?"
"I wanted to be a good person and I feel like I'm still struggling with that. I used to think that the actions of others makes me do bad things, but now I know that it's me. Nobody cares about the back story - there's no justification for hurting someone else in anyway and the only way to be better is to stop playing the blame game and start with yourself. Hurting others because you've been hurt is a vicious cycle and we all need to stop being a part of it."

"We met 10 years ago and we were friends for a while after. I was the one who asked him out actually...his reaction to which was - 'are you joking?'"
"What's the best part about your relationship ?"
"I don't want to sound cheesy by saying I married my best friend...but it's true!"

"A few days ago, a passenger sat in my cab and started chatting with me. He asked me about my life, my family, my origins and my beliefs.   While driving I told him I knew a shorter route and when I got him there faster than normal, he said to me while getting out of the cab- 'You're doing a great job - you know so many short cuts...thank you.' For the first time I felt like someone cared about my life and I wasn't just a driver...it felt so good to just hear the words, 'Thank you.'"

"On October 12th, 1976 a Madras bound Indian Airline plane caught fire on one of its wings and there was panic everywhere because this burning flight was flying low, being a threat to residential areas. It crashed right before landing and I rushed to the site with my servant and 2 colleagues to attend to patients.  All 96 patients died that night, but the efforts of everyone trying to look for life was commendable. I'll never forget the sight I saw – severed heads, limbs and bodies with no skin. The next day, all the papers told the story of how we 'bravely' rushed to save lives and assist the rescue mission but 1 week later a police party came to my clinic because there was a complaint lodged against me entering a 'restricted area' (the airport runway) without police permission. That's when I realized, that we have forgotten basic Humanity because even an effort to save lives could be criticized and belittled by the authorities."
"If you could give one piece of advice to a large group of people, what would it be?" 
"Overcome obstacles, don't worry too much, always have a good night's sleep and don't harm others for your personal gain. Eventually, we'll all die; but it's how much we've done for others that will ultimately leave our mark on the world."
"Whenever I'm angry, all he has to do is come and say, 'mumma I love you' and I'll melt...every single time!"

"It was around 7:30 pm, at rush hour when I got off at Dadar station. I was the last one to get off the coach when all of a sudden, I felt someone touching me inappropriately and groping me. When I turned back, I saw this boy hastily getting into the ladies coach. I knew it was him, because when I started screaming, asking the other ladies to catch him, he was trying to escape through the other entrance. Since nobody acted, my instincts took over, and out of the anger I got back in the coach and slapped him hard. I was furious because he had the audacity to touch me and just walk away. I kept slapping him and kicking him and he didn't resist. He started weeping and on seeing that, one of the ladies said -  "Arre jaane do, kitna maarogi?"(Let him go, how much will you hit him?)
I was surprised and angry at the same time and that's when I asked her, 'What if it would have been you or your daughter? Would she react the same way? Today, he has dared to grope; tomorrow, he'll have the guts to rape -if he isn't taught a lesson.'
That's when she kept quiet and other ladies begun verbally supporting me, asking me to hand him over to the cops.
I had to wait till Sion station to get him off and I thought the ladies who were supporting me, would help me, but when I turned back to see if anyone was with me - sadly, there was no one.
But I had made up my mind that I wouldn't let him go so easily. So, I held him by the collar and took him to the police station. There, I shamelessly explained whatever happened. The cops themselves felt disgusted. They slapped him too, but after that they told me that they have taken my compliant, because it would be too much of a hassle to pursue this case, since he was a juvenile (this wasn't verified by the cops). They told me they'll keep in the station for a day or two and that it should be enough to teach him a lesson. There was already too much on my mind, so I just left. But before leaving, they told me that I could speak to him. So, I slapped him one last time, made him apologize and left – not for me but for the thousands of women like me who face this kind of shit everyday and are either too scared to voice their frustration or have to fight for themselves…like I had to."

"At 43 I decided to stop working for others and start working for myself and it has been the best decision of my life. I wake up with a passion I never had before - and it makes me want to get up and build my dream."
"What's the one thing this experience has taught you?"
"It's never too late."

"We often think about love as loving another person and we think of Valentine's day as a day for that person. But from my point of view, if we are going to celebrate love then we have to start by loving ourselves. Why can't we use this day, to find what we most love about ourselves? A successful relationship is only built on mutual admiration and respect, if we don't love ourselves how can we expect someone else to love us?
How wrong is it for a woman to expect a man to build the world she wants, rather than creating it herself? The day we learn to be happy with ourselves, we will know if the person we are looking for is the right one for us or if we are just looking to fill a vacancy in our hearts."

"I first met her when she attended my Yoga class, where I was a senior trainer. Over time we both would end up reaching the class a few minutes early, so that we could spend time with each other. A few weeks later, we began dating and we've been together ever since. There have been ups and downs though - she's from Chennai and I'm from Haryana and my parents have refused to accept our relationship...but I know I want to marry her. I'm trying to start my independent classes to support us in the future. It's difficult to survive in a place like Bombay, without your parents support but I know that together we'll make it work."

"When I came here from my village, I wanted to be a Stenographer and work my way up in a corporate firm. Things don't always work out though."
"What have your experiences taught you?"
"There's no point getting upset when things don't go according to plan and sometimes it doesn't work out for the best. I may not be working at a corporate firm today, but I'm a free man with a loving family and friends who have supported me through some of the worst times. Dreams can change but people don't - and those who support you through that journey are more important than that dream itself."

"I was born and brought up in a small Iranian village where girls weren't given much freedom. We came to Pune, India one summer to visit my father's sister and that's when I met him for the first time - his family and our family were neighbors..." 
"And then she started hitting on me!"
"He's just fooling around - but yes we fell in love. The funny part is we couldn't communicate much because I didn't know proper English or Hindi, and he didn't know how to speak Persian. We used to just spend hours together, trying to understand what the other was trying to say. We ended up taking language classes together - but if you ask me you don't really need words to feel the love. Even through the communication barriers, I felt strongly for him because he was giving me so much love and respect - that as girls we never received back in my village. Somethings are written in your destiny and I feel like he was written in my life, infact for many lives to come - because we're connected at a much higher level and in all my lifetimes I only want him."
"We need to look inside to find peace. As humans, we suffer because we love things and use people. We need to start loving people and using things to actually understand peace and happiness."

"Why do we fight? 2 out of 3 of us here were born in Pakistan and moved here before partition, but not once do we feel like we don't belong here. God has made us all, so why can't we understand that we're all one? Religion, caste and land are all man made divisions. We all see the sun, moon and stars, but have we started wars to claim that they belong to us? We just need to breathe, thank God that he created us and do one more thing as a matter of urgency."
"What is that?"
"We need to stop selling weapons to idiots - slowly but surely they will destroy our world."

"Are you two dating?"
"No..."
"So you guys are friends then?"
"Not exactly...it's something in between I guess."

"I used to be 101 Kilos. When I first came to Bombay from Muradabad, I was nervous to even go to college because I felt so out of place. I still remember, this one guy from college once said, 'There's no future for fat people' and that's what really pushed me to lose weight just to show him that weight is temporary - it can be lost, but it's what's on the inside that matters. Today, I'm probably fitter than him but I haven't once judged him or tried to pull him down...and I think that in itself proves the difference."
"Should I say something deep? Actually there's nothing deep about me, hold on let me just google a Batman quote."

"I lost my best friend in a motorbike accident around a year ago. It was the most trying time of my life not only because I miss him but also because of all the things I never told him when he was here. I guess, somewhere we all take things for granted."
"What would you tell him if he were here?"
"I'm proud of you, bro."

"After growing up all over the world, I lived in Delhi for 6 years where I was a backup dancer for various indie pop artists. I first came to Bombay back in the year 2000, to visit a friend, completely randomly - and I fell in love with this city. At 22, I withdrew all my savings and decided to move to Bombay with Rs. 40,000 in my bank account, 2 suitcases and a big dream. I've had my share of struggles where at one point I was sharing an apartment with 6 girls and a pigeon – all because that was the only rent I could afford. I feel like I've always pursued the things that I'm passionate about, whether it was my love for writing in my column, or my love for connecting with people through my 9 years in radio. 
Where I am today hasn't been easy - I've worked 2, sometimes 3 jobs all at once but the difference is I've loved every minute of it. When I finally decided to start blogging, I had only one purpose – to show a side of Bombay that not many people knew existed. Growing up abroad, people would ask me, 'do you own an elephant?' That's how clueless they were about life in India (but boy wouldn't it be cool to own an elephant!) I know Bombay is also home to massive slums, and we have our share of suffering and poverty - but that's not the only thing that defines Bombay and I wanted to show the world what else we have to offer. In the end, the way I look at it, we're only here for a short time. What really matters is how we loved. From loving what we do, to loving others around us, it's the only thing that makes everything worth it."

"My parents passed away when I was 8 years old and I came to Bombay with a relative of mine with 2 pairs of clothes and no money. People are always saying that child labour is horrible, but the only reason I'm alive today is because of that family who gave me work and a chance to survive. They gave me 3 meals a day, a roof over my head and most importantly made me feel like I wasn't alone. My Saheb even partly paid for my wedding...I feel like this family was God sent for someone like me. I really believe that Allah, God, Jesus are all one and in so many ways they take a human form - they're all around us. How else do you think a lost, uneducated 8 year old girl could have children and grandchildren who are all educated and working? There is a higher force, not necessarily in a temple or a mosque - but within us as humans and our tremendous capacity to give strength to other humans when they most need it."

"In your 40 years of friendship, what has been your happiest time?"
"We were pretty happy last evening only...good weather, whiskey and no wives around!"

"I moved to Bombay from New York because I wanted to experience a different culture. I was working as photographer for an NGO when I first came here and even though I didn't know anyone - I fell in love with this place. A few months after I moved, I was having a small birthday dinner at my neighbors place with a few close friends. After a while, It got a little stuffy so I went to the kitchen window to get some air when I saw these 3 boys playing playstation, through the window in the building across mine. The building was like 5 feet away - they could hear me from where I was standing and by that point I was a few drinks back so I asked them if they wanted to join us and they agreed! I became great friends with one of those 3 boys and 8 months later we began dating...but as luck would have it both our Visas expired and he had to return to Iran, while I had to go back to New York. 
I haven't seen him since the past 8 months and it's really hard because both our nations are hostile towards one another which makes it difficult to travel - but we're making it work. I mean, you have friends that live away but your friendship doesn't end right? Which is why it was so important that we were friends before dating. So now, Bombay is a neutral territory where we can actually meet and I'm waiting here for him...I guess it's the memory of having been together which gives us the patience and the hope of seeing each other again which makes our love that much stronger."

"She works as a security guard at the mall where I sell cosmetics. Everyone in my department really disliked her because she was very strict about timings and wouldn't let us in if we were over 15 minutes late. This one day, I had to rush home because of an emergency, but no one supported me in front of my manager, who thought it was just an excuse. At that point, only she stood up for me and said that I wouldn't lie about a family emergency...and I should be allowed to go. I was shocked because for the longest time, we used to make fun of her, say things behind her back but when the time came, she was the only one who spoke up for me. I guess that's when I realized that we judge people too quickly, and sometimes the people who you think so negatively about aren't so bad afterall."

"If you could change one thing about India, what would it be?"
"The lack of opportunity. I've been cutting hair since I was 15 and i'm 70 now, but this is all I've known. It's almost like it's my fault that I was born into a family with lesser means who couldn't afford to educate me. If I just had the opportunity to study, my life would have been so different. Well, my time has gone, but I hope for the future, for the children who are born like me into less affording families that there is atleast an opportunity to turn life around...that atleast they're given a chance for a better life."

"My husband wasn't keeping too well, but he was still working to make ends meet. Finally, I put my foot down and asked him to quit his job and I started working full time to make up for that. Other people in our neighborhood laugh at him because of this, but I keep telling him that there's nothing to be ashamed. We have to take care of each other in our best and worst times and it's not always the man who has to be strong and earn. I love him and respect him, and it gives me happiness to work for our future and family."
"I have everything I need on me. I don't believe in unnecessary baggage - simple needs, simple life."

"What do you want to be when you grow up?"
"A soldier!"
"A doctor!"
"And why?"
"We'll go together Didi - I'll fight the war and he'll take care of me!"

"I was diagnosed with stage 1 Hodgkins Lymphoma, a type of cancer right before my 12th grade board exams. I asked my doctor if I could give my exams before starting Chemo and he agreed. I went through 6 Chemo sessions and radiations after and was fully cured a few months later. I however relapsed in 2013 with Non- Hodgkins Lymphoma, which was rare because it was a different type of cancer all together, but I fought it with a stem cell transplant where I was in isolation for 30 days. 
Initially, I used to be very upset because of the hair loss, but eventually in the light of bigger things that seems so small –I feel so lucky to be alive! There are so many children younger than me who are going through the same thing and I feel like this experience has brought me so much perspective. I'm literally always happy, living every second to the maximum and never stressing the little things. It's funny because it took not one but two life threatening experiences to make me realize how lucky I am and how beautiful life really is."
"I first met her when we were sitting in our examination hall, and I looked over to her for some multiple choice answers...and she gave them to me!"

"I've tried killing myself on multiple occasions. I'm not proud of it, but there have been times when I didn't see any other way out. I feel bad looking at my children sleeping on the street everyday - without proper food and no education. My husband works but earns only enough to feed us two meals...It's so difficult to survive. I want to work as a house maid, I want to earn, I want to be strong for my children...I want to send them to boarding school where they can escape from this life. Help me, please."

"I have 3 sons, 3 daughters, 3 son-in-laws and 32 grandchildren, but not one of them fends for me and that's okay, because I look at it as a good thing because I'm traveling and still discovering things about life. I move around with a small bag and wait for each day to unfold and take its course - people don't always like unpredictability, but even at this age that's what keeps me alive and going."

"At 16, my parents made me meet this boy for marriage, and I felt like we got along so I said yes. We moved to Bombay soon after, where he was working at a hotel, and I was working part time at his boss's house, as a house maid. He's never stopped me from working, because I've always maintained that if he can work, so can I. When I had to travel 2 hours to reach my new job, he asked me, 'how will a village girl travel so far by herself?' - I just said that if he has understood how to use the bus, even I could understand. I love working in this city and I feel like my life is so much better than when I was in my village. I have a purpose here as well. Before leaving, my mother told me that my in-laws are asking for more money as dowry...I left asking her not to worry. I want to buy a fridge, TV and cupboard for them, with my own money to prove that I can more than provide for them, and that I went to the city and achieved something for myself."

"When I was just 15 years old, my aunt brought me to Bombay under the pretext of finding me a job, but instead she made me meet a boy and his family for an arranged marriage and within 3 days - I was married off to him! A few months into the marriage, I found out he was already married to another woman, who was currently staying at her mothers house; but I was already pregnant by then and delivered my daughter at the age of 16. For 3 years after that my mother in law would insist I work in the scorching sun on their piece of farmland in Baramati, and when I used to resist I would get beaten up and instead of protecting me, my husband used to join in and hit me as well. This continued till the age of 19 when I delivered my baby boy - but one day he came home and threatened to hit my children as well. That day, I walked out of the house and never looked back. I left both my children with my mother in Roha and came back to Bombay to work and earn money for them. I earn from working in different houses in Bombay and send almost all the money back to my mother, for my children. I'm finally getting a legal separation as well, and I've never felt more free and independent. I'll work all my life to feed my children, but I'll never go back to him again."

"When my father came to India from Lahore in 1944, he set up a lingerie store which a lot of conservatives found 'unethical', in those times. I grew up to manage the store with my father, who was always giving me advice. One of the most important things he's told me is, 'People will always create differences - whether about money, religion, gender or social standing; but it is upto us to rise above these 'self created' rules and look at the bigger picture .We need to do what we have to do and create our own lives, exactly the way we want it - keeping in mind that ultimately we're all human and no amount of differences can change that.''"
"Yesterday my teacher was shouting at me because I was talking in class, but then they started laughing, so even I started laughing and we all ended up getting thrown out of class!"

"At 19, my parents wanted me to marry a boy from the US, but I wasn't sure if I would get along with him – so I refused. I took a risk and left Rajkot for Bombay, telling my parents that I would only come back home once I was married. I ended up marrying a boy of my choice, a doctor - and that was the best decision of my life. Back then, he had a large group of friends who were all primarily in the medical field, so before attending any party I would read up about 2-3 subjects and speak about them there and then everyone would tell him, 'she's so well read!', and that would be the highlight of my night!"
"What advice would you give people?"
I've reached a stage in my life where I feel like I've spoken enough  and have finally understood the power of listening. I sit at family dinners and listen to my children and grandchildren because I think there's a lot to learn from the new generation.
I can now use Whatsapp and Facetime to keep in touch with my family wherever they travel and this is something I've learnt by listening to my grandchildren.  So, if I have one piece of advice it is to speak less and listen more, because the world is always full of great things to learn...even at my age!"

"I moved to Nagpur after my marriage, but the rest of my family is here in Bombay. She's my aunt and I really miss her, so I come here to visit her every year. She understands me more than anyone else, which is why we never run out of things to say to one another. One of our favorite things to do is walk for hours on Marine Drive...just chatting like old times."
"What's the best part about her?"
"There's no one in the world who can make better fish curry...she makes it with so much love - it just transports me back to my childhood!"

"After my daughter passed away a few years ago, I was very upset for a long time. I wasn't working back then, so the more I stayed at home; the more upset I got over time. Finally, my husband pushed me into getting out of the house. Since 5 years, he catches the fish and I clean them and come here to sell. We have a proper partnership, where I get some money from whatever I sell for my own expenditures."
"What is your happiest memory with your husband?"
"One day he took me fishing with him in the early hours of the morning - it was a beautiful sunrise. That morning, he caught the biggest fish I'd seen yet and as soon as he did - he put it on my lap and said, 'this is not for sale - this is a special fish for dinner with my wife.' He kept his word and cooked dinner for me that night and even though I eat fish almost everyday, that was the best meal I've eaten all my life."

"I never joined my father's business and my son's never joined mine; so I know that they'll have the freedom to do whatever they want when they grow up."
"What's the best part about having Grand children?"
"GrandFather's day out...they take me wherever they want to go and I just go with it."

"People need to get over the stereotype about India - that it's dirty, mean, unfriendly and violent. We're from New York and we find that Indians are compassionate than most people we've met - always helpful and warm towards everyone. Infact, I'm working on a project in Dharavi, which is a slum area but I've noticed that even despite adverse conditions they're hospitable, with very giving hearts.
Basically, we love India."
"What's the one thing you've leant, while staying in India?"
"To say, 'challo, challo - jaldi challo!"

"I only gave my students one piece of advice - don't take anyone else's advice too seriously - they can never place themselves exactly in your shoes to make a judgement for you and ultimately only you can do what's best for you, because nobody else cares as much."

"I lost all 4 of my children when we moved here during Independence. My husband was the only family I knew for decades after...and I loved him immensely. We knew each other since we were growing up so he was my friend, my companion and the only person who understood what it felt like to lose your entire family. He passed away a few years ago, but he made me strong enough to deal with that too. I keep myself busy - I come here to overlook our shop, fend for myself and continue being strong. I miss him, but I know I'll be with him again soon."

"I first met her when we were in the 7th grade, but were studying in different schools. We had each other on MSN at that point, so we would talk on and off, but just as friends – even though I had told her I liked her back then itself. In the 11th grade, I moved to her school and officially asked her out to 'ice-cream' when we were in Bombay and we've been together since."
"What's your happiest memory together?"
"I guess it's the small things...He cooked dinner for me on Valentines Day in the first year of university in his dorm room – but there wasn't any furniture so we sat on the floor and ate. Or last year, when I really wanted to go on a holiday but our dates didn't match, so he picked a fight with me randomly one day and when we went back to his room there were candles everywhere, French music in the background and 2 tables with dinner, beneath a poster of the Eiffel tower – it was amazing!"
"What's the best part about the two of you together?"
"Through the 7 years there have been countless fights and breakups where we didn't talk for months together, but eventually we always found our way back to each other. I mean, I knew she was the one when I asked her out in the 11th grade itself, so it was only a matter of popping the question. When I had to do it, I made a treasure hunt for her, with each clue preparing her for the proposal – breakfast in bed, spa treatment, a dress picked out for her...and the final one which led her to the Shard in London, where I asked her to marry me on her favorite song – no place I'd rather be. "

"I used to roll bidis for around 6 years, when I just moved to Bombay. From that, I couldn't make more than 2 rupees per day which was enough for just me, but when I got married I had to move to something that made me more money. So from one profession that didn't require eduction to another - I got into this business. Life is about survival for people who aren't born with a golden spoon - and I've mastered the art of that. Give me a job that doesn't require reading or writing and I'll do it better than anyone else, no matter what it is. That's age, experience and survival combined for you."
"How old are you?"
"75 - still working, no complaining."

"I want to go home to mommy."
"What do you love the most about her?"
"She has the best heart in the whole world!"

"My husband got him home as a surprise 14 years ago and just put him on my lap. He's my baby...you know children grow up and get busy with their own lives but he's just the same and I love pampering him as well - believe it or not I feed him all his meals with my own hands!"

"I was married when I was 13 and my husband was 18. He was born and brought up in Bombay, but I had been a village girl all my life. We had two daughters and my life was going well with my husband  earning well from this vegetable business. Over time, he began consuming a lot of alcohol from these local shops and a few years later he passed away because of over consumption. That month, I left Bombay and went to my mother's house because the city scared me without him; but eventually I realized that my daughters have no one to fend for them, except me. I picked myself up and slipped into his shoes...I've been running this vegetable business and my house here in Bombay since the past 40 years. My biggest motivation was to educate my daughters and give them a chance to face the world better than I could. Today they're both qualified and well settled with their families...touch wood, God has been kind."

"Everyone at this market calls me 'amma'. I'm 80 years old and cannot support myself, so these people are like my family. I'm here from morning to night where these vendors give me food and protect me like their mother. I try helping them how much ever I can, but my old age doesn't always allow me to do as much as I would like. When I sleep on the street, my stomach and back hurt but It's made me strong. I haven't given up all these years...I'm not going to give up now."

"I was married into a very well to do family at the age of 23. It was only once I entered the joint family did I realize that everything was controlled by my mother-in-law, right from the house to the finances. My husband was a very intelligent man, but he was constantly overpowered by this family - to the point where we had almost no money for daily expenditures. 
For the first 10 years of my marriage I would borrow money from my mother and brother to get by, but once my children were born I decided that I wanted to take control and earn for the family. I was always into cosmetics, so I took a beauty course to learn how to professionally apply make up and drape a sari. 
Once my father-in-law passed away, we were constantly in court trying to keep our house and at the same time I was working, raising two children and supporting my husband - who overtime had developed schizophrenia. I've supported myself and my family since then and even after he passed away in 2004...all from draping saris. I feel like when it comes to protecting family - nothing is impossible for a woman and that's exactly what pushed me as well."

"We've known each other for like 6 years, but we became friends only 4 years back. I thought she was really weird at first and we just didn't like each other."
"Why?"
"I was going through a rebellious phase with red hair, tattoos and just not liking people in general."
"Then what happened?"
"I gave law a chance. Now it's all about that - college till 12, internship till 8. No regrets though...I wouldn't have reached here without that phase of my life."

"I was born in 1933 in Lahore and moved to Bombay in 1944, after I lost 2 of my brothers during riots. Through everything, my mother always told me to focus on my education and make something of myself first. She said, 'what will you have to show for your own life apart from your marriage?' I have fond memories of my college life, playing badminton, working and volunteering. Finally, I had a beautiful marriage when I was 33 to a man who understood the importance of an independent woman in his life."

"We've been married for 46 years and retired for 13...so now we're just bumming around, traveling and experiencing the world."
"What experience has touched you the most?"
"We were at a hotel in Morocco, overlooking the Sahara desert a few years ago. At around 6am one morning we were both standing in our balcony witnessing the most beautiful sunrise we'd seen, when all of a sudden a massive wind swept over us and jammed the balcony door. We were stuck on this 15th floor balcony with no one around...so I was bending down to try and attract some attention. While I was doing this, he was holding me to make sure I don't fall - but this person 3 levels below us thought I was trying to jump and commit suicide! The manager rushed to check what was happening and that's how we got out. We still laugh when we think about it...it was bizarre but one of the happiest times of my life."

"I want to buy a big car and drive everywhere!"
"Where do you want to drive to first?"
"China!"
"Why China?"
"I love noodles!"

"I undertook a 'Gandhi Fellowship' a few years ago and during that period I stumbled across a school in Dharavi which was in the worst condition - moldy walls, no ventilation, no color and no restrooms. No repairs were undertaken because of legal issues and failure of anyone stepping forward to take responsibility.
When I interacted with these children, I found that despite these conditions they were very keen on learning. I felt moved by this situation and decided to help in any small way I could - I set out to collect funds for the next six months. When I had collected around 1 Lakh Rupees I began fixing the walls, adding windows and lights to make the space more lively. Finally, I collected some volunteers from St. Xaviers college to paint the school with beautiful murals and learning aids. We began early on the weekend when the children weren't at school and completed the project by Sunday night. On monday, when these children came to school they were overjoyed seeing so much color and light...I'll never forget the look on their faces. Since then, I feel immense happiness and satisfaction when I take on a new school to transform...I'm currently working on the 8th such Municipal School Structure.

"When we were in the 4th standard, we were playing this game called dictionary, where we had to guess the word of the other team. Her word was 'binoculars' and I was the only one who guessed it. I liked her from back then, but I was too young to say anything at that time. Finally, when I was in the 8th grade I sent her an Email telling her I liked her and she replied in the affirmative.
But even after that, we were too shy to talk to each other at school, so I would go home and wait for his Email everyday. This went on till the 10th grade, when finally one day we spoke to each other, one on one when we were walking back home from tuitions. This one day, we were at Worli SeaFace just sitting there when it started pouring. That was the first day he said he loved me - and we were only 15 years back then.
"When did you know she was the one?"
"I knew she was the one all along, it was just a matter of making it official. When I did propose, I made a treasure hunt involving all the places that meant something to us like school or Seaface and finally the place I proposed was where we eventually got married. So the first email I sent her was on 20th December 2000 and we ended up getting married on 20th December 2013. So even though its our one year Wedding Anniversary tomorrow...it's actually us completing 14 years together."

"I've been working since I was 21. For the first few years at a Finance firm and for the next few years with a garment company. Since 18 I knew that I wanted to start my own restaurant because of my passion for cooking, but I was just waiting for the right time. When my daughter was born a few years ago, I quit working completely. Once she was old enough to go to school, I realized that I had to resume working again - but this time for myself. I took the time off to plan my restaurant and the menu. I was scared of it not working, but my husband pushed me into it and said, 'If not now, then when?' He supported me, went through countless tastings for my menu and gave me the courage to do something for myself and live my dream...actually live our dream and here it is, standing in front of you today!"

"He caught a viral fever over 2 weeks ago and he's just become better. The cost of antibiotics as well as the fees of the doctor were too much for us to manage. You can say that this is the first 'proper' meal my husband and I are going to eat since a few days."

"I was born on the pavement thats opposite the Haji Ali Signal. I grew up seeing my mother make money by collecting and disposing garbage, and I knew early on that I wanted to start working young and make money. I left school in the 2nd standard to start selling books at the Haji Ali signal. While selling books, I tried to make sense of words and began asking my regular customers for help with pronouncing and reading. Over time I taught myself how to read basic english and speak in broken sentences. 
One day, there was an Akanksha Survey happening at this garden nearby my house and my friends and I stopped to see what's happening. My friend told this Didi there that I can speak English and she insisted on me joining Akanksha. After that day Caroline Didi came to my signal everyday and tried convincing me to join school when I was around 12 years old. I agreed one day, but when I went to school I felt very out of place. I quit after a week and got back into selling books full time. 
One day, one of my regular customers asked me, 'Till when are you going to do this? Will you live the rest of your life at this signal?' That's when it hit me and I realized that I need to educate myself to go anywhere in life and fend for my family. Caroline didi trained me to study for my 10th exam under NIOS. I failed one subject in my first attempt but passed the 2nd time. I got into college and topped my 11th standard with 91% and got 81% in my 12th...I even became Headboy for those two years! Now I'm pursuing arts in KC college and I want to major in Sociology. I want to do for others, what my Didi did for me."

"We first met at a hostel in Thailand. We became really good friends there and parted ways, without any contact details. After a few months we co-incidentally met at a hostel in Nepal - again. What were the chances of us being together in the same place at the same time completely unplanned? That's when we got to really know each other and started dating. When we were leaving Nepal I asked him 'now what?' and he said we would be together. I was wondering how that was possible considering he's from Holland and I'm from Portugal."
"And then?"
"And then he surprised me in Portugal and we've been traveling together since!"
"The soul of the Artist is starving for satisfying work...not just something you do to pay the bills."

"I got married at the age of 21 to the man I really loved. At 24, my son was born and I felt like our family was complete. I knew my husband used to drink occasionally, but overtime that increased to everyday till the point where he couldn't work because he was under that alcohol influence. We tried really hard to get him out of it but it didn't work. At that point, my priority was my son and to ensure that none of this affected him. I would take science classes at 7 in the morning, go to school all day till 4 and then work again at a third job - only to return home by 10 at night. All this in addition to cooking and managing the house because I couldn't afford the help. There came a time when I was tutoring over 150 students - and I never complained. 
In 2006, my husband passed away. I feel sorry more than anything else, because he was such a nice man and I really loved him. So many people told me to remarry and send my son to a boarding school but that thought never even crossed my mind. I'm the mother - he's my flesh and blood and he will always be my biggest priority."

"The last time I went to my village, my wife asked me to bring back a gift for her from Bombay."
"What did you get her?"
"A mobile phone. She's very intelligent - she learnt how to dial my number on her own! Now whenever we talk, I feel like it's a gift for both of us."
"Why discuss struggle? There's no struggle when theres one life, one wife, two children, good food and a lot of love!"

"I did a showcase of 20th century fossils recently. In that, I included a pink caste of the Marilyn Monroe Brassier which sold for thousands of dollars - carved in marble stone. To me, they were not only selling a garment but the idea of sexuality and eroticism which I wanted to accurately depict in my sculpture - to make it so real that people are perplexed with the illusion. 
Art to me, is not something that anyone should receive passively. It's supposed to motivate you to feel something and experience different emotions. Today, people sell art to survive, but where's the imagination? It's something like the Theory of Relativity- imagination is everything and everything you can image is real - if only you open your mind to it."

"We're from the same village, which is why we've known each other for over 25 years. I'm an electrician, so this one time I was called into work late at night to fix a problem. I was relatively new to the city, and I was scared to leave my family at home alone, when I decided to call him. Just like that, he came to my house with his wife and children and said 'you go work and don't worry about anything.' I'll never forget what he did for me that day - sometimes even your real family doesn't do that for you."

"I like fusions, so I dress this way. I love art, so I want to look like art itself. Some people don't understand that, but why worry about people who don't get how magnificent you are? This is me and I'll never change myself to please those who don't understand what I'm about."

"Do any of us really know who we are? We're satisfied with whatever's been given to us, or told to us right from birth. When we're children we're told, ' you're stubborn' or 'you're reserved' and that's what we grow up believing. I feel like it's important to wake up to your own reality. You give so much of your time to your family, your friends and other social commitments, but where's the time for yourself? Give 5 minutes everyday to look inward and realize things about you. You'll begin to understand things about yourself like, 'I'm compassionate' or 'I'm loving' and that's when your internal journey will begin and open up a whole new world that you didn't know existed. It's you - it's you first and that doesn't mean you're selfish - it means you're taking back the power of your own reality. How can you think of loving others around you, when you don't truly love and appreciate yourself? The relationship you have with yourself has been the longest - so make that one the best before anything else."

"The dog I used to look after for 3 years before him, passed away a few months ago. I was very upset after it happened, and when we got this dog here 6 months back, he could sense that I was sad about something. He would come and be around me while I was doing other things around the house and just spend time with me. I take care of him, but really he has taken care of me...which is why I call him my friend."

"I never tell people my age, but when I last travelled to Heathrow and the immigration officer saw my birthdate, he asked me how I keep myself fit. I just said, 'Honey, age is just a number - my heart is still younger than ever!'"

The show of hands is in response to the question, "Who likes to run?"
"And why?"
"Because I don't have to sit in class!"
"Because it makes me the flexiblest!"
"Because I can fly!"

"Every other day people come here and start talking about India and politics. I have a lot of opinions about Modi, but I don't think he cares about what I say and my one opinion isn't going to matter for anything...not for this issue or any other issue in this country - so please don't waste my time and let me earn for my family."
"You have your fun until you find 'the one'. Once that happens, everything changes and you can do anything to not let that love go."

"On the morning of 27th November 2008, my dad got a call from his cousin's domestic help, saying that the whole family had gone to the Taj for dinner, but they hadn't come back. My parents obviously panicked and rushed to find out what was going on. They had to go to many different hospitals to identify bodies and check if any of them were of my family. For those next four days I was all alone at home, glued to the TV - just watching the news for any piece of information. I didn't see my parents at all during that period of time and when I did finally see them, I was told that I had lost 3 of my family members."

"I was at my restaurant Refresh at CST on the night of 26/11. As soon as we heard gunshots coming from the washroom nearby, I ushered my staff and a few more people inside my restaurant and asked them to hide underneath the tables incase they shoot through the doors. While all this was happening, I didn't realize that I myself was standing and as a result I got shot twice at 9:37PM - one bullet in my abdomen and the other in my chest area, but thankfully all 54 members of my staff were safe and so were around 50 odd people who were at the restaurant. 
There was no bleeding - just a burning sensation; so I got up, put myself in a cab and went to Bombay hospital where the doctors were all shocked that I was walking. I slipped into a coma and was declared 'dead' on 27th November, but my organs began healing, I came out of my coma and by mid December I was on my two feet and working at that very restaurant.
Two things I will always be grateful for - first is the kindness extended to not only me but all the victims by Mr. Ratan Tata and the Taj Group who showed so much sensitivity and support to us all. When I told them that my medical insurance would cover the cost of all my surgeries - they were diligent enough to notice that insurance wouldn't cover taxes and on the day of my discharge when I went to clear that bill, I was told it was already paid for. 
And secondly I'm grateful that those bullets actually did hit me, because right behind where I was standing at that time, were 18 cylinders which would have exploded and killed everyone who I was trying to save in the first place."
#SuperHumansofBombay #Wewillneverforget

"We were at cafe Leopold that night. I hadn't been able to catch up with a friend of mine for really long so we thought we'll meet there and get a few beers. As expected, Leo's was lively and filled with people even on a Wednesday night. We were sitting upstairs, at these two tables that they have along the side of the stairs as you walk up. 
I don't know exactly what you would call this but at around 9:05 my friend wanted to step out for a smoke and that's exactly when it happened. We were outside the small side entrance of Leo's, where the door is - to access the staircase, just standing there when we heard what we thought were fireworks. I mean we had never heard gunshots before so were confused with the sounds and the small flashes of light that accompanied them. 
Just about then, a guy walked out holding his neck because he was bleeding profusely. Our instinct was to go towards him to help him but he was just yelling at us asking us to run and get out of that place. We stood there for a few seconds but he kept screaming at us saying he was fine and to leave. My heart was racing as we turned around and robotically started moving away but during that whole time I could hear this man, shouting at bystanders to get out of the way and save their lives. I guess that in itself was a message to the people carrying out such atrocities...a message that our humanity will always prevail."
#SuperHumansofBombay #wewillneverforget

'While waiting for hours on end in the Taj that night, I remember conditioning my mind to the idea of death and suppressing any illusion of hope.  Bombay responded to the terrorist attack as it always does, hands tied behind its back, it's authorities asleep at the wheel while facing murderous thugs, with a staggering indifference to the fear of death and as for the people of Bombay...they showed an undying spirit like they always do.
I am alive today because of the Taj Staff and the commandos. On at least three occasions, I was saved by the remarkably brave Taj staff members. First, when they bolted the banquet hall doors of the Crystal Room where i was just before the terrorists were outside the hall. Then, when the evacuation went horribly wrong in the early hours of November 27, when the terrorists found us in the Chambers corridor because politicians had given away our position on live television and started shooting directly at us. For the next many hours, these young professionals were right there with us, hiding in one on of Chamber's meeting rooms, keeping us hopeful, keeping us alive. 
A taj Staff woman came back into the Taj to show the commandos our location, and as we left we all got emotional when we saw the blood and destruction in their hotel, but they put on a brave face and ushered us to move forward.  When we were brought out to the entrance of the Taj, the terrorists started shooting at us again and the cops who were supposed to escort us ran for cover while the Taj employees formed a human circle around us to prevent us from getting shot or hurt during stampeding.
These were ordinary individuals being extraordinarily brave when many whose job it was to protect us, had failed.They were all citizens of Bombay that day. They exemplify hospitality. it wasn't their job. it was what they believed they wanted to do. They could have left us there to die and found their way to safety, but they chose to stay. I cannot comprehend their bravery but i am in generous awe of it and in their perpetual debt. They shone a light on the finest elements of humanity on a dark and bloody day. I will stand with them today. I will stand with them always.
#SuperHumansofBombay #wewillneverforget

"Whenever I come down from Indore to visit my daughter and her family, I make it a point to bring my granddaughter to the park to play in the open. She needs to be around mud and trees and run around enjoying being young instead of sitting at home in front of a computer screen. She has the rest of her life to do that, but this time of being young and carefree will never come back and I just want her to enjoy every minute of it."

"I've known her for 40 years now - we don't meet that often but she still knows me the most. You know a person wants best for you when you tell them things that are wrong in your life and they try to make amends instead of pushing you further away - and that's what she's done all through. Throughout life, from having children to grandchildren she's been the person I confide in about everything, without ever hesitating."

"She lived in the same area as me but my family and her family were enemies, to the extent that there was a wall between our houses. I used to see her cycling up and down the road, laughing with her sister and drinking mangola and I used to wait for hours to just catch a glimpse of her. Finally I approached her sister and tried to become her friend - I used to buy her sandwiches and coffee in the hope that atleast she would like me from that family. Finally I convinced her to give me her sisters number but the first few times I called her she got so shy she wouldn't even talk. But I didn't give up- I used to write her notes everyday on tree leaves and finally after months she smiled at me while she was on her way home. We dated for 5 years and we tried really hard to convince our parents to let us marry but they were only focusing on the hatred between our families."
"So then?"
"So then what...we ran away and got married at a beautiful temple in Alibaug and then I took her home. At first, they said mean things but eventually they couldn't ignore how much we wanted to be together. 25 years later and marrying her has still been the best decision of my life."

"I've grown up listening to women around me saying something needs to be done for women and to protect women...but instead of waiting for that to happen I just decided to make myself strong enough to never need anyone else' to protect me."

"To be a 22 year old woman starting her own business in a place like India was by itself a struggle. I remember I used to ask my father to call suppliers, because they wouldn't take me seriously - but I stuck by what I loved and today those suppliers call me to make their sales. I feel like two things got me to where I am today - first is the support of my parents to educate me and give me the freedom to choose my career. So many girls in India today are denied that education and support and I feel like that is the biggest change that needs to come about. 
The second is the sheer love for what I do...I remember first baking when I was just 7 but even that entire journey has had so many ups and downs. When I was 18, I interned at this hotel in Switzerland and the experience was terrible - I used to cry everyday and just wanted to go home. At 20 I interned at a hotel near the first one and that for me was the best experience. Even though the first one was a complete failure, both experiences helped me grow and its my belief that you learn more from failure than you do from success and as long as you love what you do, relentlessly everyday - there is nothing that can stop you."

"I've been working as a security guard for over a decade now. It's not the best of professions and I have often been mocked, but I have learnt to ignore those people and focus on whats important...my children. I promised myself that I would work double shifts if I had to, but I wouldn't allow my children to be uneducated and living in a village all their life. Two of my children are still studying, right here in Bombay and my older daughter decided to return to our village as a teacher, because it is her belief that if children are educated the right way, no dream is too small - no matter where you come from."

Sometimes you have to casually put on sunnies and surround yourself with the best parts of life...
and the little ones always seem to know how to do it best :)

"The youth of today need to realize that they are the ones who can make a positive difference in our society. So many youngsters come here under the pretext of volunteering, but actually they just want a certificate saying they've worked with visually impaired people. We need to stop being selfish and actually start caring and understanding. They're all so talented - right from singing, teaching to software engineering we make them realize how much potential they all have. Despite all that, these children and adults have so many limitations they have to overcome - if you come here and spend time with them and actually care for them, you get to understand what beautiful human beings they are and how selfless their love is."

"I was forced into an arranged marriage when I was just a boy of 16 and my wife was 13. We realized early on that we were very different, but by then we had no option but to stay together...because what will society say? We also did it because we both love our children and we've worked hard for them - my younger son's a Columbia graduate and I'm so proud of him, but at the end of the day I feel like I've lived a half life and wish I could back to say something to my parents who decided to plan my life for me."

"In our country from the time a girl child is born the society, the home and others in the periphery channelize her into not having faith in herself. The woman herself grows up to believing that she isn't capable...but she couldn't be more false, she's just unaware. I live by the western etiquette where a woman knows what her prerogative is. Take a simple handshake - it is for the woman to decide if even that squeeze is a 'good touch' or a 'bad touch' and it's her choice to make whether she wants to greet someone with folded hands as opposed to the handshake. Women are looked at as commodities - we are subject to rape, molestation and prostitution and we should be outraged! This takes us back to the role of a mother ; how she raises her child and we complete the circle - from birth to giving birth it is the woman that moulds society. We have a lot of fire within us - we just need to embrace it and have a problem with the way things are going!"

"If you could change one thing about this city, what would it be?"
"Rickshaws...they've ruined my life!"

"My father introduced me to this market when I was 12 and since those days I've worked here. Things have changed over time...back then we used to love doing our business and making deals but today with all the politicians and their bribery it's no longer fun. To me, Bombay is finished. That's why when it came down to deciding whether my sons should carry this forward or get away from the struggle, I decided its time to end this business with me. Today, one of my son's is working in Kuwait, and the other is working for Apple. I am a small man, but I have tried to give my family everything and ensure that atleast my children can live the life that I could never live."

"I was 18 when I returned from the US and started studying at St. Xavier's here in Bombay. I saw such a contrast between the two worlds and felt that something was so wrong in the way people here disregard education, that I woke up one day and just took off to the slum areas in Dharavi and started teaching children. That's how Akanksha (The NGO) was born. I guess as people, we all want to do 'Big things which will change the world' but no one realizes that all we have to do is focus on the little things and those will add up to make the world a better place.
"What experience has touched you the most, through this journey?"
"A student that I taught, passed away really suddenly. He had been unwell for a while and I found out that the night before he passed away, his grandfather gave him Rs. 14,000 to stop working and admit himself into a private hospital. This child was aware of the financial difficulty his grandfather was having and he admitted himself to a government hospital where he died 12 hours later. That day made me realize how much we can give as human beings, and that was a definite turning point in my internal journey."

"We learn to use the Chabuk (Horsewhip) at a very young age. We go to school in the village, but whenever we have our vacations we travel here to earn more money...that's the only way we can afford to stay in school for another year."

"My daughter was born prematurely because of which she has multiple disabilities. As a result of that, no normal school was accepting her and even though she's capable of learning she wasn't getting the chance to. That's when I decided to start a school and learning center for my daughter and those like her - because it's so unfair that even though their disabilities are through no fault of their own, they are almost being punished by being deprived of an education. Even though they aren't like us, they have their own little dreams in their world, which is very different from ours...and every child whether special or non special deserves the chance to feel closer to achieving that dream."

"Years ago when I was going to get married, my to be in-laws asked me to give up the orphanage I had begun. At that time, my mother asked me to do what I wanted to do, and not give up anything under the pretext of marriage. That's when I decided to continue what I started - I'm still single and I've chosen to be single. I have 60 children here who look to me as a mother and that's what makes me happy. People in India feel that if you aren't married you cannot be complete but I'm proud to be a woman - a complete woman and I didn't have to be married to feel this way."

Just like every drop makes up the sea - a conscious effort from every individual makes a difference. We have a beautiful city and great values, so lets not waste what we have by littering and actually make that extra effort to contribute to the Swachh Bharat Abhiyan. 
#HumansofBombayforChange

"I've spent my years as a tour guide, showing people Bombay, the famous spaces and sometimes the darker, harsher spots. I've met so many countless people, all searching for something and most of the times these people feel that if they travel they'll find it - if only it were that easy! I've come to realize that life is very simple if you want it to be that way. We focus on individual events too much to understand that everything eventually fits together like a piece of puzzle and if a particular time was difficult in your life, it's because the larger picture would be incomplete without that piece. I've had a great life, a beautiful wife, healthy sons and grandsons...what more could I have asked for? Ofcourse, I've had times when I've been sad, but life has presented simple solutions for that as well - there's nothing that a little alcohol or chilam with old friends can't fix. Now, you might say that that's not a solution - ofcourse it's not, but then again solutions present themselves at the right time and in the mean while you have to do what it takes to enjoy the ride!"
"My sister's in the village. I want to go to school so that I can earn money and bring her here with me."

"My father was always into fitness, so ever since I was a small boy I wanted to be a trainer. Today, I'm 66 and still training people, because I want them to know that when it comes to your body, age is just a number - our bodies get old only because we think that an old body cannot be fit."
"In all your years of teaching, what experience has touched you?"
"A few years ago, I conducted a workshop with disabled people. For a person like me, who's entire life revolves around the physical body it was a great feeling to understand that at the end of the day everyone has a beating heart with feelings and emotions and the rest hardly matters."

We met this stray dog during one of our shoots and for the rest of the day he accompanied us wherever we went, patiently waiting as we interviewed people - all because we showed him some love. Probably more 'human' than the rest of us, we thought he rightfully deserves his own space on Humans of Bombay :)

"We've grown up together in this slum - we go to the same school and have the same tuitions also."
"What do you want to be when you grow up?"
"Doctors!"
"Why?"
"When I was younger my mother fell really ill - for many days, she couldn't even get up. At that time, one doctor uncle used to come to our slum and regularly check the health of women and children. We had taken my mother to a doctor but her health hadn't improved, but when he came and started checking her health everyday and giving her medicines - she recovered. Since that day, I've wanted to become  a doctor like doctor uncle."

"The hardest part about being a Physiotherapist, like any other medical profession I guess, is matching the expectations of people to fully recover as quickly as possible, and at the same time giving them the courage to overcome their struggle over an extended period of time."

"We've known each other since we were born practically. I work in Bombay, so she's visiting me for a week but we've always taken trips together. One time we took off to Switzerland, without any plan or any accommodation. When we reached there at night, we went to this place which we thought was a hostel, but ended up belonging to a weird man who asked both of us to stay with him in the same bed. Obviously, we ran and ended up scouting different places every night for the rest of the trip!"
"What's the best part about her?"
"I guess because we've known each other for so long, I just have to look at her and she knows exactly what I'm thinking. So we end up looking at each other and laughing on a lot of occasions, and no one else ever knows why."

"We first became friends at MBA school, when we were both seeing other people. A year and a half later, we both realized we had feelings for each other - it was a mutual thing, no one said anything; but it kind of just happened. A few weeks after we began dating, our families met and we were 'officially' engaged, so there wasn't anything over the top romantic about it until the Valentines Day after our engagement."
"What happened on that day?"
"She got me a ring and proposed!"
And when she smiled, there was no reason for any worry to exist in the world :)

"When I first came to Bombay, I had no money. I slept on the streets and remained hungry for days, but I made some great friends. Finally when I got a job, I used to earn 200 rupees a month and believe it or not, with that money, in those times I've fed 6 people of my family and provided a roof over their heads. But that isn't my biggest achievement. I feel the proudest, when I see both my sons working - one at a bank and the other at an investment company. Even though I still earn, they've taken care of me and my wife and made our lives so comfortable - touchwood, God has been very kind and life has been very good to us."

She's 84, raised 3 children all by herself and continues to work for 10 hours a day, everyday to support herself.

Happy Diwali, Humans of Bombay! This time around spend a little less on fancy decorations and crackers, and a little more on spreading light with these beautiful Diyas :)

"My last relationship ended on a bad note and I used to be very upset, wondering why he wasn't calling or he wasn't making an effort with me. That's when I began chanting Nam Myōhō Renge Kyō again. I used to chant earlier as well, but I used to strategize my life with him and somehow it never worked out. Finally, when my relationship ended, I started chanting for my own happiness and peace and overtime I realized that if he isn't a part of my life, it's only because he doesn't align with my happiness and that realization made it easy to peacefully let him go."

At first there was just one little boy telling us his story,
After a few seconds, there were a few more...
And then one of them said, 'Didi smile' and there was uncontrollable laughter!

"I go to school till 2 in the afternoon and then straight to the docks to work. I like fishing and the sea, especially during sunset."
"What's the best part about working at such a young age?"
"I get to eat my mother's fish curry almost everyday!"

"We Indians are known for our culture, kindness towards others and respect for our elders. I felt proud when after becoming Prime Minister, Modi touched his mother's feet and ate Lapsi from her hand. Not only that, when he went to America he was the only one who folded his hands and thanked the person who introduced him to the crowd. I'm an old man, but I feel happy knowing that even if I die tomorrow, India and my children are in safe hands. People say even he's corrupt like the others, but I say - what will he do with the money? He has no sons, no wife – it's just him and India. After he became PM, the Chinese have come to us, the Japanese have come to us and you watch…even Americans will understand our potential and come."

"I first met my wife in Karachi, where we lived on the same street. She was a friend at first, but somewhere I realized that no matter what I was doing she was at the back of my mind and as soon as that thought struck me - I proposed to her. We've been together for over 50 years, and I feel lucky to have found her because even though I'm a 94 year old man and she's just 74, she looks after me and loves me like we're 18! She's so caring and patient that I feel like my love continues to grow till today and mind you she's my second wife...but that has hardly mattered because once you find the one, even if it's a little late in life - nothing before of after that is half as important."

"What is life? Some people have a supernatural life, other people have an okay life and millions have a bad life. There is no definition and there is no thumb rule - we're all in this together and that's what we don't realize. If one person has negative energy, it decreases the energy of the universe as a whole; but we're too selfish to understand that concept. I have travelled road after road looking for success and fortune but ultimately I landed up with immense dissatisfaction. Finally, I found what I had been looking for all along and that is Peace. People often misunderstand Peace to be the lack of violence -  it's not. It's understanding that your energy and disposition affects everyone as a whole, and that's when you take to kindness and compassion towards all elements of this beautiful planet."

"I started this small shop with my savings a few months ago. This isn't the end of the dream though - I want to expand to more shops in Bombay and Dubai. I moved to Bombay a year ago and the one thing I've learnt is that the world does't wait for anyone to catch up - you have to get on the train yourself to move faster and make a mark."

"Art has been a part of my life since as long as I can remember- I was probably 5 or 6 when I made my first painting. Up until a certain age, I was extremely sheltered and my art was limited to the things I saw around me or at school. This one evening, I was walking by a street near my house, that I cross everyday (usually in my car) and saw a little girl scribbling  with a pencil on a piece of paper outside her chawl, without any light. I thought of the amount of resources at my disposal and impulsively spoke to her mother and asked her to send her daughter and other children from the chawl, up to my house because I could teach them how to paint. 
The next day when around 20 children came to my house, I asked them to paint things that made them happy and it was overwhelming to see that almost all of their paintings didn't have anything materialistic in them - infact most of them were portraits of happy smiling families, some had flowers and others had birds. I guess that incident changed my perspective in a lot of ways and influenced my art to include emotions more than anything else. It hit me that these children had so little, but still they found happiness in the smallest of things - things you and me probably take for granted."

"I've been working since I was 14 and I'm 76 today. There hasn't been a single day that I've felt like not working or retiring- we retire and do what exactly? I have a perfectly healthy body and an even healthier mind, which I want to put to use till my last breath. Sometimes when the younger generation complains about their lives, I feel like telling them to start passionately working, or getting involved with a new project that gives them a purpose. Remember this - an idle mind is where we 'make up' 99.9% of our problems which actually do not exist; whereas an occupied mind aligns us with positivity and purpose."

"1 year ago my chaacha sent me a picture of himself and his family at Gateway of India. I saw the picture and decided then and there that this is the place I want to raise my family - so I left my village and came to Bombay having that vision in mind. I'm a small man, but I want to open my own chain of restaurants. That's the difference between Bombay and where I come from...here even a small man like me is allowed to have big dreams."

"I was just closing my shop on the 26th of November 2008, when I saw those 2 men getting out of the cab, calmly walking into Leos and indiscriminately shooting. As soon as they started firing, I slipped into this lane and started running like a madman- not knowing where to go or how to react. My legs gave way at some point and my knees were shaking to the extent that I just collapsed. When I regained consciousness, I ran to a police station just down the road and told them what I had seen; they said that the terrorists had left and there was mayhem everywhere in Bombay. I'll never forget the sight I saw when I went back to Leos - blood, limbs and constant sobbing from those who had survived, but were in un-imaginable pain. I remember there were a number of us helping those who were injured by putting them safely into cabs - some even going with these patients all the way to the hospital.
