Not one of these people were worried that their life could be in danger as well - considering that the entire city was under attack. That day, those terrorists might have succeeded in killing people...but they failed to kill humanity."

"My husband had been ill for a while before he passed away so during that period he told me that if anything were to happen to him, I should come to Bombay and meet a man who owed us money. I came here today, but that man started screaming and told me to never come back to ask him for money. I'm taking the bus back to my home in a few hours, but I'm worried about surviving. My in-laws want me out of the house, now that my husband has passed away. They won't even give me money to survive but I know what I have to do now - I'm going to double the houses I work at as a maid and fend for myself."

"When I first came to Bombay, I didn't even have a place to sleep. Today, I own multiple factories and businesses and I've come a long way but I can't help but wonder, without that struggle was success possible? And if that is the case what about my 17 year old grandson who has no struggles at all - will he be just as successful? God knows I pray for his success everyday, but then I can't understand - why are only some us made to struggle while so many others aren't? What is the basis of that differentiation?"

"We used to work in the same office around 35 years ago and at that time there were only 2 single women in the whole office - one of them being this lovely woman sitting next to me. My colleague came to me one day and said lets pull a prank and tell the entire office that the last 2 single women are dating us! That's how it all started, but that stupid fellow didn't even end up dating the other woman and I ended up marrying this one!"

"I'm trying this thing called Sun Gazing. It basically involves sitting on any element of earth whether soil or sand and gazing at the sun for 10 seconds on the first day and adding 10 seconds to everyday thereafter. After 30 days your mind is free from thoughts that trouble your mind, after 60 days your body is rid of diseases and after 90 days you have control over yourself like the Sun - self sustaining and radiant; while gaining Clairvoyance as well."
"What inspired you to try this out?"
"I have a friend who completed his 90 days and I saw the change in him with my own eyes, but in the larger sense I took to nature after I changed my career path. I make cartoons and animated films for children which have undertones of gratitude and manifestations which we've always been told about, but forgotten as we've "grown up". Take the Rhyme, 'row row row your boat, gently down the stream; merrily life is but a dream', for example. It tells us to be the captain of our own boat and go with the course of life, visualize and know that all our manifestations are possible- like a dream. Sadly, as we grow up we become bound by routine and forget our own flow. I gave up the career I thought I wanted, for a career I love, which also allows me to have beautiful experiences in nature because that's my flow and I don't want any 9-5 desk job ruining it."

"I met her for the first time around 1936 at a balloon shop. She was a few years younger than me, but full of spirit. We laid a bet of 1 Paisa over who could blow the biggest balloon and when I won, she was so furious she went to her mother's house and brought back 1 Rupee to give to me. That's how we first met, but after that day we were inseparable - playing together, fighting with one another but mostly laughing uncontrollably. Finally, our parents asked us to take it forward and we got married in 1942 in Karachi, which is our hometown. Back then, nobody expected Partition so we had all our factories set up in Bombay and naturally we moved here; but that's the only sad part - we haven't been able to go back to our hometown or the first house we lived in after marriage. There are no regrets though, I've had only happy memories with my wife, whether here or in Pakistan - the place has hardly mattered."

"40 years ago, we used to be one of the few people who would come for walks at 6 am in the morning, religiously everyday. I used to recognize him as the only person to smile at a stranger so early in the morning and that's how we were no longer strangers - we became friends. Today, we live in the same neighborhood with our families and even our grandchildren are friends with one another."

"After I finished my engineering, I got several job offers from different international companies but I never took them up. I don't know why, but today we chase big international jobs and imported products when everything you need is right here in India. Till date, I practice Swadeshi - almost 99% of the products I wear or I use at home are made in India because we still haven't learnt to be self sufficient. After Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the Japanese rebuilt their country practically from scratch (around the same time as Indian Independence) and today they aren't known as a third world country but we are. It's because we're constantly being pulled in different directions by various political parties. Every country has an opposition party - but the core purpose is united; to make progress, develop and self sustain. We need to return those values and I see it happening now that Mr. Modi has come to power. I would like to tell him that he reminds me of Mr. Gandhi, because back then Gandhi gave us the purpose of Independence and today Modi is re-unifying us with the centralized purpose of progress."

"In my time, the school in my village would start teaching us Science and Mathematics only after grade 8 - the only thing they taught us from the beginning was Hindi and History. How am I supposed to get a 'reputed' job with only that much knowledge? I've been away from my family for 40 years - every year I visit them once, but that's about it. I have to do it to educate my children better than I have been educated - which is why they study in English Medium Schools. Ofcourse I miss my family terribly, but this world works on give and take. It is only when Laxmi (Goddess of Wealth) leaves you, that Saraswati (Goddess of Knowledge) can enter your life and then because of that knowledge , Laxmi can re- enter your house once again. Sadly, this is the most fundamental circle of life and I'm just another human being, abiding by the Gods above."

"I was walking down the road a few days ago, when this old man toppled and fell on the street. Although a crowd gathered around him, there was this young girl who picked him up and took care of him. She didn't know him, but I saw her getting into the ambulance, holding his hand. I guess, humanity still exists. because that was something that really moved me - even though she's much younger than me and I don't know her myself, she made me want to be a better person and reach out to people."

"Today all our emotions are based on money -  the bonuses we earn and the ladders we climb. I have run my own business for 45 years so I know what it's like to base emotions on how much money we make. But to tell you honestly, I preferred it back then when we were less selfish and more sensitive to our brothers. You know what the best part is? The youngsters today feel like they know what its like to party and celebrate every weekend, but I've attended the biggest party there ever will be - when we celebrated India's Freedom. The streets were filled with people singing and dancing together for a week - and I guarantee you, no amount of money can buy back that feeling!"

"My wife passed away a few years ago. It was all so sudden - she was standing near a pool when she got an attack and fell into the water. By the time someone could pull her out, it was too late. I'm a surgeon myself, but there was nothing I could do to help. Now, my daughter here comes with me for walks and takes me out to watch movies - it helps, but I still miss my wife terribly."
"What is your fondest memory with your daughter and wife?"
"Oh, I forgot to mention - she's not my real daughter. 17 years ago she joined my hospital and since then she has been like a daughter to me. Both my actual children don't live in Bombay, so especially after my wife's death she has taken care of me like family. That's why I called her my daughter -family doesn't necessarily have to mean we're related by blood; it goes a long way beyond that."

"I first found out he had Down Syndrome when he was 3 months old. I distinctly remember he was severely dehydrated when I took him to this doctor in Bombay, who lifted him from the stomach and said - 'why do you want to save him? He's going to be a vegetable.' That's when I decided that my son isn't going to live his life like that. The strength came over time though - I have questioned and requestioned God, that why did he do this to me? There were times when I wanted to abandon him, but this one day my husband asked me, 'what is his fault? We are the ones who created him - so let us do justice to our creation.' 
From there, we never looked back. Today, people know me as Rishi's mother - he has won Gold and Silver Medals at the Special Olympics World Games and he is a Gold Medalist Badminton player. But these are just his achievements- he is so much more than that. When people say he is special I agree fully because no 'normal' person can love the way he does - it is so unconditional and pure that there are times when I wonder whether he's actually an angel, sent from heaven to teach me how to give to others and truly love from the heart."

"I went to college in America to study medicine but I ended up getting a degree in Bio Engineering. From there, I went on to get my PHD in engineering but 2 years into it I gave it up. Through this entire process I used to work at different restaurants (because I was broke) and even after I gave up my PHD I was drawn to this industry. From washing dishes to bar-tending I've literally worked in every position there is to finally realize that this is what I was born to do. When I moved back to Bombay I began catering from home and from there I've reached here today- to owning my own restaurants and making food that people really love. Other people that is...believe it or not, my kids hate my food!"
"That's hard to believe, but what message would you like to give to people?"
"Build and they shall come!"
"We both want to have careers in New York; It's been our dream city for years now. It helps to share a dream with your best friend - you feel that much closer to actually getting there."

"I found out that my husband was having a relationship with another woman a few years ago. Other women in my neighborhood asked me to keep quiet about it and let it go - but I couldn't. I confronted him, told him that I was leaving him and that I was capable of supporting my child by myself. Over the next few months he kept apologizing, but I didn't relent until he showed me that he was actually sorry. He quit smoking and drinking and started to come home early to meet the baby. After a while, I forgave him. I know he was wrong, but he's human...he had a slip but I love him enough to give him the second chance. It's been a few years since this happened, but I've never been happier and a few months ago I even delivered my 2nd child."

I saw this man looking so chill- just sitting on his cycle, chatting away on his phone when I decided to ask him if I could take a picture. The woman who he was speaking with on the phone heard this, and insisted on speaking to me. The conversation went somewhat like this:
"You're from a newspaper?"
"Not exactly...it's an online 'page' on Facebook?"
"I know Facebook. You have Shah Rukh Khan on your paper?"
"No..."
"...Oh, okay give him the phone again."
One of the many great attributes of women is their ability to have high pitched voices, so I overheard this woman through the phone saying-
"What kind of a newspaper doesn't even know Shah Rukh Khan? Don't give her a picture!"
(Obviously, a little too late!)

"I got married when I was 21 years old, but I knew my husband since the 2nd grade. Literally, we've fought with each other about everything - from the swings when we were young to copying homework when we were older. He used to have a Royal Enfeld, so eventually we would skip college and go for long drives to Khandala. Even after we were married, I used to complain that he never wrote me any love letters and he would  blame it on his bad handwriting and just laugh at me. Most of the times, I would say - ' am I talking to the wall you stupid fellow?' and he would continue laughing...till finally even I would laugh with him!"
"Did you ever think of remarrying?"
"I don't know if you'll understand this, but when you love someone with such a genuine heart you cannot look beyond that person- even after death. I don't know about your generation but for me, love cannot happen more than once and I've had mine. Cancer took him away at a young age of 32, but all my happiest memories are in those 10 years with him. He passed away in 1975 but till today from the time I wake up to the time I sleep - every step of the day I miss him with all my heart."

"My cousin makes short films, while I enhance the script he gives me with my vision. I can literally take a pitch that's two lines into twelve pages, because I love adding the details - from the background, to intense character development. I'm worried though because while he does this, he has an engineering degree to back him. I want to make beautiful films but I feel like only influence works to get into the industry...the period of struggle is so big for an outsider, and what will I have to fall back on?
It's frustrating that my creativity is constantly being challenged because a lot of people have put it in my mind that creative fields pay less - and if I don't make the money, I won't be able to survive."

"My husband and I had an intercaste love marriage. We faced some opposition from both are families in the beginning, but eventually then gave in. It was difficult for me to conceive after my marriage - so we tried the IVF method and it worked for us - we were blessed with 2 beautiful babies. In 2009, he passed away from a brain disorder and after that my life just went downhill. My in-laws slapped case after case on me, claiming that I had killed him and that those were not his children. He was a police officer and PA to a very powerful politician, so everywhere I went, people were talking about what had happened...it was a dark and trying time. Finally, I moved my children to Ajmer with my mother, started running my own business and taking control of my life.
He was a great man and he would never have wanted to see me this way - he was always so compassionate. I remember during the 26/11 attacks he volunteered to go inside the Taj to plan a rescue mission - he always thought of other people first. I'm trying to be as compassionate and continue this journey without him...hopefully he's proud of me, wherever he is."

"I visit my family maybe once in a few years. 5 months ago, I had a baby daughter - but I haven't even seen her yet. I received a post card from my wife saying she's healthy and beautiful, but I don't even know what she looks like. Once in every 2 weeks, I call my village and ask my wife to give my daughter the phone, but she laughs and says 'how will she speak, she's only 5 months old!' All these years I have somehow managed to stay away from home, but I can't anymore. I'm finally leaving to go home to my family."
"I haven't had him for too long, but I don't think anyone loves me as much as he does."

"I started traveling by bus when I was 9 years old. This one day I saw a man trying to get onto the bus while it was moving, but he didn't get the right grip and just fell onto the street. I still get scared thinking of what might have happened to him. That's why, even though my younger brother's 11 years old, I don't let him travel by bus. My parents keep saying he's old enough now...but he's just a baby!"

"The last time I remember being carefree and happy was when I was in school, in my village. I remember going to school everyday, coming home to eat daal rice and rushing out to play Kabaddi with my friends. Today I'm separated from my family in my village because I have to work here to send them money. Life is funny - I used to dislike going to school back then, but today I want nothing more than to have the feeling of being carefree and coming home to my mother's hot food."

"He's my brother's son but I've loved him like he's my own child. Just the other day when I entered his room, his face lit up with the biggest smile and all I could think was, 'I'm so lucky to have someone who's that happy to see me!'"

"We first met when he came to Bombay from Gujarat and came to my shop to make some new clothes. I didn't expect someone like him to become friends with me because I'm just a tailor and he was an educated man- but we ended up becoming friends-it's almost been 30 years!"
"What's the best part of your friendship?"
"30 years and we still have our afternoon tea together."

"The most terrified I've ever been was when I was in my village during Partition and Hindus and Muslims were at raging war with one another. Everywhere you looked, there was only fire and death. My brother and I were hiding under some stacks of hay in our neighborhood, looking for the right moment to run when our neighbor,a Muslim man - spotted us. His clothes were bloody and he had a sword in his hand. I thought those 2 minutes would be the last of my life - but he saw us, looked away and shouted to the rest of the mob - 'No one's here, let's move on."

"She's my twin sister - I know we don't look alike but we still feel identical."
"What's the best part about being a twin?"
"It's probably true with having a regular sibling but it's like you're living with your best friend...we do have that twin connection though- the extra 9 months gives us that edge!"

"My father dropped me off here a few months ago and I haven't seen him since, but I meet my mother every other day. I tell her everything - my fears, my dreams and my worries because she's my best friend. I cannot wait to see the look on her face when I become a doctor."
"What is your biggest fear?"
"I won't end up finding love."

"I am the youngest boy at this school, but I love coming here. I feel like we are one big family because I have older brothers who will always protect me. When I grow old I want to be like The Hulk - I want to be big and protect everyone around me so that no one will trouble us again."
"We were four siblings, but two of my sisters died of HIV. Sometimes I miss them, but sometimes I feel they are in a better place."

"A few months ago, I took my mother to a hospital that provides free treatment because she was suffering from a stomach infection. While we were there, a foreigner came up to my mother and offered to buy her kidneys. Thinking that it'll fetch us a hefty sum, she agreed to meet him at the clinic he mentioned. When we went there two days later, we saw from outside that it wasn't a clinic; it was just a run down warehouse in a secluded area. I don't know how I convinced my mother to run away from there, but I can't tell you how glad I am that we did. Can you tell me if it's possible to survive without our kidneys?"

(Due to the sensitive background of these children, their teachers and the Humans of Bombay team together felt it best to not reveal their identities.)

"I see my mother every sunday. When I go home, she cooks food for me and I tell her what I've learnt through the week. Sometimes, she sits on the chair and looks sad - so I make funny faces and start acting like a monkey. She usually tells me to stop fooling around, so I jump around a little more and eventually she smiles and starts laughing at me. We play Ludo and Carrom till early morning and then she drops me back to school and I wait for sunday again. We both have big dreams for me. But before anything I want to learn to speak English. I want to go to London and speak English. I want to earn money and take my mother away from here, but I also want to become a 'didi' and help those like me."

#StoriesfromKamathipura

While city lights make a picturesque view for the most of us, there's an alternate reality beating strong in the heart of our city where the descending lights spell 'taboo'. Humans of Bombay, embraced Kamathipura; the women, the children and the spectators to bring to you stories that are humbling and life changing all at once. While it may be a while before sex trade is completely eradicated, we can start of by taking a step into their world, bereft of any judgement. More human than all of us put together - the children of these sex workers opened up to our team to show us, what can be only a fragment of their harsh reality. The coming week is dedicated to these children and their world, but most importantly to their undying spirit to smile through it all. 

A big thank you to the team at Prerana Anti-Human Trafficking who are doing an incredible job of relentlessly caring and educating these children in the heart of Kamathipura and Le15 Patisserie for generously giving these children another reason to smile :)

Humans of Bombay - let's see the love!

"What's the point of hiding who you are? For example, I work as a Branding Manager for a cigarette company and I meet hundreds of people everyday who are just not comfortable with who they are.  Small things- people claim to not smoke and you will find that they smoke already - just not in the open. Maybe that's why people are so cautious while trusting others; you think you know someone but chances are you only know what's been put on."

"I'm here today because of all the hard work I've put in. They kept saying that the government will give us aid - but we received nothing. It's a good thing that I realized early that our 'Sarkar' is only for name sake - no one really cares. I've worked 23 hours a day to feed my family and to educate my children.
 Sometimes you cannot live your own dreams - so you live your dream through your children. My son has completed his MBA and has a proper job where he has earned his own respect, despite being the son of an ordinary fruit seller. That's why I carry his business card around- to remind myself that my dream is still alive through him."

We were lucky to catch what looked like a celebratory moment between these two. Later when we got to speaking with them, they told us that they had just been chased by the cops because they were doing a photoshoot for their wedding video and photography wasn't allowed everywhere. 
As for their story - it's a classic. From being best friends for 7 years, to liking each other, to dating, and finally to an entirely new beginning with a beautiful marriage in Goa!
Humans of Bombay's first fairytale moment!

"You don't realize how attached you are to gadgets, technology and social media until it hits you. I lost my phone in the train last week, and for the two days that I didn't have my phone I was just zonked. After that though it felt great to not have something constantly buzzing every 2 minutes. It's not like I didn't get myself another phone- I just don't care enough about checking it all the time. Disconnection is sometimes for the best- you should give it a try."

"I started my business out of this slum. Over the last 25 years I've made maybe 10 lakh dosas. The most fun is when a regular client says he wants to try something new and there's no better joy than seeing people lick their fingers, smile at you, and ask you "Boss thoda aur chutney please."

"What do you want to be when you grow up?"
"I've already grown up - I'm 5 years old. I can do shaving and flossing!"
[His mother: "He's 3."]
"No! I'm 5!"

"I've been doing this for close to 13 years now. Some days are good - other days there are no fish. Mother Nature has her ways though- she gets you by. Just like the waves, sometimes you're up and sometimes you're down, but most of the times we're lucky to float by just right."

This one night, when I was 14, I remember hearing my parents scream at each another. The next day, when I woke up, I asked my mother what had happened. She said that they had gotten into a fight and dad had left home because he was angry. I remember calling him to ask him to come home for lunch, when he said that he wasn't coming home at all - it was that easy for him. I used to want to see him for most of my teenage years, but now when I think of how he just left like that, I can't see him anymore."

"After my first two relationships ended, it took me a while to trust again - I guess it was the fear of people walking away from my life that made me cautious. Things are different now though - I'm finally in a relationship where that fear's no longer there - but she's all the way in Rotterdam! I mean we have technology, but no amount of FaceTime or Skype can replace actually being with her. I just need to see her now - she's the one and I'm not letting her go."

"When I was 16, I trained for the Armed Forces. Soon after, I was conscripted for the Royal Indian Navy to fight in the war. Before I knew it, I was on a ship to Yangon, to fight the Japanese in World War II. We were victorious, but when you see nothing but dead bodies floating around in the water -there is very little to celebrate. I thought I was finally going to get home - but instead I was in the Atlantic, fighting Nazi U-Boats. My job included counting the number of ships that had sunk by the end of the day, but I somehow survived those Nazi torpedoes as well. My ship then took us to the Ethiopian coast to to fight Hitler's Afrika Korps. 
When finally the war ended, and I was sure they would take me home, Karachi, our base - was no longer part of India. I was locked up in a Karachi prison for a while, until a British officer who recognized me from our Boxing Club days managed to free me. The people leaving Karachi could either choose a bus to Delhi or to Lahore. I, by chance, chose the Delhi bus. To me, it was like taking any other bus because I never imagined the Partition the way it happened. I mean Indians and Pakistanis - we're the same people. In fact, so much violence was prevented during the Partition because the officers, who were then separated by two countries, were once brothers fighting for a common cause - an Independent India."

I am a Fakir and I've had a beautiful life, devoid of materialism. From the age of 12 to 36, I didn't use any mode of transport - wherever I went, I went by foot; and that was the best decision of my life. The things I've experienced, you would never even see while sitting in your air conditioned car. In this process, I might not have gotten a degree, but I'm educated - most people don't know the difference."
"What have you finally drawn from all these years of devotion?"
"We go through life, looking for God and seeking his help in tough times, when in fact God is in our hearts- he can never take a man form. God is only one light, and that light is driving the world. You don't understand that when the birds cry at 4 am, they are trying to awaken you to his arrival. But the most important thing of all is, that he has given each of us the full power for our individual lives - you don't need God to save you; you are the entire Universe, radiating in a body form."

"I don't want to get into the past, but I'm trying to hold onto the belief that the best is yet to come. Life is unpredictable for that reason - only when it unfolds, can you look back and realize that it was all part of the process and it worked out for the best."

"I used to be an engineer, but I felt like I wasted 16 years of my life trying to match up to the competition, the ridiculous marking system and the salary expectations."
"What do you do now?"
"I organize a festival in Goa, where people have installations that combine art and science. The theme this year is Light. The reason is simple - apart from being a 'life giver', light in itself defies the laws of physics on different levels - from holding different forms and having different characteristics to being an intersection between Science and Spirituality."
"What have you learnt from this experience?"
"No one can really stop learning. You just need to be open and find out where you stand in this whole range of information. But it doesn't just happen like that - you need to be able to say, 'fuck this corporate world' to   actually be able to see the 'light' - pun intended!"

"When my baby brother was 6 months old, he fell from a height of 10 feet and survived with just a fracture on his right arm. The doctor said he was lucky to not have had any internal bleeding. It worries me that we still have to use that staircase but what choice do we have? I just make sure I'm there every time he has to use it."

"The most trying time in my life was when my best friend committed suicide."
"How did you manage to cope with it?"
"Music. I spent literally two whole days in my room doing nothing but playing the guitar. It's something that just makes me feel better. Music has been with me since the last 10 years and I'm just turning 14."

"I've seen people being killed in front of my eyes. During partition, I was in Punjab and truck loads of dead bodies would pass us by- daily. Even though it was a trying time, we Indians had more civic sense back then. Today, a rich man will not hesitate before cheating a poor man- the brotherhood has left us. If you ask me India needs another Freedom Movement to actually be liberated from corruption and to make real progress."

"What struck us first was that Bombay is a very violent city. I'm talking only about the local trains we use when we go to work. It's quite scary at times, but we love it - especially the quiet moments. As students of urbanism, we're supposed to study about all this. In this city, we've seen people living in huge buildings next to slums, then people living in slums next to homeless people, and homeless people living near shit. This is nothing like what's in the books."

"6 years ago, I lost my child right after delivery and I haven't been able to conceive since. While everyone around me seems to be fighting over money or land, I look at them and think of how blessed they are to have beautiful children and how much they have to be grateful for- besides not having to go through something like this. 6 years and the pain still hasn't left me."

"Back in 1943 during World War II, a British captain came to me and said "give me your restaurant keys, we need it for administration purposes. We'll return it to you once the war is over" - and they did. That's what I miss about the British and their administration. Had this happened today I would have to bribe and what not to get Britannia and Co. back. I'm hopeful, however, that things will change with the new government and NaMo."
"Have you ever stood up against something that you thought was wrong?"
"During the Quit India movement my good friend Subhash Chandra Bose and I went to Gandhi to voice our opinion about the partition. We were some of the few Indians who didn't want the Hindu and Muslim divide, irrespective of a Free India. Gandhi had his eye set though. His exact words were "What if I die tomorrow? I want to see a free India today." I still feel if we had more patience we might have gotten freedom a little late but we would be a United India."
"When would you say you were the happiest?"
"Of course I was overjoyed when we got freedom, but the happiness I felt when when I married my wife - I can't explain. It was part-love part-arranged but what a woman she was! She was a lawyer and a very good one - but she quit her job eventually and came here to the restaurant. All these dishes are her recipes. We were married 45 years and then she left me. Everyday I feel her presence in all the food we make. Don't get me wrong, I'm 92 and hoping to live till 114 so that I can beat my grand father's record - but I still miss her. Everyday."

"We have a small box at home, where we put away a part of my husband's salary every month towards our children and their education. After all our daily expenses, the amount we saved was very little."
"How did you begin doing this?"
"My entire neighborhood loves my tea! Every afternoon, someone or the other would come home and say, 'Chaachi make some of your special tea.' Finally, I decided one day that I can actually make some money out of it and add to my children's education fund as well - why should all the pressure fall on my husband? Today, he's the one who proudly says - 'my wife make's the best tea in all of Bombay!'"

"I always feel like my life is in order when I match my underwear - it's true! Today I met my childhood friend after ages. We retraced our old route: causeway shopping, Theo's, Stop 'n' Shop guy. I don't know how to explain, but I just like believing in little things. They make my days better."

"When I was in school everyone told me that I was too dark and that I wasn't good looking. They told me I could never become a model, so I pushed myself to this point where I've proved them all wrong." 
"What have you learnt through modelling?"
"I can't exactly pinpoint what I've learnt. But, I can tell you that I've had many life-changing ups and downs. When I first came to Bombay I slept on the road for one night because I got ditched by someone. I woke up the next day and returned to Delhi. I decided to come back to Bombay only when I deserved it and got my calling. It's the law of attraction that works when everyday you know that this is what you're made for. Two and a half years later, I think I've finally got that calling."

"We met 3 years ago, but she left college after just a few days. Post that, we both got really busy with our lives and didn't have the time to keep in touch. I mean we had each other on social networks - but that was it. You caught us on a great day...we literally just met today, right now- 5 minutes ago after 3 whole years!"

"We both work at the hotel and that's where we first met, but we didn't speak in person for a while after that."
"What happened then?"
"Once we did start talking we realized we balance each other out. I'm hyper, loud and talkative while he's calm, patient and a great listener. Like today, I've had a really bad day and I wanted to get done with work as soon as possible so I could talk about it and vent to him."
"So are you two dating?"
"...Not yet."

"We met through mutual friends and we started talking via Snapchat. It's been a while since we've been dating now."
"What do you think best defines your relationship?"
"Our parents have been against us dating because we come from different religions, but we've never let that matter. It's not out of disrespect really; we just can't help being together."

"Bombay jisko deta hein, acche se deta hein - warna kuch nahi deta."

("Bombay either gives you everything or gives you nothing at all.")

"We just celebrated Friendship's day."
"Wasn't that yesterday?"
"These girls have too many permission issues - they couldn't meet us yesterday so we pushed it to today."
"What did you do?"
"We decided to go a little old school and give friendship bands another go.   It never hurts to relive a little bit of your childhood!"

"I tend to procrastinate a lot, as a result of which I struggle with time management."
"In what way do you want to manage your time better?"
"I want to give more time to my family. It was after my grandmother developed cancer that I realised that even though everyone's time is limited, we don't actively try giving that extra bit for the relationships that matter."

"I went to Mantralaya to make a complaint." 
"Regarding?"
"It's been years since I applied for my Ration and PAN cards and two years since I applied for my Aadhar card; I still don't have any. This time they told me to make a written complaint, but I can't read or write. I'm going to back to my village now and not coming back."

In the era of advanced gaming technologies, this young man was found cutting pieces of marble to make a model of a home he eventually wants to live in. 
"Ek din mera bhi marble ka ghar hoga!" 
("One day, I'll also live in a marble house!")

"As a marine engineer, I was out at sea for nine months a year for nearly 40 years of my life. Name the port and I've travelled there, literally. This one time we had to survive a collision between two 100,000 ton ships. I remember being pretty happy as we sailed away after a life threatening situation. But, do you want to know where the real happiness was? It's what I felt when I saw my family after an entire year...the feeling was even sweeter than surviving that collision."

Street Survivor Stories:
We found these 2 when the older brother was helping the younger one cross the street and their mother was selling flowers nearby. When we asked them what they wanted to become in life, the older one said he wanted to wash clothes and clean houses. This is the conversation that ensued:
"You know you can become something bigger. Do you go to school?" 
"I left school when the rain started."
"Why?"
"I don't have an umbrella, and we have to walk for an hour to get to school."
As soon as he realized we were thinking of how we could help him out, he said -
"Three umbrellas please. One for this brother, one for other brother, one for me."

You can find them at the signal outside Wilson College around 3pm.

"The happiest I've ever been was when I got divorced. It's not as serious as people make it sound you know? It just didn't work out!"
"Did you ever remarry?"
"You never make the same mistake twice! Marriage, no; girlfriends, yes. Speaking of which, can you put up an advertisement of some sort, for me?"
"Sure, what would you want us to put in that?"
"82 year old man looking for a girlfriend under the age of 80. Even 2 forties will do. Open to all religions. House with a sea view is an added benefit. And don't forget to caption it."
"What would you want the caption to be?"
"The Experienced Bachelor. Put that in bold."

"When we were dating, he randomly called me up and said 'come down, we'll get ice-cream.' I literally got down in my pyjamas and a few minutes later I found myself at his house, in front of his entire family as he introduced me as 'the girl he's going to marry' - and this was just our third date!"
"What's the best part about her?"
"Before we got married, I showed her my wallet and said, 'today I have no money, but I'm going to make it really big one day'. She stuck by me through all of that, and now here we are today."
"And the best part about your relationship?"
"Our love has carried on in ways we couldn't imagine. 30 years later, our son followed our footsteps and brought home the girl he wanted to marry in exactly the same way!"

"I decided to stand here with a message everyday, after I attended a world religion conference. Every speaker there spoke so beautifully, but I felt that such a small number of people were getting to hear what was being said. The idea came to me when I wasn't allowed to stand in line to receive blessings at a church. I was also given looks when I went to pray at a mosque. I saw that some Hindu temples say 'Hindus only' and the Parsi fire temple at Churchgate doesn't allow non-parsis. That's when I realized that we all just make big talk, but when it comes to humanity we all shut our doors to others, in the name of religion. 
I've been doing this for 6 years to bring that humanity back. People have even complained about me doing this, but at the end of the day I'm still here and close to 3 lakh people have waved and smiled back at me since I started, including those who complained. That, in my eyes, is a victory of humanity over the devils that live inside each of us."
"There was no water at the beginning of this season, and that is disaster for vegetable vendors like myself. But ever since Ramzan started, it has rained heavily. Like always, Allah has been kind."

"The first time he saw me getting out of a taxi with my granny he asked his mother whether she knew us and when she said yes, he said 'I have to marry that girl someday'. This was when I was all of 14. After that, he took it upon himself to try and accidentally 'bump into me' at every opportunity he got."
"When did you finally say yes?"
"1 year after he saw me, he asked me for a dance at the Sophia College Social and I finally said yes. After he convinced me, he went straight to my parents and asked for my hand in marriage. They sent him packing - calling him a 'cradle snatcher' but he never gave up. After 5 years of asking the same question he finally wore them out and they relented! That's when we got married and it's been 57 years since."

"I've always wanted to be like my father. Not only because of his personality, but also because of the kind of role he's played in my life. He's the kind of dad I'd like to be to my children someday."

"I've worked in Real Estate since a year and a half."
"What's the best part about that?"
"It feels good to be at pace or sometimes even ahead of men in this particular line. I've challenged the norm that only men can do the field work - I'm more than capable of going out there and doing it myself!"

"Speaking is the biggest aid. People complain about different situations in their life but when you ask them if they've spoken to the concerned people, whether its about a relationship or a job promotion - they'll say something like 'no' or 'what's the point'? The point is this - If you feel like you deserve that promotion and haven't made any attempt to make that known, or if you like someone but are scared by the prospect of a no - you will never know and by keeping things to yourself, you eliminate any possibility of all these great things happening to you."
"The trains are really dirty especially during the rain, but atleast I'm not alone...she's always there to make time pass by quickly and make me laugh."

"I've been a mentor for a year to an 11 year old girl through the Light House Project and I'm moving into my 2nd year soon."
"What has the experience been like?"
"Surreal. The funny part is I teach her education related things, but I've learnt so much about life from her. At 11 she's constantly living life on the edge, without knowing what the future holds for her in terms of education or the security of a home- but she doesn't complain. She's changed me - I've become a much calmer, composed person because I think of how my behavior would affect her and whether I'm being someone she can actually look upto." 
"What's the best part about her?"
"Her smile has the power to light up a million hearts!"

"There comes a stage where you just have to cut out all the negativity from your life."
"Have you managed to do that successfully?"
"Yes and they were difficult steps. I've cut out a friend who I've known for almost 20 years because I realized that even though I wasn't complaining, everything he would complain about added so much negativity to my life. We tried for years to make him see the light, but it didn't work. It's at these times that you realize life passes you by quickly and if you surround yourself with negative energy that's what you will attract forever."
"Are you happy?"
"I have mixed emotions- ofcourse it isn't easy to let go of someone who's been in your life for that long, but overall today I feel like I'm always happy and attracting the right energies."

"I maintain and repair aircrafts. You know, the landing gear, the engines, everything that keeps the plane in the air."
"Do you enjoy what you do?"
"I do. Although, it's a huge responsibility knowing that there is no margin for error, because the work I do either maintains or threatens the safety of everyone on the plane."
"What would you change about your job, if you could?"
"The working hours. Having 15 hour shifts gives you no time to socialize or work out. I feel like life will run by you before you know it and if you spend all your time at work it isn't going to be worth it. After all, who doesn't like coming home at a decent hour, firing up the the television and enjoying a chilled beer?"
"I can't explain what it feels like, when every morning she wakes up and  the first thing she calls out is 'mumma'."

"I'm a professional diver"
"Do you have any interesting stories you wouldn't mind sharing with us?"
" There are so many...I've swum with a killer whale...oh wait! Once while I was diving, my mask cracked. The funny thing is that I didn't even realize until the dive was over. I came up to the surface and my face was covered in blood. The cut was right here"
"Weren't you scared?"
"No, In fact it made me realize just how much I love diving and the underwater world. I was so happily oblivious, even when I came up I was smiling...until I saw the panicked faces of my colleagues. I was bleeding so badly - they thought I was attacked by a shark!"

"For how long have you been friends?"
"Not too long...about 15 years."
"That's long."
"We come from a generation where relationships last decades...so 15 years isn't as long."

"I was traveling to Pune on the anniversary of the Intercity Express when I saw this group having a party literally on the train- with music, alcohol and dancing. It wasn't the party which had an impact but the larger than life attitude of the people which did. Just watching from the outside, I felt like we bother about so many petty details and here these people weren't bothered about the place or the situation - they were just making their own party as they went along."

"People need to embrace the idea of making mistakes - it's only if you're open to making mistakes that you'll take more chances."
"What kind of mistakes do you make?"
"We're artists- we make the most creative ones!"

"I have to break my fast in half an hour."
"For how long have you been observing Ramzan?"
"It's been so many years...I don't even remember when my first Roza was."
"Do you feel tired?"
"This doesn't make you weak, it only makes you stronger."

("Aadhe ghante mein Roza todna hein."
"Aap yeh kabse kar rahe ho?"
"Itne saal ho gaye aab yaad bhi nahi hein ki pehla Roza kab tha"
"Aap thak nahi jaate?"
"Ramzan hame kamzor nahi banata - hame mazboot banaata hein")

"He was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease three months ago. We don't know how it happened really - one day he was fine, running his business and the next thing we knew he had it."
"Where is his family?"
"He doesn't have any. I'm his caretaker, I'm his family."

"Today you chase a Lamborghini, tomorrow a Ferrari and day after something else and it's the same with anything materialistic. What we don't realise is that in the process of making these elaborate bucket lists and chasing luxuries we lose people and fail to touch lives; you're surrounded by all these materialistic things with the most empty feeling inside."

"We take off about 3 months a year to travel, but we don't go to the conventional tourist places. The last place we went was Mongolia which is a huge country with few people - basically barely any human imprints on their soil."
"Why do you pick these places?"
"There's beauty in the unconventional. Our best experience has been living with nomads and following their lifestyle. Nothing compares to that really...we finally knew what it was like to feel free."
It took a huge effort to distract them from playing in the water, but they finally did stop to give us a smile and say- "acche din aa gaye!"

"I've been here since 4:30pm and I've only made Rs.25 till now." (It was 7:30pm at that point.)
"What will you do now?"
"I'm trying everything to make ends meet - I even walk everywhere with this stand, in the rain. Nobody wants channa, what can I do now? The monsoons bring a very difficult time."

("Mein yahaan 4:30 baje se hoon, aur abhi tak sirf pacchis rupiye kamaaye hein."
"Ab aap kya karoge?"
"Mein paise kamane ke liye sab kuch kar rahaan hoon - sab jagah iss stand ke saath, is baarish mein chal ke jaata hoon. Kissi ko channa nahi chahiye, toh mein kya kar sakta hoon? Baarish mein bahut pareshani hoti hein.")

"I recently traveled to Europe, and I saw an entirely different world. The smallest of things there were so different. For example, while I was in France I don't recall hearing a single honk on the road and it was so peaceful! In India especially, we need those things which bring Peace - no matter how small they are."

"They say any woman who dates a Chef is lucky...but they don't realize that those women realize rather quickly that dating a Chef only means long boring work hours with no holidays and no birthday celebrations - that's a real struggle!"

"A year ago a really close cousin passed away and I wish someone had told me earlier that it's important to slow down and stop running.  Everyone knows that life is short, but you don't understand the importance of giving as much love today, until something like this happens."

"I've been at this shop since Indira Gandhi's assassination."
"Where were you during Emergency?"
"I was right here. It was during that time that many people told me to stay at home because I'd be killed in the anti-Sikh riots. I was scared but then I knew that if I stayed at home I wouldn't be able to support myself...so I continued to do what I had to."
"Is there any particular incident which has left a mark on you?"
"I had one close friend back then. During the riots he asked me not to visit him again...and I haven't seen him since."

"I'm a photographer as well as an Interior Designer."
"Which one do you prefer?"
"Honestly, photography. It's allowed me to travel and explore more than anything else."
"Is there something all the traveling has taught you?"
"Everywhere you go people have different tastes and different mindsets. Amidst all those differences there's one universal fact which is that the world is too fast and the only way to move forward without losing yourself is to find your own speed."
"I've been born and brought up here, but I don't feel like being a part of civilization. I don't think I can explain it to you, but I'm just off limits to this society."

"I work with an NGO that handles rescued sex trafficking victims. We believe in creating equal opportunities for those who've been sexually abused and healing them."
"What's the one thing that keeps you going?"
"Sacrifice. We've closely aligned ourselves with the teachings of Jesus where he sacrificed himself for the sins of man. We give up higher salaries and opportunities which can further our careers or lifestyles to cleanse the brutality of other men."
"What's the best part of working on a project like this?"
"I've never felt closer to God."

"We've grown up together and somewhere along the way we just started dating."
"Can you think of your fondest memory as a group?"
[Guy in the denim shirt with sunglasses]- I can tell you a memory that's more like a nightmare. My girlfriend [girl on the right] and my best friend here hated one another, till the point where they couldn't stand being around each other. Imagine balancing your best friend and your girlfriend - I had to move mountains to make them friends! Touch wood quickly - I don't want to take the risk of jinxing it ever again!"

"My friends and I look after these dogs- 13 of them here and a few at Marine Drive. We make it a point to give them 2 meals a day and treat the injuries they get because of activities like stone pelting." 
"How did you initially start doing this?"
"When I came to Bombay 2 years ago, I barely had any friends. These two right here were the first friends I made in the city. I got into this to protect my friends."

"I'm an exchange student from Canada."
"What's the experience been like?"
"I feel like India is a country made up of many smaller countries - where every city  is completely different from the other. I've tried so many different kinds of food and seen such different cultures- it's surreal."
"What about the people?"
"When I was studying in Delhi, every weekend I would travel to a different city or village, but mostly alone. I feel like the people are so warm but they don't explore and travel that much. I know how important studying is, but I feel like the people I've met prioritize it to an unhealthy extent. I've honestly learnt so much more outside the classroom...because India has that much to offer if you would only go out there and look!"

"Khaana nahi chahiye, kapde chahiye."
"Kyun?"
"Meri abhi abhi ek behen hui hein...uske liye chahiye."

("I don't want food, I want clothes."
"Why?"
"I just got a sister...I want it for her.")

"People advocate too many negative things. If we focus on just spreading happiness to whoever we can - we'll actually start making a difference, bit by bit."
"When was the last time you spread happiness in that way?"
"Right now. Aren't you happy I'm standing here in the rain, because it matters to you? It's small, but it makes a difference to you right? We try doing things in these grand gestures, but in reality it's the little things that spread the most happiness."

He works as a horse-cart driver and has 'picked up' a large chunk of the Italian, Arabic and English languages from the tourists he's been serving for the past 20 years. He went on to proudly demonstrate translating a few sentences in those languages. Here's the conversation that followed-
"Did you ever try getting a job?"
"English is good, but no degree -so no one wants to hire."
"Are you happy?"
"Some people are jolly, some are grumpy and bargain for money- but l'm happy-happy."

We recently featured a young girl who spent a large amount of money to buy herself a dog (without telling her parents). Based on the large number of people who found it insensitive and illogical to spend that kind of money on her dog, when she could have easily adopted a stray - we decided to post this.
This girl has been caring for this stray dog - including paying for his vaccinations and 2 meals a day - everyday since the past three years. Last month she even got bitten by him, but she continues to care for him till the present day.
She would have loved to adopt a stray,but foundations like YODA insisted on a house inspection before doing so and because her parents didn't want a pet - it wasn't possible.
We aren't advocating any form of breeding, but portraying a different side of the same story and hoping we negate some of that negativity with these lesser known facts.
link_name: Photos from Humans of Bombay's post

status_message:
"I'm struggling to be an officer in the Navy."
"What's keeping you going?"
"The traveling. I've learnt so much from all the different places I've been to."
"What's the best place so far?"
"I've been to so many beautiful places...but I still feel like I haven't seen any beauty like Kashmir."
"What people think about you is none of your business. Ignore what they have to say and keep doing what you have to anyway."

"My biggest dream was to get a dog, so I guess Sherlock here made that possible."
"When did you get him?"
"I actually got him without telling my parents - it was a risk I took because I assumed that they wouldn't be cruel enough to tell me to give him away once he was there."
"How did you manage the entire process?"
"My neighbor and I contacted breeders from all over and once we narrowed down on him we realized we needed Rs.20,000 before 25th of April. We would say we're going to the mall for lunch and not eat, take money for movies and not go...we raised the entire amount in 12 days."
"What about your mother?"
"She'll never admit it but she's in love with him and can't do without him!"

"I don't have a favorite subject. I guess I like speech and drama."
"Why?"
"I find other subjects really boring, speech and drama is more open."
"What sport do you like?"
"I don't like sports either. Well, does an indoor sport count?"
"Yes."
"Then Chess...maybe I'll be a Chess Grandmaster."

"My husband recently passed away."
"How are you handling that?"
"I really miss him a lot and I thought it would be a lot harder because we have three daughters, but they've infact taken care of me - right from managing our home to running the business...they've had everything under control."

"There's been a shift in perspective lately. People need to start caring a little more - start with your dog, your neighbors, your parents and family and move on to care about people you don't know, or who can't do anything for you."
"When was the last time you cared for someone like that?"
"There are these two little underprivileged brothers at Marine Drive - I take them out for lunch often. It's not so much about the lunch as it is about speaking to them and hearing them out. You don't have to care from your pockets."
"Have there been past experiences that make you think like this?"
"When you're young and rebellious- everything get's on your nerves. You may care about people - but don't necessarily show it and you just tend to take people for granted. That's the worst, because you do end up losing them."
"What do you feel people need to do more?"
"I feel like we need to propagate caring rather than propagate doing. All our lives we've taken from Earth but we don't give back. You don't need to start a big movement- just don't throw shit outside your car. You judge people living in slums because they live in dirt, but how are you any different if you do the same?
Recently, I saw a cop at Chowpatty spit paan outside his car. I got off and created the biggest scene - I actually made him apologize to the road. At the end of it he still spat and polluted - but I made sure atleast something got into his fucking head to think twice before doing it the next time."

Hello everyone,

We've recently been getting several emails and messages regarding the comments on the page and the harshness that stems from some of them. We understand that this is an open forum, where people are entitled to their own opinions and beliefs (which we highly respect), but It's only fair of us to ask you guys to show a little more compassion towards people who are sharing incidents/experiences of value to them, with us. 

We've been asked to take down several portraits because the subjects in them have felt 'judged'. We received a message that said, the comments had caused a certain subject 'mental trauma'.
Humans of Bombay does not want to associate with such negativity. We want to work towards making you feel connected to the people in the city - no matter what their story is because ultimately it isn't easy to share parts of their life with people at large.

As much as we love the comments and the healthy arguments that ensue, we request you to think before directly attacking the person in the picture and taking swings at their personal life from an external view. 

Hoping you spread more love and light,
Humans of Bombay.

We found this little one exuberantly jumping all over the place because someone decided to give her left overs. We originally stopped to take the photograph because she was feeding the left overs to her mother, but because her mother was too shy to take the picture she jumped up, came forward, smiled for the camera and said 'thank you' atleast 10 times once we took the picture.

"We met around Feb this year and we were married soon after."
"When did you know she was the one?"
"I knew when I met her the first few times itself. Everything about her appealed to me - her attitude towards everyone around her, her kindness, her warmth and just her cuteness!"
"When did you know he was the one?"
"To be honest, I only knew once he told me, I was the one.'"
"He just waits for me to fall asleep and as soon as I do, he'll come and curl up next to my feet. If anyone even tries to wake me up - he goes crazy barking at them!"

"I had no interest in technology until we discovered how quickly she ate while the iPad played the right game or the right song. Do you know that there are actually apps now to make feeding babies easier while developing their minds at the same time?"

"I miss working everyday. I used to work as the Technical Director at GSK India. I joined in 1963 and retired in 1987."
"Is there anything in particular which made the journey special?"
"It's all to do with progress. At one stage I myself had handpicked over 1500 employees who reported to me and I look back and feel blessed to have had that kind of respect."
"What about your family?"
"I have two beautiful children and many grand children but my wife passed away in 2003. She was a beautiful woman. I remember, we had to move to a factory location around 1966 because I was setting it up and I asked her if she was okay with it. Had she said no, I would have declined going but she agreed within a second to leave Bombay and move to this remote place. 
I remember being so moved that day because I'd heard of placing other's needs before your own when in love, but it was then that I understood what a powerful emotion it actually is."

"What do you do?"
"I'm into making French cinema. I recently turned 21 and I wanted to travel to experience a different lifestyle and culture. I picked India because it's rich in both and I had the opportunity to assist in the making of a Bollywood movie as well."
"How was that experience?"
"Bollywood movies portray a different side of India, atleast the one's I've seen. I went deep into the villages of the North and so many sights broke my heart. Even France has villages with poor people but It's different here - everyone has so much warmth despite the poverty. This one man took me to his house to introduce me to his family and offered me food which he could barely afford. Your heart aches to reach out."
"If you could do something for these people, what would you do?"
"Just share time. I feel like more than anything else they just want your compassion. I don't speak Hindi, but sometimes you make your own language; one that's without words and filled with limitless emotions."

"We've been friends for over 20 years now. We're actually 4 friends, the fourth one isn't here right now."
"What's the fondest memory of your friendship?"
"There's no such 'fondest memory', but we go for dinner often - just the 4 of us, without our wives. They're too fussy with everything, so we don't ask them to join us. Today we're sitting here, tomorrow we'll be gone...if we keep waiting for our wives, we'll be waiting till we're no longer here!"

"I went from Dalal street to this street."
"What happened?"
"There's just no money. The west keeps telling you that the money will come back, but it isn't. The problem is we're still trying to build on our bread and butter for us to even think beyond that. The US doesn't even look at agriculture - it's all technology and everything to get the 'luxury' quotient up. It's supposed to be simple where you make a kill out of the difference between supply and demand - but it's not."
"What do you feel people find most difficult to do during these times?"
"Raise their voice for something. I've been here for 2 years just trying to sell delicious food on the street but I still don't have all the necessary licenses. They try and mute you with all these laws but in reality they just want you to be sucked into their corporate trap so they can benefit from it. I'm selling food, not arms."
"What advice would you give people?"
"Go back to the soil, to your roots. Go Eastern- the Western shit is fucked up...it's not working and never will."

"Are you two dating?"
"No, he's my ex. We've actually met today after 3 years."
"What happened back then?"
"I moved away to study and it didn't work out."
"So how come you guys met today?"
"We always came here to just walk in the rain and we spoke today after years, so we thought why not?"

"I'm a single mother. What can I say...people change sometimes and things just don't work out."
"What's the most difficult part about being a single mother?"
"Doubling up as both parents and not letting your child ever feel the lack of love."
"What's the best part?"
"Once you've lost that one person you actually do grow and evolve and realize that if you shift your focus there are so many people who are backing you. But more than any of that, it's that you know in your heart you're the one person who will kill and die for your child."
"If you could give a piece of advice to your child, what would it be?"
"Do not let anyone take away from your peace. When you're at peace, all positive forces come with it. If there's ever something that takes away from that peace - do what it takes to walk away."

"I have 4 daughters and 2 sons."
"Where are they?"
"Back in my village."
"How often do you see them?"
"I live here for 1 year and then the next entire year I spend with them, while my brother overlooks the Dhobi business."
"Isn't that tough?"
"Not when you know it's for your children - all of them today are educated and all four of my daughters married."

("Mere chaar ladki aur do ladke hein."
"Kahaan hein?"
"Gaon mein."
Aap unhe kab milte ho?"
"Mein ek saal yahaan rehta hoon aur agle pure saal unke saath rethta hoon. Dhobi ka kaam bhai sambhalta hein."
"Woh mushkil nahi hein?"
"Sab bacchon ke liye hein - aaj woh sab padhe likhe hein aur charo beti ki shaadi ho chuki hein.")

"Being a woman is difficult."
"When was the last time you felt like it was difficult?"
"Everyday."
"So what do you do about it?"
"Carry on."

"I've been working here for around 20 years now. A few months ago I got Malaria but never fully recovered but because I couldn't afford prolonged doctor services - I kept relapsing. A doctor has been coming to the park regularly for a few years and he saw me sitting down (because of the pain) a few weeks ago and asked what happened. He then prescribed some medicines for me and keeps checking on me - all on his own accord and I haven't relapsed since then. When I first moved here, they told me the city has no time to stop and no heart...but the doctor proved them all wrong."

("Mein yahaan 20 saal se kaam kar raha hoon. Kuch mahine pehle mujhe Malaria hua aur mere puri tarah ilaaj nahi ho paya. Ek doctor sahaab hein jo bahut saal se park mein aate hein aur kuch hafto pehle unhonhe pujhe dard mein dekha aur mujhe dawai likh kar di aur check karte rahe. Uss din se mein bimar nahi pada. Jab mein yahaan aaya that logon ne kahaan tha ki yeh sheher ka dil nahi hein...par doctor Sahaab ne galaat saabit kar diya.")

"It's impossible to pick just one 'best' memory - when everything she does touches you."
"How does it feel to watch her grow?"
"Honestly...I'm trying to learn to be detached."
"Why is that?"
"Sometimes its better to be detached from the beginning because you never know - you're here today and gone tomorrow. "

"Mein ab 95 saal ka hoon, 40 saal se taxi chala raha hoon."
"Aap azadi ke waqt kahan the?"
"Mein Gaon mein tha. Uss waqt itni mehengai nahi thi - itni mehnat nahi karni padti thi."
"Aapke bachhe kamate nahi?"
"Ek beta hein - kamata hein, lekin uske bhi chaar bacche hein. Uske saare paise baccho ko school bhejne mein aur ghar chalane mein chale jaate hein. Agar zinda rehna hein, toh kaam toh karna hi padega. 95 ka hoon, bahut thak jaata hoon, par aur kya chara?"

("I'm 95 years old now and I've been driving this cab for 40 years."
"Where were you during Independence?"
"I was in my village. At that time it wasn't so expensive - you didn't have to work so hard to feed yourself."
"Do your children earn?"
"I have a son who earns, but he has 4 children to send to school. All his money goes into their education and running the house. If I have to survive, I have to work. I'm 95 and get extremely tired...but what other option do I have?")

"I've lived in Bombay for 67 years and watched it go from bad to worse."
"Why do you say that?"
"When I was your age I used to walk freely with my girlfriend at 2am from Taj Mahal to Warden Road. I've taken a tanga from Nariman point at odd hours...alone if need be. Can you do that today? Forget unsafe, cops can  pick you up for anything - even if you're holding hands with your girlfriend - It's such bullshit!"

"I've been doing this for 10 years."
"Are you happy?"
"Yes, I'm very happy. It's because of this work that my children can go to school."
"If you could change something (anything), what would it be?"
"My life is okay, but from where I come from there is so much poverty. If the new Sarkar can do something to just give these people 2 meals a day and money to educate our children...because what is their fault? These children were born in poverty, but something needs to be done to make sure their whole life doesn't go away being poor."

("10 saal se yehi kar raha hoon."
"Aap khush hein?"
"Haan, bahut khush hoon. Issi kaam ke wajah se mere bachhe school jaa paate hein."
"Agar aap kuch badal sakte toh woh kya hota?"
"Hum toh theek hein beta, lekin humaare yahaan itni gareebi hein. Agar naye Sarkar kuch aisa kar sakhe ki do waqt ki roti aur bachhon ko school bhejne ke paise...aakhir unki kya galti? Woh gareebi mein paida hue iska matlab nahi ki woh sari zindagi gareebi mein hi rahe.")

When we first saw these two girls they were playfully trying to converse with a security guard who stood nearby. Usually we have to approach people, but they ran towards us and happily started a conversation. Here's how it went from there - 
"Where are your parents?" (Aapke Maa-baap kahan par hein?)
"They're dead." (Mar gaye.)
"Who do you stay with now?"(Toh aap kiske saath rehte ho?)
"With my granny, but she can't do much." (Dadi ke saath, par woh zyada kar nahi pati.)
"And money?" (Aur paise?)
At this point there was a silence, with the two girls just smiling shyly.To lighten the mood, we asked -
"What do you want to be when you grow up?" (aap bade hokar kya bana chahte ho)
"Ice-cream please!"

PS- I don't think there was even a second in this entire conversation, where the girls weren't larger than life and smiling.
"I'm at the stage in life where I don't know where my career's headed and I'm supposed to have it figured out by now...but I don't."

"Dabbewale ka kaam mein saath saal se kar raha hoon."
"Aapko yeh kaam achha lagta hein?"
"Haan, logon ko khaana pahucha raha hoon aur Bambai mein reh raha hoon, burai kya ho sakti hein?"
"Aapka pariwar?
"Ma-baap pune mein hein."
"Aur patni?"
"Kya aap bhi. Ab toh mein sirf 23 ka hoon aur khushi se maze kar raha hoon...woh sab ke liye bahut time hein!"

("I've been working as a Dabbawala for 7 years now."
"You like your job?"
"Yes, I give food to people and live in a city like Bombay, what's not to like?"
"And your family?"
"My parents are in Pune."
"And wife?"
"What marriage? I'm just 23 and enjoying life...there's a lot of time left for all that!")

"Dance is all I know. People say you can't make a lot of money in a field like this, but I would be miserable doing anything else."
"Who's your biggest inspiration?"
"Should I just do the move?"
"Go for it!"

There are certain people in this world who act like mirrors. They reflect every scar, every smile, every little gesture. And most importantly, every flaw. When I met this person I realized, Humans sail on the sea of greed. No matter what we have, we always want more. But there are certain people who are so selflessly content with what they have. He looked so happy with what he was doing. He accommodated himself so perfectly in that place. He was particularly remarkable amongst all other things. He said to me -
 ''We're artists too, you know. In our own right. We deserve to have the same creative freedom as that of a movie star. Tight rope walking requires the same amount of skill, focus and balance as any other art. And yet, nobody recognizes this. People give me money out of sympathy for the poor. I want them to simply enjoy my craft and reward that. But I don't have the freedom to make them realize this. I cannot refuse what they give me regardless of the sentiment behind their action. I have mouths to feed. I hope someday, instead of seeing a man who places his life in jeopardy for his family's food, people will see me for who I am- a talented craftsman simply performing his Art".

Story and Image by Soham Vaidya.

I found this girl on a 11:30 am Virar train -In the middle of the staircase, calm in chaos, with a henna cone in her hand, struggling to apply it on her palms.
Suddenly a middle aged man kicked her and told her to move. She moved herself to the corner of the staircase and as the 11:35 train arrived, she along with me got on to the 1st class ladies compartment. She sat on the floor of the train and continued to struggle to apply the henna. She looked over at me and smiled, I smiled back. I gestured to her to come next to me, she resisted but then agreed. There was no vocal conversation, just hand and face gestures. 
I took the cone from her hand and held her palm and manage to draw a flower. She kept looking at me with pursed lips and once I finished she smiled at me, nodded in approval and kept looking at her hand in awe. Since it was a fast local, the next stop was Bandra, a female police officer entered the compartment and told her to leave. She instantly sprung up, still looking at her hand, with the biggest smile on her face- and left the train. 

It was and will be one of the happiest days of my life which made me feel so grateful for what I have and at the same time made me realize that it isn't always about buying food or things for the under privileged - it's about the compassion you show toward them. 
That and the fact that sometimes the most touching of experiences come without any words. 

-Story and Image by Niharika Saraf.

We crossed 60K likes today and just as a BIG thank you we're taking submissions (only for tomorrow). Send in your High Res pictures with the captions to officialhob@gmail.com before 10 pm tomorrow, and we'll put up 2 of the best stories with credits. 

Thanks for the love - Humans of Bombay :)

"My mother passed away right after my delivery. Ever since then, my father and his parents have blamed me for her death. My entire youth went in feeling that guilt."
"How did you get out of it?"
"I decided that I had to yank myself out of this life. I got myself a job and stayed out of the house as much as possible."

("Mere janm ke baadh, meri maa mar gayi. Us time se mera pura parivaar manta hein ki woh meri wajah se mar gayi. Itne saal mujhe bhi aisa hi laga."
"Phir aapne kya kiya?"
"Mujhse yeh dosh saha nahi gaya. Maine naukri chalu ki aur ghar ke bahar rehne lagi."

"I used to be 20 kgs heavier - all my classmates used to make fun of me when I was that size."
"What happened then?"
"My doctor told me I had to stop putting on weight because I was on the verge of having thyroid. I decided to put my health first and followed the strictest diet routine - for 6 months I just focused on myself and didn't meet anyone."
"Do you meet these people now?"
"Yes, and those people are in shock over how much weight I've lost and they now say 'you're looking good'. But when I needed to hear it at that time, they mocked me - so now it doesn't matter."

"Mein zyada nahi kamati hoon lekin agar mein shikayat karne lagi toh inki di hui zindagi ka kya fayda? Isliye kehti hoon -haste raho aur chalte jao."

("I don't earn much, but what's the point of the life God has given if I start to complain? That's why I say, keep smiling and moving.")

"I'm a jeweler, born and brought up in Delhi. Having seen the best and worst of both worlds I can tell you that apart from having really bad roads, the enthusiasm and energy of this city is a league apart - no matter where you go you want to keep coming back."

"I've been doing this for 20 years, wearing the same uniform and working at this very spot."
"If you could do things differently, what would you do?"
"My family was so poor that they couldn't afford sending me to school. I always wonder where I would be if I had been educated. Today, I earn money so that my children can go to school and they don't have to pick odd jobs like me. When they complain about going to school - I tell them my story and stress on how without education life is so difficult."

("20 saal se yahi kar rahe hein, uniform bhi wahi - jagah bhi yahi."
"Agar aap kuch alaag kar sakte, woh kya hota?"
"Mera parivaar toh itna gareeb tha ki mujhe school bhejne ke paise nahi the. Hamesha sochta rehta hoon ki agar maine padhai ki hoti toh mein aaj yahaan nahi hota. Aaj paise kama kar mein apne bachon ko school bhejta hoon taki unhe aise- waise kaam nahi karne padhe. Jab woh school se pareshan hote hein, mein unhe yehi kehta hoon ki padhai ke bina zindagi bahut buri hoti hein.")

"I studied in Canada, but came back after a semester. I'm in my gap year - hopefully I'll get into a Bombay college and work side by side."
"How did that decision come about?"
"I realized that I wasn't learning much or enjoying my classes - I didn't want to get a degree just for the name."
"What have you been doing in your gap year?"
"I got an internship for a few months, travelled in North India, fell in one of the mightiest currents in Rishikesh and recently shaved my head."
"What's this time off taught you?"
"If you do exactly what you want to do there are never any regrets - just experiences that help you find who you are."

"How did you get into film-making?"
"It was a confusing path - I tried architecture, fashion designing and then filmmaking. Took 5 years of traveling, doing drugs, meeting new people to realize that I had to move out of engineering."
"How did your parents react to your decision?"
"Oh, my dad disowned me. My mom tried to stop him, but didn't work. Eventually when I got a job and he saw me dedicate my time to something I guess he forgave me. It was a 'Wake up Sid' kind of moment really.
"What's the best part about making films?"
"I don't know about the best or worst part, all I know is that the biggest downfall of the film industry was when someone decided Sunny Leone should star in a movie."
"But baby doll?"
"....No."

"Can you think of an experience that has left a mark on you?"
"It's actually a funny story about the tattoo I got. It's a saying in English which I wanted written in French...but it's wrong french because I was high when the idea came to my mind and I just google translated it."
"Were you high when you got it?"
"No, but that's the thing about being in that zone - the idea just sticks with you even when you're not in that state of mind."
"Do you regret it?"
"Not at all! It's still beautiful and I look down at it and know the meaning behind it ; even if there's a mistake to it - It's my mistake and I love it like that."

This man started off by giving us instructions on when to take the picture with succinct commands - 'Start. Okay? One more? Fine? Okay, thank you.' This is what he told us after -
"I've been doing this for 30 years now. I had a company job earlier but I realized early that I didn't want to be a part of the race. The money isn't as great as a job but look at the other benefits - It gives me time to enjoy other things in life, keeps me rooted to nature and helps me spread a little happiness in my own way."

"I used to teach journalism."
"If this was a lesson, what's the most important thing you would say about journalism?"
"When you've been on the other side, you know that a lot of journalism includes sensationalizing what's happened, and the truth is somewhere right at the bottom. So know this - whatever you see or read almost certainly has another side to it and the sad truth is that you're a media puppet, made to believe what they want you to believe."

"Dance accha chal raha hein, dost bhi acche ban gaye hein - ab bus girlfriend ki kami hein. Aapke page se mil jayegi? toh photo accha lena!"
