("My dance classes are doing fine, i've even made some good friends - now only a girlfriend is missing. If I'll get one from your page, make sure the picture is good!")

"I'm a first year student at Pratt in New York - I'm back now for my summer break."
"What's the most important thing you've learnt in this past year?"
"Smiling is so underrated. Just smiling can be one of the most powerful things you do for yourself and others around you - and that isn't necessarily limited to the people you know."

"I've just lost faith in the system."
"Why is that?"
"On 13th November they picked up the gate to my building (Campa Cola) like it was a toothpick, threw it out and when we all resisted we were lathi charged like criminals."
"What's keeping you going?"
"It's a fight for our homes. They've told us that they can make preventive arrests if need be - all because we're defending our shelter. Do you have any idea what it feels like to be in the constant fear of being homeless?"

"What experience would you say has changed you?"
"On 26th November 2008 I was at the Taj with the Korean consulate, celebrating the Korean National Day. At around 8PM I had a drink in my hand and I just put it away for a minute and the next thing I know it wasn't there - I guess that was the first sign. 
Just then my wife called me and said it had been 8 days since we had eaten dinner together and that she was feeling lonely so she wanted me home. Usually I wouldn't have left before midnight, but I just felt like I needed to be home so I left.
I'm a firm believer in destiny and I feel God wanted to save me, so he mediated it through my wife.   26/11 marks a day of tragedy, but on this day I was leased to live.
Life is too short – I'm 72 now and still hungry to learn as much as I can and see as much I can."

"I'm a typical Delhi girl who's recently moved to Bombay...and loving it!"
"Can you tell me in one sentence why you're 'loving it?'
"Oh, I can tell you in 4 words - Just so much safer!"

"3rd November, 1954 ko mein Bambai aaya aur driver ki naukri chalu ki. Uske baad mein yahaan-wahaan bahut ghuma. Maine Dubai, Muscat, Oman mein bhi naukri ki, par sab jagah ghum kar mein wapas yahi aa gaya."
"Kyun?"
"Kya kahoon? Mann hi nahi laga...paise achhe mil rahe the par jaan toh meri hamesha yahi thi."

(I first came to Bombay on 3rd November, 1954 and got a job as a driver. I worked in many different places after that including Dubai, Muscat, Oman but after everything I ended up coming back here."
"Why?"
"What do I say?The money was good but my heart has always been here.")

"I had a near-fatal car accident a few years ago, where my hand literally broke into two pieces. It was so ironical because I was working with Mouth and Foot Painting Artists at that point, where these artists didn't have hands but painted using other body parts. I felt like the accident happened to actually make me feel, how they felt."
"Would you say it was a good thing or a bad thing?"
"It was a great thing - it changed my perspective. Because of my leg graph I couldn't walk for really long and I just knew what I had to do once I could. I wanted to get back on my feet, work and actually feel the struggle that I once detested, because it is all of that, that makes it a great life."

"When my husband died, my in-laws wanted to remove my sons from school, but I didn't let it happen. I worked as a cleaner in LG for 27 years and supported my sons in a small room in Vashi. Today they both work in a bank and give me money, but I continue to work at different houses because I still don't like sitting at home."

("Jab mera aadmi mar gaya, mere saas- sasur mere bachon ko school se nikalna chahte the lekin maine aise hone nahi diya. 27 saal ke liye maine LG mein kaam kiya aur apne bachon ko Vashi mein ek chote room mein bada kiya. Aaj woh dono bank mein kaam karte hein aur mujhe paise dete hein, par mein ghar kaam karti hoon kyunki mujhe ghar bethna acha nahi lagta.")

"What would you say changed you?"
"My grandfather's death. I was in the States and couldn't make it for the last rites or see him one last time."
"What was the one thing you drew from him?"
"Even if someone did something to harm him in anyway, he wouldn't do anything bad in return. He was always so calm and patient with everyone around him- he chose to only see the good in people and I'm trying to make myself more like him."

"What would you say is your biggest struggle right now?"
"Just growing up I guess. You start seeing the world in so many different ways and realize that things aren't always the way you are."
"When did you realize that?"
"When I was at this camp called Seeds of Peace. There were students from 7 different countries and it was easy for us to live together. We grow up being told that we won't get along with people from other nations but at this camp I found that I could be exactly who I was and infact it was only there that not one of them judged me for it."

"We've been married for 5 years, but dated for 7 years before that."
"How did it all start?"
"With an email actually. We'd never spoken before, but he heard some rumor about me and another boy and sent me an email about how he felt."
"What's the best part about him?"
"That he married me. My parents weren't okay with our relationship but he was just so patient about everything. Undoubtedly the best thing he's done for me, is marry me."

"Aap kal nahi aa sakte ho madam? Aaj main woh apne Chulbul Pandey wale chashme bhool gaya!"

("Can you photograph me tomorrow?I forgot my Chulbul Pandey glasses today!")

"What was the freedom movement like?"
"It started for me when I was 12 years old. In those times the military base was at Kalina where British officers used to travel in carts and my friends and I would chase them saying, 'Quit India.' I've been to jail as well because I used to organize the 'Prabhat Pheris' (Morning ritual of singing patriotic songs). I've sung these songs with Gandhi and Nehru - it helped us unite people.
"What did you go on to do after?"
"I was the first female student to study physiotherapy in Bombay hospital. I was actually educated after my marriage because my husband and in-laws believed in education first. I went on to get additional degrees and even a job in London and USA and then that was it...I used to be in the hospital over 12 hours a day, just serving. I feel blessed because even before independence, we used to treat our freedom fighters."
"What advice would you give Indians?"
"Whatever we followed then, still applies now. Wear Indian, help Indians, Breathe India and Make India."
link_name: Photos from Humans of Bombay's post

status_message: Prayer and snack time at The Happy Home and School for the Blind where these little boys could maneuver their way around this space, without any assistance. In their prayer they thanked God for a beautiful life.

"There's no struggle, with this job or in life. What's not to like about my work? I eat a little myself and over feed all the other people around me!"

("Koi pareshani nahi hain, kaam mein ya zindagi mein. Mere kaam mein acha kya nahi hein? Khud thoda khaata hoon aur sabhi logon ko bahut khilata hoon!")

"What was the saddest moment of your life?"
"When I lost my brother, he was only 14 years old."
"What happened to him?"
"It started with a common cold, but it turned out to be meningitis. I don't know, you can never take anything for granted- be it your health or the time you have with someone you love."
"I don't know about what's been my happiest moment, but I know what's going to keep me happy for the rest of my life - I'm holding it in my arms right now."

"I'm a misfit in the Indian society. I'm 43 with no wife and no children. I've travelled the world, I know 20 languages, have 6 degrees and worked at 38 different jobs and I may still not have a rupee in my pocket right now, but I know how to live-I'm a one man show."
"What do you do now?"
"I'm a tour operator but I don't talk about what the government wants you to hear. I say it as it is -how hopes and dreams are offered here and how many do get fulfilled but also how many just die on the fucking streets."
"What is the one thing all these experiences have taught you?"
"I no longer give a shit about God and Satan, let them fight their own battles, I believe in Rock and Roll. Music is where I found my soul and I just don't give a shit about the rest!"

"When would you say you were the saddest?"
"There are so many- it's really hard to just pick one."
"And how old are you?"
"13."

"What do you do?"
"Nothing now, I just cook and clean in the house."
"What did you do before?"
"I used to work in a service company but after marriage my in-laws asked me to stop. Since then I raised my children and watched them grow."
"Where are they now?"
"One works in Dubai, the other in Assam. I left my job to raise them and now their work keeps me from seeing them...what can I even say? It's life I guess."

("Aap kya karte ho?"
"Ab kuch nahi, bas khaana banana, ghar saaf karna."
"Aur pehle?"
"Pehle mein ek service company mein kaam karti thi, par shaadi ke baad mujhe chodna pada. Uske bad bas bacche aur unko bada karne mein lag gayi."
"Woh ab kahaan pe hein?"
"Ek Dubai mein aur dusra Assam mein. Unko bada karne ke liye maine kaam choda aur ab dekho unka kaam hi mujhe unse door kar raha hein. Kya kahoon...shaayad yehi zindagi hein.")

"Who's your idol?"
"I don't have one idol in particular. I feel like there's something to idolize in everyone - which is why I want to study psychology, to help me understand people better."
"What's your bigger goal after studying psychology?"
"I'm going to try calming the demons that live within each of us."

"How long have you been playing for?"
"7 years now."
"How old are you?"
"I just turned 13."
"What have all these years of playing taught you?"
"I defeat boys who are a lot older than me. They make fun of me sometimes, but when I bat they keep quiet. It has taught me to stay calm and keep practicing."

"When we lived in India, it was all about work. It was only when we began to travel that we realized that we never got to experience the 'real India'. Ever since we've been back here we've only been traveling and exploring different parts of the country."
"What have you drawn from this experience?"
"Everyday we feel like so much needs to change here - infrastructure, facilities and the standard of living. India's beautiful no doubt, but in today's world you don't thrive yourself on beauty - you thrive on a beautiful life that so many people in India have never experienced."

I was sitting at the bottom of a dingy staircase talking to this man who was sitting on a chair, asking him about his life when this girl came up to me and said, "sit?" I asked her if she wanted to sit with us when she shook her head,smiled and ran off. She came back in around a minute with a plastic chair, looked at me and said 'sit,you?' 
Once in a while you come across a person that no appropriate words can describe -this girl was one of them.

"Do you enjoy music?"
"No."
"Then why are you doing this?"
"Why are you taking these pictures? I'm doing it for the same reason- to make money and feed my family. The only difference is you're lucky to have an education that gives you more choices to do what you really want."

("Apko gaana acha lagta hein?"
"Nahi."
"Toh phir aap yeh kyun kar rahe ho?"
"Aap yeh photo kyun le rahe ho? Ussi ke liye mein bhi yeh karta hoon - paise banane ke liye aur apne parivaar ko khilane. Farak sirf utna hein ki aapne padhai likhayi ki toh aap jo chahe woh kar sakte ho.")

"You collect moments as you go along. Mine are a bunch of firsts; first job- big moment, first student - big moment, when I was first blessed with a son-biggest moment and then a feeling I can't describe with words...when a student of mine landed his first job and thanked me for it."

"They say be a responsible citizen and vote. I checked 8 different voting booths for my name but it wasn't there. I had registered weeks before the registrations ended and got my voting ID but my name was still missing...what do members of these election committees have to say to that?"

"I live in the Himalayas. I've been working on making chimneys to cure respiratory problems for people who live there."
"Do you feel distanced because of the drift with technology?"
"Honestly, I miss a nice bed and a hot shower."
"What's the most important thing this process taught you?"
"Experiencing different lifestyles gives you shanti. You learn to place less value on money and more on these experiences that make you."

"I'm writing a thesis on citizenship and gender inequality in the country."
"What do you feel needs to change to help reduce the gap between men and women in India?"
"The lack of female independence. Women need to taste what real financial independence feels like - no parents, no husband, no boyfriend. I've been financially independent for close to 5 years - from getting a full scholarship at college, to working till I can sustain myself and there is no better feeling. It's not just the state that doesn't help us- this dependent attitude is getting us nowhere either."

"After so many years, I've started loving bananas with him...and I feel like we've even started looking alike."

("Itne saalo ke baadh mujhe kele pasand lagne lage hein aur aisa lagta hein ki hum ek jaise hi dikhte hein.")

"What advice would you give to people?"
"Have a positive mindset, in every situation."
"When have you struggled to be positive?"
"Now actually. I was born in Africa, lived for a better part of my life in France and now I just moved to Bombay with my boyfriend. I love this city but it's a struggle to adjust...and the food - just so spicy!"

"God made me this way and I suffer not having a job because of that. So the way I see it, It's not begging - It's his way of telling me to continue to fight and survive."

(Bhagwan ne mujhe aise banaya, isliye mujhe naukri nahi milti. Mere liye ye bheek nahi hein. Mein manta hoon ki yeh ek rasta hein jisse bhagwan mujhe ladne aur jeene ko keh raha hein.")

"How long have you known one another?"
"Around 8 months now."
"What's the best part about you two?"
"We're the forever kinds."
"Captain, here has been with me for years now. I've always loved racing horses, but overtime I found a friend in him - sometimes animals just understand you so much more than human beings."

"I've been here just 8 months, but I like the village better.Over there I would eat and be asleep by 9, but here the night doesn't even start before 9. This generation is moving too fast."

("Main yahaan sirf 8 mahine se hoon, lekin mujhe gao zyada pasand hein. Waha mein khaana khake, 9 baje tak so bhi jata tha, par yahaan 9 baje se pehle raat bhi shuru nahi hoti. Yeh zamaana bahut tej ja raha hein.")

"I'm retired, but I began assisting a dentist recently again. Everything is so expensive and you think you can survive only on the interest money, but you can't"
"What about your family?"
"I never married - there were too many responsibilities. I support my 92 year old cousin now, who's on permanent bed rest."
"So If you could change something about the way your life's been, what would you change?"
"I can still make a change and travel -my friends keep calling me, but again I have to stay at home to look after my sister or till I can afford full time help. That's why I'm 80 and still working.

"When have you been the saddest?"
"When my mother passed away a few years ago."
"What do you miss the most about her?"
"She was always worried about me -  whether it was about my food or my studies. I miss knowing that someone cares about everything to do with me."

"It's about perspective. You pride yourself about living in one of the biggest cities in the world, but it doesn't bother you that the largest slum is also a huge part of it. It's what you choose to see, and then what you choose to do about it."

"The grass always appears greener on the other side. Today, you feel like you have a shit job and move...and as soon as you're at your new job you prefer the old one. I speak from experience- it's better to just stick it out."
Today's the day - you have until 6PM to vote. Humans of Bombay, make this one count!

"It's an image that's half Shiva, half Parvati, something like the Yin Yang."
"What does it symbolize?"
"They're opposite energies, yet they're both required to maintain eternal stability in the universe. It also has all the elements- earth, fire, air and water which balance each other out as well. The intensity of it was so high, it took 18 hours to make..at one point he had to stop because he couldn't differentiate between the color of my blood and the red ink."

"What's your biggest struggle right now?"
"It's difficult to sustain myself here, not being able to get what I want. This city is so expensive as is and if you're unhappy with where you are with your career it just drains you financially and emotionally. It's bittersweet- the process is frustrating, but you can neither give up the city, or the dreams that come with it."
"We're best friends because we're just really similar and no it's not only about the big hair....but yeah, that too!"

"If you could change one thing about India, what would it be?"
"The entire electoral system is chaos. When I vote, I'm not sure if my actual vote is being registered, or it's going to be manipulated. They say every vote counts, but if the voting system itself is corrupt and they've already decided who's going to win, you end up thinking, does it even really matter?"

"It's funny, we call ourselves educated but more often than not it's the people driving fancy cars that throw trash outside their windows. What's the point of having all that money, when you fail in something so basic?"

"What would your advice to women of India in particular be?"
"Don't live in the fear of being a woman. I feel like women, along with men need to burst the bubble that she needs to be protected. Just explore your inner power and embrace it – you'll be invincible.
"Remember your dignity as a woman is God given. Unless he took a human body form, he could not save us - so he made use of a woman to do the saving."

When we first approached him we began talking in Hindi. He responded in English to the initial few questions when we picked up that not only did he speak the language, but he spoke it pretty fluently. The most striking thing he said in the conversation was -
"Even educated people can work in security, it isn't demeaning."

"There's such a big distance between women, even in the workplace. Men support each other, celebrate their promotions, but there's so much jealousy with women. Women need to grow together because men will always divide you - you'll get divided into groups and he'll end up with the promotion!"

"What's the tattoo for?"
"It's my son's name."
"Oh.."
"Yeah, because he's the best thing that's happened to me."

"I'm a copywriter."
"If you could summarize the current political state of affairs in India in one line, what would it be?"
"Depressing choice for the people without any possible healthy outcome."

"Have you ever been in love?"
"A lot of times! People learn from mistakes, I've decided not to learn from mine. Being in love is the best feeling in the world, so I'll keep falling over and over again -till it doesn't end in a fall."

"I moved to the States when I was 2 and at 17 my parents asked me to leave the house and make something of myself. My dad dropped me to Bombay and left. I stay here with my friend - I've just given my 12th grade exams and have a full time job now."
"What's your biggest dream?"
"I really just want to make money - as much as a I can of it."

"Why blue?"
"Oh, it's not always blue, It's actually like a mood ring. I change it every 2-3 weeks depending on how I feel."
"So if you had to give advice to a large group of people, what would it be?"
"What do you want to do? If you want to shave your head - do it! People will always talk.. as long as you're not hurting anyone-do exactly what your heart tells you."

"What's the best part about your brother?"
"That he supports the same football team as me."

"What's the best part about living in Bombay?"
"Women are safe here. I'm an air-hostess, naturally I've travelled a lot- but no other city has made me feel as safe as Bombay does."

"What's the best piece of advice you've ever gotten?"
'Without compassion you have no existence'. And it's true, If you can learn to be compassionate your inner realm becomes just as strong and beautiful."

"He's my best friend. He can put a smile on my face at any point. Do a lot of girls follow your page?"
"Probably, why?"
"I'm trying to find him a girlfriend, can you mention that he's single and just the best?"

"What's your biggest struggle right now?"
"I'm overqualified for the position I'm working in and I'm not getting a promotion."

"What has been the happiest moment of your life?"
"I had a really fatal accident some years ago. My happiest moment was when I could walk again after. Today I'm grateful for everything that I would otherwise take for granted, because of that."

"Just today morning he was running around, happily screaming all because I told him I'll take him for a swim. The happiness on his face over something this trivial, makes being a father even more fulfilling than it already is."

"What's the best part about music?"
"It fills you up with joy - it touches your soul."
"What's your biggest dream?"
"That you'll be able to hear me on the radio one day."

-A visually impaired student at the Happy Home and School for the Blind.

"Dance for me is the biggest form of expression"
"What does this particular move mean to you?"
"Freedom."

"What do you want to be when you grow up?"
"A pilot."
"Why a pilot?"
"Because then you can look up at the sky and say hi to me anytime!"

"I'm originally from Delhi, I recently moved to Bombay."
"What's the change been like?"
"Well..I love the fact that I roam around in shorts in Bombay - that didn't happen too often in Delhi!"

"What is the one change you want to see in India after elections?"
"The income tax slabs need to be more relaxed. It should be increased to say a sum of 5lakhs, so the common can get that income tax return and collect more revenue. We need to start paying attention to these little things that can change India, no matter which party comes to power- the bigger picture, in every sense.
"I haven't been in love. I just end up fighting with all of these guys. I think either they're crazy, or I am!"

"What's your biggest struggle right now?"
"I feel like living in this city is a struggle in itself. I for one detest commuting and have to do it for over an hour everyday. Eventually, I began photographing one person on the train everyday and made an entire portfolio out of it. 
"So what's the best part about living in the city?"
"Again, Bombay itself. It's only here that even your biggest struggle can produce your best work."

"We were better off when the British were ruling us. Atleast that time we didn't overpay for basic things like bread and water."
"Why do you say that?"
"Look at how much we pay for something as basic as transport. I used to travel from Dadar to Fort in 2 rupees. Today, I don't even travel that far because I can't afford it. These politicians have eaten up our money. Atleast the British put our money into making the quality of life better."
"Who will you vote for this time?"
"The congress has been running since those times. It's the only party I've ever voted for and although they haven't been delivering what they're supposed to, I'll continue to put my faith in them..I don't even know the names of the other competitors, to be honest."

"Chalis saal se paan bech rahe hein, lekin pichle kuch saalo se lag raha hein ki yeh paan ki dukaan kum, aur cigarette ki dukaan zyada hein."

("I've been selling paan since the past forty years, but since the past few years it feels less like a paan shop and more like a cigarette shop.")

"Madam, take how many ever pictures you want..just don't disturb me right now."

("Madam, jitne bhi photo le sakte ho le lo. Bas mujhe disturb mat karo.")

"What was the happiest moment of your life?"
"When I saw my baby's face for the first time."

"What's the best part about your granddaughter?" 
"She's assertive at a young age."
"How has she been assertive?"
"She loves the attention on herself all the time. The other day she was dancing to that lungi song when I just looked away for a minute to answer a phone call and she stopped dancing to say - 'look at me - i'm not there, i'm here!'"

"If you had to give advice to a large group of people, what would it be?"
"There's no room for hate. Once you leave behind that anger and hatred, you begin spreading the peace and love and that's the basic 'human' thing one can do."

"What was the happiest moment of your life?"
"The day I decided I didn't want to become an engineer and actually pursued my passion for writing."
"How did that come about?"
"I read a lot of Gulzar Sahab when I was an engineer. It's difficult to explain what happened internally during that period. These poems took me into a different zone entirely and I realized that writing..in whichever form it is, is my true calling."

"Pehle kabhi kissi ne aise photo nahi liya hein. Kya Karoo main?"

("No one has taken my photograph like this before. What should i do?")

"What's the best part about her?"
"She has the most beautiful smile."
"What's the best part about him?"
"He's just a little child inside."

"Aap kahan se ho?"
"Hum Allahbad se hain, kuch saal pehle parivaar ke saath jhagda hua, aur hum bombai aa gaye"
"Bombay kyun?"
"Bombai Allahbad waalon pe bahut meherbaan raha hai. Humare amitji bhi toh aaye the."
"Phir kya hua?"
"Kuch nahi. Pehle toh kaam nahi mila. Bahut idhar udhar bhagna pada. Bambai ki hawa nahi jami.
"Aur ab?"
"Ab kya. Bambai ne is musafir ko bhi panah de di. Jab main tut ke bikhar ne wala tha, tab Bambai ne sambhal liya."

("Where are you from?"
"I'm from Allahabad. A few years ago, I had a fight with my parents and came to Bombay."
"Why Bombay?"
"Bombay has been very kind to people from Allahabad, even Amitji is from there only."
"Then what happened?"
"Nothing, I didn't get a job for a while. I had to run from here to there..the Bombay air didn't suit me."
"And now?"
"Now what. Bombay gave me a chance as well. Just when I was going to break..it took care of me.")

"Jab mein ikkis saal ki thi, mera pati mar gaya. Do-teen saal mein sirf ghar mein rehti thi aur din bhar roti thi. Uske baad maine naukri karne ka faisla kiya. Mere saas-sasur tokte rehte hein lekin mein imandari se kaam karti hoon aur khud ke paise kamaati hoon."

"When I was 21 years old, I lost my husband. For two-three years after I used to stay at home all day, crying. After that I decided to look for a job. My in-law's nag me about it but I continue to work with honesty and earn my own money."

"How long have you been married?"
"About 500 years..it feels like forever."
"What's been your best memory?"
"...of not being married!"

"She's my best friend."
"What makes her your best friend?"
"We both love the color red!"
"What's so special about the color red?"
"It's the color of love!"

"Chalis saal se ek hi ghar mein kaam karti hoon."
"Aur aapke bacche?"
"Maine shaadi nahi banayi."
"Kyun?"
"Kyun, banana zaroori hein?"

("I've been working at the same house since the past 40 years."
"What bout your children?"
"I've never been married."
"Why?"
"Why, is it necessary to get married?")

"I used to work with an airline, but I quit to become a make up artist."
"What was the change like?"
"I feel like a magician."
"Why a magician?"
"Ever heard of 'age is just a number'? Well, I can actually take that number down several years with my make up. It isn't just make up, it's art."

"Aap yeh kab se kar rahe ho?"
"8th standard se..jab se school choda."
"School kyun choda?"
"Paise hi nahi the."
"Toh phir construction kyun?"
"Hamare yahaan, construction wale ladkiyo mein bahut famous hote hain."

("Since when are you into this?"
"From the 8th standard..ever since I left school."
"Why did you leave school?"
"There was no money to pay."
"So why did you get into construction?"
"From where I come, construction workers are very popular with the girls.")

"Kya hum aapka photo le sakte hein?"
"Kya aap newspaper se ho?"
"Nahi. Hum bas photo lete hai logon ke."
"Acha. Yahan pe bahut paper wale aate hai. Unhe lagta hai hum kaafi sexy hain."
"Zaroor chacha, kya hum aap ka photo le le?"
"Lelo beta. Aur phir market ka bhi photo lena. Koi kuch bole toh mujhe batana. Iss ilake ka thakur hoon main."

("Can we take your picture?"
"Are you from a newspaper?"
"No, we just take pictures of different people."
"Oh, a lot of newspaper people come here. They think I'm quite sexy."
"Ofcourse uncle, we'll take your picture now?"
"Yes, take the picture. And also take pictures of the market. If anyone says anything come tell me - I'm the 'boss'(thakur) of this district.")

"I stopped working to raise my children 20 years ago."
"What made you get back into it?"
"I work in a day care, so the opportunity to raise so many children helped me combine my 2 passions and I ended up finding a new purpose to life."

"Okay, now we're going to take your photograph."
"But you haven't even said, 'say cheese'!"

"What do you do?"
"I'm a celebrity manager."
"What's the best part about that?"
"You get to hangout with the celebrities."
"What's the worst part?"
"Everything else."

"Mere pati ko mare hue kaafi saal ho gaye, mein akeli in baccho ko sambhalti hoon."
"Aap yeh kaise karte ho?"
"Din bhar 10- 9 yahan, kapde ki mill mein kaam karti hoon. Lekin bahut tension hein. Bombay ka kharcha aur uske upar unke taxi ka bank ka loan joh badta ja raha hein."
"Aapko kissi ki sahayta mangi chahiye."
"Sahatya toh chahiye – mein apne baccho ko aisa kabhi nahi dekhna chahti. Lekin sahayta maang kar thak chuki hoon – kissi ko hamari kya fikar? Lekin agar mujhe pacchis ghante bhi kaam karna pade toh mein khushi se karoongi taki beta engineer banne or beti doctor."
 
("My husband passed away a few years ago – I'm bringing these children up by myself."
"How do you manage that?"
"I work everyday at a clothing mill from 10 -9, but I'm in a lot of stress. Bombay is an expensive city to live in and the loan that we had taken for my husband's taxi is just rising."
"You should ask someone for assistance."
"I really need the help because I never want to see my children in this situation. But I'm tired of asking for it because nobody bothers with us. Its okay – If I have to work 25 hours a day, I'll do it happily to see my son become an engineer and my daughter a doctor.")

"Meri beti school mein 1st aayi hai."
"Kaunsi kaksha mein hai?"
"Doosri kaksha."
"Kitne bacche hai aap ke?"
"Ek hi. Lekin ladki hai isi liye mere saans sasur usse zyada pyar nahi karte. Mujhe yeh samaj nahi aata ,  kyunki meri saans bhi toh aakhir aurat hi hai. Lekin mujhe parvah nahi. Main meri beti koh hazaar logon ka pyar akeli hi de sakti hoon."

("My daughter stood first in her school"
"Which standard is she in?"
"She's in the second standard."
"How many children do you have?"
"Just one, but because she is a girl my inlaws don't love her as much, but i don't understand why because ultimately my mother in law is also a woman. But this doesn't bother me - I can give her the love of a thousand people by myself.")

When we met this man and explained our concept to him, he excitedly beamed back at us and showed us this tomato shaped like Ganpati (an Indian God), that he had found in the market. This was what he had to say when we asked what this meant to him:

"Yeh mere naseeb main tha, aur ab jab main inki pooja karke samundar mein visarjan karoonga, toh mujhe yakeen hain ki meri kismatt badal jayegi."

("Finding this was in my destiny, and now when I pray to it and release it into the sea, I know that my luck is going to change forever.")

"We were drunk last night and making a lot of noise when the cops came. We got into a huge argument, and they asked us to go to the police station - so we went with them. "
"Wasn't that scary?"
"At first. But then we paid them some money, laughed it off and got ourselves a roll."

"I started off as an office boy and as time went by I began concentrating more and worked hard to get more responsibility. Today I've progressed to admin work and accounting, it's a great feeling."
"What made the transition easy?"
"All my colleagues. They helped me every step of the way. They could have looked down at me as an office boy, but they supported me to get me to where I am."

("Main pehle office boy tha aur dheere dheere main apne kaam pe aur dhyan dene laga aur mehnat karke mujhe aur zimedari mili. Aaj mein account department mein kaam karta hoon."
"Yeh aapke liye kaise raha?"
"Mere saath jo kaam karte hein, unhone mujhe bahut maddatt ki. Woh chahte toh mujhe office boy hi rakhte lekin mein aaj yahaan pe hoon toh unki wajah se.")

"Hi, are you clicking pictures of Haji Ali?" 
"We're just clicking pictures of people." 
"Are you a Muslim?" 
"No"
 "You know I used to teach in Islamic schools, but I had to stop." 
"Why?" 
"Because I believe that different religions are different paths to the same God but not in the way that Osama thought of it. He is a terrorist." 
"So now what do you do?" 
"This. I walk around Haji Ali trying to talk to people."

"What inspired you to get your tattoo?"
"I believe that everything in the universe is connected. There is a quote by Bill Hicks which says that all matter is merely energy condensed to a slow vibration, that we are all one consciousness experiencing itself subjectively. This makes me believe that everything is connected."
"When in your life have you felt like something has connected?"
"Well, at this very moment actually. I love your page, and now I'm on it."

"I've been a ballerina since the past 10 years."
"What's the best part about being a ballerina?"
"You can speak to people with your dance. You put all your emotions and you need nothing else - your rhythm speaks more than any words ever will."

"What has been the happiest moment of your life?"
"Happy moments are fleeting, they don't last. A sad moment will always be more permanent because it hits you harder."
"So what was the saddest moment of your life?"
"When I lost my father to cancer."
"How did you manage to deal with it?"
"We knew the end was close, so we were prepared. Although we were losing him, a part of us was happy because he would finally be free from the pain."

"Can we take a picture of you?"
"No wait, let me just make my hair first."

"If you had to give advice to a large group of people, what would it be?"
"Accept the will of God. Accept the changing patterns of the universe. There's only one soul which is permanent. Feel only that and enjoy the bliss. When you're hurtful towards others you hurt that soul and in turn yourself. When you look at it like that, you just get more compassionate towards everything around you and you realize that ultimately, it is love that makes the world go round - nothing else."

"In advertising you tend to work weekends and you're just dying on a Saturday morning because of how much you've drank the previous night. But when has that mattered to anybody? 
I mean, I survive the week only 'cause I know Friday's coming!"

"What was the happiest moment of your life?"
"When I bought my first bike."
"What was the saddest moment of your life?"
"When my brother passed away in a bike accident."
"Isn't that a dichotomy?"
"It is, but I never let that stop me from riding bikes. It's life - you have to overcome fear, you cannot let fear overcome you."

"What are your hobbies?"
"I like playing cricket."
"Who's your favourite cricketer?"
"Sachin."
"But he's retired now."
"...But I'm still his biggest fan."

"If you had to give advice to people what would it be?"
"Dress well, look good. My father always said, you could be unemployed and hanging around an office, dressed well and who knows someone might just pick you up and hire you! And of course attitude also matters. You could be wearing shorts and a T-shirt but still have that 'come get me guys' look, you know what I mean?"

"Aapko yeh kaise hua?"
"Mera aadmi peekar maarta hain. Ek din usne kerosene daalkar mujhe jalaa daala. Mein aaj zinda hu toh meri maa ki wajah se, meri maa ne mujhe bachaaya.
"Aap police ke pass nahi gaye?"
"Gayi Thi. Usko sirf 3 mahine jail mein rakha. Kuch paisa bhi nahi diya. Uss waqt meri maa ne hi mujhe sambhala."
"Aap uske saath abhi rehte ho?"
"Haan, woh hamara aadmi hein. Zindagi bhar ussi ke saath rehna hain."

("How did this happen to you?"
"My husband is an alcoholic who beats me when he is drunk. One day he burnt me with kerosene. I'm alive today only because of my mother, she has always been my saviour."
"Didn't you go to the police?"
"I did.They jailed my husband for only 3 months and didn't give me any money for the duration he was there, but my mother took care of me."
"Are you still with your husband?"
"Yes, he is my husband, I have to be with him for the rest of my life.")
"We call him Tasty Singh at home, we just feel like eating him up all the time!"
"I'm sick of guys saying, 'oh you're PMSing.' Fuck you ya, maybe you're the problem, and not the fact that I have a uterus!"

"Were you alive during the partition of India?"
"Oh yes, and you won't believe the things I've seen. My papa got left behind in Lahore but my mother managed to escape. I went to Lahore looking for him and I saw trains filled with people half killed and bleeding."
"Did your father make it?"
"He did. In those times we had a Muslim driver. Believe it or not when Hindus and Muslims were at brutal war with one another, a Muslim driver dropped my Hindu father to the border on a bullock cart. So yes we all made it and by god's grace - I made it big."
"I'm 86, but don't be fooled! I don't even need this stick...my son just forces me to use it."

"I'm not from here, I shifted to Bombay only 7 months ago."
"Why did you decide to shift base?"
"Don't laugh, but one of the main reasons I came here was because Marine Drive was on my bucket list."
"We are trying to discover who we are; and we find that travel is the best way to do it."

"Hum kisaan hai, lekin yeh kaam karne ka matlab hai ki hamein takleefon ka saamna karna padta hai."
"Aapko kaisi takleefon ka saamna karna padta hai?"
"Hum mehenge daamon pe beej khareedte hai, fir bhi hamari fasal acchi nahi hoti kyonki hamari zameen paushtik nahi hai. Hum sarkar se madat maangte hai, lekin hamien koi madat nahi karta. Hum laachaar hain."
"Aapne kabhi kuch aur karne ka socha hai?"
"Kabhi nahi. Yeh hamari zindagi hai, hum isse kabhi nahi chhodenge. Hum saare desh ko khaana dete hai, khaane ke bina, aapke paison ka koi kaam nahi, aap kuch nahi khareed payenge."

("We are farmers. But being in this profession means that you have to face a lot of hardships everyday."
"What hardships do you have to face?"
"We buy seeds at high prices, but eventually we produce low quality produce because our land is not nutrient-rich enough. We ask the government for help but we get no response. We are helpless."
"Have you ever thought of doing something else besides farming?"
"Never. This is our life, we will not give it up for anything. We provide food for the entire nation, without our food, your money will be worthless because you will have nothing to buy.")

"Hum pandhra saal se yeh kar rahein hain. Ek baar hum Andheri recreational club mein ek bahut badi party mein guard bane the. Tab humme ek assi hazaar rupiyo ka diamond mila tha, aur humne lost & found mein jamma kar diya. Uske badle mein, humein ek award aur hazaar rupiye ka inaam mila. Humara khyal hain ki imaandiri se jiyo aur safalta ka phal apne aap aayega."

("We've been doing this for 15 years. This one time, there was a big party at Andheri Recreational Club, and we were on duty. After the party was over, we found an 80 thousand rupee diamond and returned it to lost and found. As a reward, they gave us an award and a 1 thousand rupee cash prize. We feel like if you're honest, success will come to you.")

"Are you a very religious person?"
"Not really. Till date religion has done nothing good for me, but I've been through so much in my life that I feel like I need to wear all of this to please the Gods. I'm giving them all a chance to prove themselves, with the hope that someday at least one of them will deliver."

"How would you describe your friendship?"
"I'd say we balance each other out. One of us is the risk-taker who is always up for an adventure, one of us thinks twice before doing something, and I'm the neutral one. I keep both of them in check."

"What's the one thing you love the most in this world?"
"My twin sister...she looks just like me!"

"I used to be a hairdresser, but I completely switched over my profession and now, I'm the Group Account Manager of my firm."
"What was that switch like?"
"Honestly, I'm living my dream. I came into this firm knowing nothing, my boss was far too kind and gave me a chance to prove myself. From cutting hair to working as a Digital Marketing Manager, that's a huge jump right there."
"So, if you had to give advice to people what would you say?"
"Go after what you love, and success is bound to follow."

"Hi, can we take your photograph? We have this page called Humans of Bombay..." 
"Oh man, a friend of mine started Humans of Amsterdam, and she's been trying to get me on it since so long. She's going to say 'Shanti, what the hell are you doing up there?'"

"What do you do?"
"I'm an architect getting my footing back in Bombay. I was interning in Auroville before that."
"What was that like?"          
"Well for starters, I thought that I had stepped into Lala Land. There was so much silence you could hear yourself think. I lived in a forest, and the whole place seemed like home...I felt a bit like Mowgli."
"How does it feel like to be back?"
"Coming back to Bombay makes things seem more real; even though everyone needs an escape every once a while."

"What's your biggest dream?"
"To become a soldier so that I can fight for the country. What's your biggest dream?"
"To make $200,000 and go to space, but I haven't made so much  money yet."
"Oh that's easy. Why don't you go on Quikr.com and sell things? You'll make money in no time."

"I've been playing football since I was in the 6th standard. Just last week my team won a match, and I was awarded the best player on the ground. We haven't been performing too well since the past 6 months, and so this was the perfect motivation."  
"What's the one thing you love about football?"
"When I'm on the field I forget about everything else, it's just me and the game. My focus is the goal. Aim, shoot, score."
"My granddaughter and I spend the evening together everyday. She can be quite the attention monster. You know what they say about grandchildren? An hour with them, and you feel young again."

"What do you think has been the most defining moment of your life?" 
"My decision to forgo the family business and pursue my dream to get into marketing. It isn't easy to make a decision like that, especially when you're the only son and have a set business to take over." 
"What influenced this decision?" 
"I see myself in the percentage of people who don't follow what their parents have laid out for them. I believe you need to make that decision at some point because eventually you have to live with it. We're in a city where dreams are built every second of the day-I would just have to push hard to make mine a reality.

"What do you do?"
"I run a buddy system project where we pair children with special-needs children. 
"How does this help them?"
"You don't see how well they complement each other until you realise that they always have something new to learn from one another...and that's how they grow."

"What do you do?"
"I'm a documentary filmmaker. I've been travelling all over India shooting some films."
"So what's the best part about this country?"
"Definitely Bombay. The energy of this city is something indescribable. It just manages to give me a rush of a different kind."

"What's the saddest you've ever been?"
"I'm really not a sad-sad kind of guy, but you could say I felt a deep sense of loss when I lost a few followers on twitter!"

"What's been the happiest moment of your life?"
"When a non-verbal autistic child I had worked with throughout college, said my name for the first time."

"Kya aapko yeh kaam pasand hain?"
"Aur koi chara bhi nahin hain, humne padhai nahin ki, umar ke hisaab se yeh hi kaam mila.
"Aap zindagi se kya chahte ho?"
"Ab mera kya, mein toh yeh hi karta hoon. Haan lekin main apne baccho ko padhaana chahta tha, aur aaj mera beta woh computer company Quikr mein kaam karta hain. Bus yeh hi kaafi hain, zindagi se aur kuch nahin chahiye."

("Do you like your job?"
"I don't have a choice, I haven't been educated and according to my age this is the only job I got"
"What do you want from life?"
"What can I say, this is all I do. But yes, I've always wanted to educate my children, and today my son is working with that computer company, Quikr. That itself is enough for me...I don't want anything else from life.")

"What bothers you about the world?"
"The pointlessness of a lot of things. We live in a world where the pursuit of selling more and more is a bit too much. Sometimes, a lot of what I do is pointless, but I try and work towards an idea that has some meaning; one that has some sort of feeling."
"So what advice would you give to a large group of people?"
"Give a damn. Ask yourself at the back of your head whether giving a damn is going to make a difference to someone else's life and go out there and do something about it."

We first saw her walking with three other burkha-clad women and a man. When we approached her for permission to photograph her, she looked at the man for approval. After we explained our concept, he nodded and said "take the picture." This was the conversation that followed with her:
"Where are you from?"
"No English"
"Aap kidhar se ho?"
"No Hindi"
Sensing that the others were getting agitated, we thanked her and began walking away, at which point she murmured the word -"peace."

"Hum Rajasthan se aaye hain. Waha kuch zyada nahin karte the, par yahaan pe hum dhanda karte hain. Humare bhi kuch sapne hain, isliye hum yahaan aaye...kyonki sabko pata hain ki Mumbai sapno ka shehar hain."

("We're here from Rajasthan. We didn't do as much there, but here we work. We too have our dreams, that's why we came here, because everyone knows that Mumbai is the city of dreams.")

"I used to be a professor in Lucknow, life was very hectic. But now Im retired-life is lazy, life is good. I sit around, go for morning walks, and time goes by. Then once in a while strangers like you come for a chat...and time goes by even faster."

"Didi, can I ask you a question?"
"Yes, of course."
"Can you use two conjunctions side by side in one sentence?"
"Why don't you tell us how to?"
"Life is beautiful, and so are you." 
"Wow, who taught you that?"
"My teacher, Dipti Didi...she says this to us every day."

"When did you meet her?"
"The first time we met was when I was 16, our parents chose us for one another. I knew I had to say yes no matter what, without speaking, without as much as a glance. But I'm so thankful to them for finding her…she ended up being my soul mate." 
"What do you think has kept the love alive all these years?"
"We communicate. Youngsters today, don't talk for days on end when they fight. We fight, but since the age of 16, we've been together for 60 years and there hasn't been a day that we haven't spoken to each other."

"Is it hard being a female videographer?"
"It is, there are crowds of people you have to deal with and most people stare all the time."
"When has it been the hardest to deal with?"
It was in this village where Rahul Gandhi was making an appearance. There were thousands of people and someone just pinched me while the rest kept staring. I had to eventually move behind the police force and shoot from there. But I don't let these things stop me from shooting - it's been my passion since childhood. Ultimately my camera is my weapon...it makes me feel empowered."
"Is se rozi-roti chal jaati hain. Main unse paise nahi lena chahti...main apne aap kuch banna chahti hoon."

"What do you want to be when you grow up?"
"Batman!"
"What's your favorite thing about batman?"
"That he's on my face and he's a bat."

"Are you waiting for someone?"
"Yes, I am actually. My roommates have my keys. I'm currently locked out of my own house."

"What do you do?"
"I'm a photographer, working at an NGO"
"What have you drawn from that experience?"
"It's just amazing how much smarter these kids are compared to us.They've been brought up with so much care at these NGOs while allowing them to be independent at the same time." 
"What experience there has touched you the most?"
"We were once at an exhibition and we asked these girls a set of questions, to which one answered- the most beautiful things in the world are nice people. It was something so innocent and simple. It made me realise that they give me so much more than I can ever give them."

When we approached this man, the first thing he said was "No English, French French." After  minutes of frantic sign language and broken English , we got him to understand that we wanted to photograph him for our page. When we managed to ask him why he was waiting with his suitcase in the middle of the street, all he did was point at the bar opposite him and smiled.

"How long has it been since you guys started dating?
"We've been with each other since years now."
"So what's the best part about him?"
"He has so much respect for me"
"What annoys you about him?" 
"He can be possessive. It's flattering but annoying from time to time, you know?"
"You've been really quiet this whole time, why don't you tell us what annoys you about her?"
".....she talks too much"

"I'm not an atheist, but I don't believe anyone knows what God is. I pray once in a while. I feel like people pray when they do bad things. The few times I've done bad things I've gone to pray- It's a redemption of sorts" 
"So what's your go-to when you're in a tough situation?"
"I go to logics, I go back to my basics. I don't think, 'I'm in this fucked up situation, let me go pray.' I'm just grateful to nature for keeping me vertical and above the ground"
"Lawyers are the most dynamic, innovative, and passionate people around. Who else can convince you that the glass is half full, when you know it's actually half empty?"

"Jab main chhota tha tab main padhai mein bahut kamzor tha. Mere professor ne mujhe art ki disha dikhayi. Uske baad main har din VT jaa kar sketch karta tha. Phir bas, 50 saal se le kar aaj tak...main yeh hi kar rahaan hoon."

"Where did you meet?" 
"I met her at a party. After two days, I asked her out on a date and surprisingly, she said yes. When she arrived, the first thing I noticed were her shoes. She was wearing flats instead of heels. I knew right then that this woman was both–caring and understanding...she didn't want me to look too short."

"What's your biggest goal?"
"To become a model"
"Are you pursuing it?" 
"No, I'm studying engineering, not everyone gets to follow their dreams."
"We're in the navy. We could have settled for a 9-5 job, but that's not what life is about, is it? You need to go out there, travel, and see the world."

"What's your biggest dream?"
"I'm actually going to live it soon. I've quit my job and I'm moving to Goa at the end of the week with my life partner"
"Why such a drastic change?"
"At 31 you strike a button and want to do something else. You realise that you can't wait to do what you've always wanted to do, or live the life you've always wanted to live. You only have now. You can call it the big 30 change."

"What do you love most about India?"
"The Taj Mahal."
"Why?"
"Who doesn't love a love story?"

"What's the craziest thing you've done?"
"This. Why am I talking to strangers in the middle of the street, in the middle of the night, when I'm late for my meeting?"

"Aapka favourite gaana kaunsa hai?"
"Aaj kal ke gaane toh sab dhik-chik, dhik-chik hote hain, koi slow bandha ho toh usko naachte naachte heart attack ho jaye."

"Where are you from?"
"I'm from Korea, I've been a part of this city since a year now and have been studying interior design."
"What's the craziest thing you've done?"
"Actually...I didn't only come here to study...I left everything behind and came here to be with the woman I love."

"What has been your happiest moment?"
"Finding myself. The more I started loving who I am, the more I found myself."
"If you had to give advice to people, what would it be?" 
"Before judging someone try to understand their background, because you don't know where they've come from or what they've been through."

"Kya aap Shah Rukh Khan se kabhi mile ho?"
"Haan bahut baar"
"Woh kaise hain?"
"Khan Khan hain bhai, khubsurati ka khazaana hai- Khan ka khazaana hai."
"She's my sister. From childhood to now, we've always been together and these evening walks have become a ritual. Because no matter how old you are, everyone needs sister time you know?"

"Can we photograph your dog?"
"You can't do it for free"
"Is he expensive to shoot?"
"Yeah, he's expensive, but I'm pretty cheap."

"I'm a pro feminist. What I want people to understand is that you can't distinguish men and women in their work. Women are doing super jobs, even as mothers. We provide a peaceful environment at home while still having to do as much. Like the saying goes, only if you lose something do you realise it's value, after work if a man sees a messy home he'll  realise. We're probably emotional in return, but you'll just have to respect that about us."

"What's your best memory together?"
"We went looking for this ice cream shop that he wanted to take me to, we spent all day in the rain looking for it, at the end of the day we found the place, but landed up taking the wrong train home."

"If you had to give advice to a large group of people what would you say?" 
"People really need to dance a little more"

"I just started my own company"
"Hire him as an intern" 
"Ya hire me, what can I do for you?"
"Develop an app or something?"
"What develop an app, this chut will develop a bong for you"

"What do you do?"
"Divine Power has created me only for feature film writing, so I want to write till my last breath."
"How is that going for you?"
"I'm sure you've heard that quote that when you want something, all the universe conspires in helping you to achieve it - that is my life. 
"How so?"
"I've not earned anything since 2001, everything I have the shoes, the bag, the jeans are all a gift. When rent is due, the money comes from odd jobs I do but I continue to come here all day to write and I guess now I'm going to Hollywood - they liked my script."

"I came to Bombay as a child not knowing why."
"Then what happened?"
"I had dreams to go abroad."
"Did you?"
"My wife gave birth to 3 daughters. I have spent my life earning money for their weddings."
"Do you regret not being able to go abroad?"
"Do you have a daughter?"
"No."
"Then you wouldn't know what it feels like to get her married happily!"

"At one point they made me chairperson of the Worli Association and I made a lot of changes to the seaface landscape.
